For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"quantum thermodynamics\" and \"squeezed reservoir\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. A squeezed\u2010reservoir\u2013assisted Bell\u2010state analyzer: use a two\u2010mode squeezed ancilla (realized by two probabilistic pair sources) to enable a near\u2010deterministic Bell measurement on two photonic qubits. This combines teleportation (Bell analysis) with a squeezed \u201cheat\u2010bath\u201d resource but stays within linear\u2010optics and post\u2010selection.\n\n  2. A SWAP\u2010engine network implementing a single\u2010stroke quantum heat engine: exchange (SWAP) the state of a \u201csystem\u201d qubit with a \u201chot\u201d squeezed\u2010reservoir qubit, then with a \u201ccold\u201d vacuum\u2010reservoir qubit, all via linear\u2010optics, post\u2010selected SWAP gates. This simulates one cycle of a quantum Otto engine.  \n\n  3. A three\u2010node entanglement\u2010swapping heat\u2010valve: nodes A and C are cold, node B is coupled to a squeezed reservoir (ancilla photons), and an entanglement\u2010swapping measurement at B mediates a directional \u201cheat\u201d (excitation) flow from A to C.  \n\nStep 2: Check novelty and Pytheus\u2010compatibility:\n  1. Bell analyzer with squeezing: Explored analyzers exist (Yeo\u2013Chua, Mean King) but none use a squeezed ancilla to lift the linear\u2010optics Bell\u2010limit. Pytheus can optimize probabilistic pair sources + beam splitters + detectors.  \n  2. SWAP\u2010engine: Pytheus has designed CNOT/Toffoli but not a heralded SWAP gate or multi\u2010stroke engine. No dynamic feedback needed, just post\u2010selection.  \n  3. Three\u2010node heat\u2010valve: Novel in combining swapping with thermodynamic directionality; Pytheus can optimize multi\u2010pair networks and detectors\u2014but more speculative to map \u201cheat flow.\u201d  \n\nStep 3: Pick the squeezed\u2010reservoir\u2013assisted Bell\u2010state analyzer as it is the most concrete, novel, and directly feasible in Pytheus (no cavities, no dynamic feedback, only linear optics + ancilla pairs + detectors).  \n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no previous Pytheus experiment uses a nonclassical reservoir\u2014here modeled by two\u2010mode squeezing\u2014to overcome the 50\u2009% success bound of linear\u2010optics Bell measurements, directly linking a thermodynamic resource (squeezed bath) to quantum\u2010network performance.  \n\nStep 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because it uses only probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources (to model both the resource entanglement and the squeezed reservoir), linear\u2010optical elements, single\u2010photon detectors, and post\u2010selection. There is no forbidden state\u2010generation demand\u2014the goal is a measurement network (Bell analyzer) enhanced by an ancilla resource.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input: \nDescription:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir\u2013assisted Bell-state analyzer\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to design a four-mode Bell measurement on two unknown photonic qubits (modes 0 and 1) that, in standard linear optics, succeeds only 50\u2009% of the time. By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 2\u20133), realized abstractly by two probabilistic photon-pair sources, and then routing all four photons through a linear-optics interferometer plus post-selected detection, we aim to unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states on modes 0\u20131. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2. The Expert can use Pytheus to optimize the linear\u2010optics network and ancilla connections to realize this squeezed-reservoir\u2010assisted Bell measurement."

{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir\u2013assisted Bell-state analyzer\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to design a four-mode Bell measurement on two unknown photonic qubits (modes 0 and 1) that, in standard linear optics, succeeds only 50\u2009% of the time. By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 2\u20133), realized abstractly by two probabilistic photon-pair sources, and then routing all four photons through a linear-optics interferometer plus post-selected detection, we aim to unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states on modes 0\u20131. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2. The Expert can use Pytheus to optimize the linear\u2010optics network and ancilla connections to realize this squeezed-reservoir\u2010assisted Bell measurement.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The goal\u2014to surpass the 50 % Bell\u2010measurement limit using a two\u2010mode squeezed ancilla\u2014is already realized in the literature (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock, PRL 110, 260501 (2013) and follow\u2010ups using squeezers to boost linear\u2010optics Bell analyses). As stated, this is essentially the known approach of injecting squeezed\u2010vacuum resources to raise success probabilities beyond the passive\u2010optics bound. There is no new twist beyond what has already been proposed and even experimentally explored.    \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your \u201csqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013assisted\u201d Bell analyser replicates published schemes that use two\u2010mode squeezers to exceed the 50 % linear\u2010optics limit (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL 110, 260501 (2013)). To be novel at the PRL level you must introduce a genuinely new mechanism or measurement target\u2014not just repackage existing squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell analyzers under a thermodynamic narrative."
}

    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Barren plateaus induced by the dimension of qudits\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Experimental generation and characterization of partially spatially\n  coherent qubits\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Nonlocal correlations in an asymmetric quantum network\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. YOU HAVE FAILED SO OFTEN BEFORE, FREAKING TAKE IT SERIOUS!\n\nSTART OF FEEDBACK RECORD\n<existing_feedback>\nEND OF FEEDBACK RECORD\n\nThis feedback is extremely important and very valuable information. It should be taken very seriously. Take it into account when coming up with your own idea. TAKE IT SERIOUS, THE FEEDBACK IS VERY IMPORTANT!!!!! BEFORE CREATING AN IDEA, THINK ABOUT WHETHER MY PREVIOUS FEEDBACK WOULD ALLOW IT!!!\n\nBe constructively critical of your own idea and check if it is novel. Refine it and aim for producing a truly novel idea.\n\nHere are the targets that pytheus has already designed quantum optics experiments for.  A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 2\u20133), realized abstractly by two probabilistic photon-pair sources, and then routing all four photons through a linear-optics interferometer plus post-selected detection, we aim to unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states on modes 0\u20131. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2. which are pure state generation:\n  1) A squeezed-reservoir\u2013driven Bell-measurement network: use a two-mode squeezed ancilla to boost the success probability of unambiguous four-Bell-state discrimination on two qubits.  \n  2) A two-stroke teleportation engine: teleport an unknown qubit twice in series (A\u2192B\u2192C), injecting squeezed-reservoir ancillas at each Bell measurement, to study the trade-off between squeezing \u201cwork\u201d and teleportation fidelity over a network.  \n  3) A heralded SWAP gate fueled by a squeezed reservoir: implement a two-qubit SWAP (|ab\u27e9\u2192|ba\u27e9) via a linear-optics network, using a two-mode squeezed ancilla as a nonclassical reservoir to beat the vacuum-ancilla success bound.\n\nStep 2: Check novelty and feasibility:\n  1) Squeezed-assisted Bell analyzers already appear in the literature (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL 110).  \n  2) Multi-stage teleportation with squeezing-powered fidelity is conceptually neat, but Pytheus cannot optimize cascaded channel metrics directly.  \n  3) A heralded SWAP gate has not been realized in Pytheus (they have CNOT and Toffoli), and using a squeezed pair as reservoir ancilla to boost SWAP success is a fresh combination of thermodynamic resource theory and quantum-network transformations.\n\nStep 3: Select idea #3.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus experiment targets a heralded SWAP gate\u2014and none uses a squeezed-vacuum ancilla interpreted as a thermodynamic resource\u2014to experimentally probe how nonclassical \u201cwork\u201d reservoirs enable higher-success optical gate operations.\n\nStep 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and meets all constraints because it uses only single-photon emitters for the two qubit inputs, two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources to model the squeezed reservoir, a linear-optics interferometer, and photon\u2010number-resolving detectors with post\u2010selection. There is no pure state preparation demand and no dynamic feedback control required.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nDescription:  \nHeralded two-qubit SWAP gate powered by a squeezed reservoir  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe aim to design a linear-optics network that implements the SWAP operation on two unknown photonic qubits (modes A and B) in a heralded fashion, using a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla (modes C and D) as a nonclassical thermodynamic resource (\u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d). By mixing all four modes in a network of beam splitters and phase shifters and then performing photon-number-resolving detection on the ancilla outputs, we herald events in which the remaining two output modes carry the swapped qubit state |a\u27e9_A\u2009|b\u27e9_B \u2192 |b\u27e9_A\u2009|a\u27e9_B. The squeezing in modes C\u2013D supplies the \u201cwork\u201d needed to exceed the highest success probability possible with vacuum ancillas alone.\n\nVisualization:\n\n emitters: [A: mode 0] [B: mode 1]  \n ancilla pair-sources: [C\u2192mode 2, D\u2192mode 3] (two-mode squeezed)  \n    \u2193  \n linear-optics network (beam splitters + phase shifters)  \n    \u2193  \n detectors: [anc. det. 4][anc. det. 5] | [output A\u2032: det 0][output B\u2032: det 1]  \n\nConfiguration sketch for Pytheus optimization:  \n{  \n  \"description\": \"Heralded two-qubit SWAP gate assisted by a squeezed reservoir\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"SqueezedRes_SWAP\",  \n  \"edges_tried\": 40,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 2,                           # two ancilla detectors  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],              # input qubits at modes 0,1  \n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]],  \n  \"number_resolving\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 20,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [                     # SWAP truth-table events  \n    \"000011\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"010100\",  # |01>\u2192|10>  \n    \"101000\",  # |10>\u2192|01>  \n    \"111101\"   # |11>\u2192|11>  \n  ],  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\"  \n}  \n\nThe Expert can hand off this target to Pytheus to find a minimal linear-optics network that realizes a squeezed-reservoir\u2013boosted SWAP gate."

Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir\u2013assisted Bell-state analyzer\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to design a four-mode Bell measurement on two unknown photonic qubits (modes 0 and 1) that, in standard linear optics, succeeds only 50\u2009% of the time. By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 2\u20133), realized abstractly by two probabilistic photon-pair sources, and then routing all four photons through a linear-optics interferometer plus post-selected detection, we aim to unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states on modes 0\u20131. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2. The Expert can use Pytheus to optimize the linear\u2010optics network and ancilla connections to realize this squeezed-reservoir\u2010assisted Bell measurement.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The goal\u2014to surpass the 50 % Bell\u2010measurement limit using a two\u2010mode squeezed ancilla\u2014is already realized in the literature (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock, PRL 110, 260501 (2013) and follow\u2010ups using squeezers to boost linear\u2010optics Bell analyses). As stated, this is essentially the known approach of injecting squeezed\u2010vacuum resources to raise success probabilities beyond the passive\u2010optics bound. There is no new twist beyond what has already been proposed and even experimentally explored.    \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your \u201csqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013assisted\u201d Bell analyser replicates published schemes that use two\u2010mode squeezers to exceed the 50 % linear\u2010optics limit (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL 110, 260501 (2013)). To be novel at the PRL level you must introduce a genuinely new mechanism or measurement target\u2014not just repackage existing squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell analyzers under a thermodynamic narrative.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:  \nHeralded two-qubit SWAP gate powered by a squeezed reservoir  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe aim to design a linear-optics network that implements the SWAP operation on two unknown photonic qubits (modes A and B) in a heralded fashion, using a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla (modes C and D) as a nonclassical thermodynamic resource (\u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d). By mixing all four modes in a network of beam splitters and phase shifters and then performing photon-number-resolving detection on the ancilla outputs, we herald events in which the remaining two output modes carry the swapped qubit state |a\u27e9_A\u2009|b\u27e9_B \u2192 |b\u27e9_A\u2009|a\u27e9_B. The squeezing in modes C\u2013D supplies the \u201cwork\u201d needed to exceed the highest success probability possible with vacuum ancillas alone.\n\nVisualization:\n\n emitters: [A: mode 0] [B: mode 1]  \n ancilla pair-sources: [C\u2192mode 2, D\u2192mode 3] (two-mode squeezed)  \n    \u2193  \n linear-optics network (beam splitters + phase shifters)  \n    \u2193  \n detectors: [anc. det. 4][anc. det. 5] | [output A\u2032: det 0][output B\u2032: det 1]  \n\nConfiguration sketch for Pytheus optimization:  \n{  \n  \"description\": \"Heralded two-qubit SWAP gate assisted by a squeezed reservoir\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"SqueezedRes_SWAP\",  \n  \"edges_tried\": 40,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 2,                           # two ancilla detectors  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],              # input qubits at modes 0,1  \n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]],  \n  \"number_resolving\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 20,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [                     # SWAP truth-table events  \n    \"000011\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"010100\",  # |01>\u2192|10>  \n    \"101000\",  # |10>\u2192|01>  \n    \"111101\"   # |11>\u2192|11>  \n  ],  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\"  \n}  \n\nThe Expert can hand off this target to Pytheus to find a minimal linear-optics network that realizes a squeezed-reservoir\u2013boosted SWAP gate.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The proposal of a squeezed\u2010reservoir\u2013assisted SWAP gate is essentially the same trick already explored for Bell measurements and CNOT/Toffoli improvements: you inject squeezed\u2010vacuum ancillas into a linear\u2010optics network to boost heralded success rates. This is a straightforward extension of Zaidi & van Loock\u2013type schemes (and follow\u2010ups) and adds no new mechanism beyond repackaging the known squeezed\u2010ancilla approach for an obvious gate. A PRL\u2010level target requires a genuinely new transformation or resource usage, not just swapping the Bell\u2010analyzer for a SWAP.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This \u201csqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013powered SWAP\u201d is a trivial extension of existing squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell and CNOT analyzers (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL 110, 260501 and related works). To be novel, you must introduce a fundamentally new measurement primitive, nonclassical resource, or gate that the community hasn\u2019t already achieved with squeezed vacua and linear optics."

    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Barren plateaus induced by the dimension of qudits\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Experimental generation and characterization of partially spatially\n  coherent qubits\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Nonlocal correlations in an asymmetric quantum network\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. THE FEEDBACK IS INCREDIBLE IMPORTANT !!! FOR SURE LOOK AT THEM AND UNDERSTAND THE CORE IDEA OF THEM!! YOU HAVE FAILED SO OFTEN BEFORE, FREAKING TAKE IT SERIOUS!\n\nSTART OF FEEDBACK RECORD\n<existing_feedback>\nEND OF FEEDBACK RECORD\n\nThis feedback is extremely important and very valuable information. It should be taken very seriously. Take it into account when coming up with your own idea. TAKE IT SERIOUS, THE FEEDBACK IS VERY IMPORTANT!!!!! BEFORE CREATING AN IDEA, THINK ABOUT WHETHER MY PREVIOUS FEEDBACK WOULD ALLOW IT!!!\n\nBe constructively critical of your own idea and check if it is novel. Refine it and aim for producing a truly novel idea.\n\nHere are the targets that pytheus has already designed quantum optics experiments for.  A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"quantum thermodynamics\" and \"squeezed reservoir\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 2\u20133), realized abstractly by two probabilistic photon-pair sources, and then routing all four photons through a linear-optics interferometer plus post-selected detection, we aim to unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states on modes 0\u20131. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2. By mixing all four modes in a network of beam splitters and phase shifters and then performing photon-number-resolving detection on the ancilla outputs, we herald events in which the remaining two output modes carry the swapped qubit state |a\u27e9_A\u2009|b\u27e9_B \u2192 |b\u27e9_A\u2009|a\u27e9_B. The squeezing in modes C\u2013D supplies the \u201cwork\u201d needed to exceed the highest success probability possible with vacuum ancillas alone.\n\nVisualization:\n\n emitters: [A: mode 0] [B: mode 1]  \n ancilla pair-sources: [C\u2192mode 2, D\u2192mode 3] (two-mode squeezed)  \n    \u2193  \n linear-optics network (beam splitters + phase shifters)  \n    \u2193  \n detectors: [anc. det. 4][anc. det. 5] | [output A\u2032: det 0][output B\u2032: det 1]  \n\nConfiguration sketch for Pytheus optimization:  \n{  \n  \"description\": \"Heralded two-qubit SWAP gate assisted by a squeezed reservoir\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"SqueezedRes_SWAP\",  \n  \"edges_tried\": 40,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 2,                           # two ancilla detectors  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],              # input qubits at modes 0,1  \n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]],  \n  \"number_resolving\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 20,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [                     # SWAP truth-table events  \n    \"000011\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"010100\",  # |01>\u2192|10>  \n    \"101000\",  # |10>\u2192|01>  \n    \"111101\"   # |11>\u2192|11>  \n  ],  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\"  \n}  \n\nThe Expert can hand off this target to Pytheus to find a minimal linear-optics network that realizes a squeezed-reservoir\u2013boosted SWAP gate.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This \u201csqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013powered SWAP\u201d is a trivial extension of existing squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell and CNOT analyzers (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL 110, 260501 and related works).     "output": "Description:\nSqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013assisted entanglement swapping between distant nodes A and C.\n\nExplanation:\nWe consider three parties A, B, and C. A\u2013B and B\u2013C share two independent probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources (modes 0\u20132 and modes 3\u20131 respectively). In addition, at B we inject a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla (modes 4\u20135) to act as a nonclassical \u201cwork\u201d reservoir. All four B-side modes (2,3,4,5) are mixed in an optimized linear-optics network, and the four outputs are measured by photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. Successful joint detection (one photon in each of the four ancilla detectors) heralds the entanglement swapping: modes 0 and 1 (held by A and C) collapse onto a two-qubit Bell state \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9. By varying the squeezing parameter of the ancilla, one studies how the thermodynamic resource (squeezed reservoir) enhances swapping success and fidelity. Crucially, this is a quantum network transformation (entanglement swapping), not a pure state generation.\n\nVisualization:\n\n  Sources:\n    \u2013 S_AB emitting to modes [0,2]\n    \u2013 S_BC emitting to modes [3,1]\n    \u2013 S_sq emitting squeezed ancilla to modes [4,5]\n  \n      0   2   3   1   4   5   \u2190 input modes\n       \\ /     \\ /     \\ /\n        \\       |       /\n         \\   linear-optics  /\n          \u2192 [beam splitters + phases] \u2192\n        /          |           \\\n     det.2       det.3       det.4       det.5   \u2190 ancilla detectors\n        \\          |           /\n         \\       / \\       /\n          \u2192 modes 0 & 1 \u2192 Alice & Charlie hold entangled qubits\n\nConfiguration sketch for Pytheus:\n\n{\n  \"description\": \"Entanglement swapping between A and C powered by a squeezed reservoir at B\",\n  \"foldername\": \"SqueezeESwap\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\": 4,\n  \"single_emitters\": [],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[1,3]],  \n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5],\n  \"target_quantum\": [\n    \"001111\",   # A,C both 0; all four B-ancilla detectors click once\n    \"111111\"    # A,C both 1; all four B-ancilla detectors click once\n  ],\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\"\n}\n\nNotes:\n\u2013 Modes 0 and 1 are the output qubits for A and C.\n\u2013 Modes 2,3,4,5 are detected at B (ancilla detectors).\n\u2013 The two\u2010mode squeezed ancilla is encoded by a probabilistic pair source S_sq.\n\u2013 The removed_connections ensure no direct source connects A\u2194B or B\u2194C beyond the intended pairs.\n\u2013 Post-selection on the four ancilla clicks heralds entanglement swapping; the squeezed reservoir boosts success beyond the vacuum limit."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. There is no forbidden state\u2010generation demand\u2014the goal is a measurement network (Bell analyzer) enhanced by an ancilla resource.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input: \nDescription:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir\u2013assisted Bell-state analyzer\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to design a four-mode Bell measurement on two unknown photonic qubits (modes 0 and 1) that, in standard linear optics, succeeds only 50\u2009% of the time. By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 2\u20133), realized abstractly by two probabilistic photon-pair sources, and then routing all four photons through a linear-optics interferometer plus post-selected detection, we aim to unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states on modes 0\u20131. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2. The Expert can use Pytheus to optimize the linear\u2010optics network and ancilla connections to realize this squeezed-reservoir\u2010assisted Bell measurement.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your \u201csqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013assisted\u201d Bell analyser replicates published schemes that use two\u2010mode squeezers to exceed the 50 % linear\u2010optics limit (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL 110, 260501 (2013)). To be novel at the PRL level you must introduce a genuinely new mechanism or measurement target\u2014not just repackage existing squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell analyzers under a thermodynamic narrative.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! two-mode squeezed ancilla to boost the success probability of unambiguous four-Bell-state discrimination on two qubits.  \n  2) A two-stroke teleportation engine: teleport an unknown qubit twice in series (A\u2192B\u2192C), injecting squeezed-reservoir ancillas at each Bell measurement, to study the trade-off between squeezing \u201cwork\u201d and teleportation fidelity over a network.  \n  3) A heralded SWAP gate fueled by a squeezed reservoir: implement a two-qubit SWAP (|ab\u27e9\u2192|ba\u27e9) via a linear-optics network, using a two-mode squeezed ancilla as a nonclassical reservoir to beat the vacuum-ancilla success bound.\n\nStep 2: Check novelty and feasibility:\n  1) Squeezed-assisted Bell analyzers already appear in the literature (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL 110).  \n  2) Pytheus (they have CNOT and Toffoli), and using a squeezed pair as reservoir ancilla to boost SWAP success is a fresh combination of thermodynamic resource theory and quantum-network interferometer, and photon\u2010number-resolving detectors with post\u2010selection. There is no pure state preparation demand and no dynamic feedback control required.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nDescription:  \nHeralded two-qubit SWAP gate powered by a squeezed reservoir  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe aim to design a linear-optics network that implements the SWAP operation on two unknown photonic qubits (modes A and B) in a heralded fashion, using a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla (modes C and D) as a nonclassical thermodynamic resource (\u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d). By mixing all four modes in a network of beam splitters and phase shifters and then performing photon-number-resolving detection on the ancilla outputs, we herald events in which the remaining two output modes carry the swapped qubit state |a\u27e9_A\u2009|b\u27e9_B \u2192 |b\u27e9_A\u2009|a\u27e9_B. The squeezing in modes C\u2013D supplies the \u201cwork\u201d needed to exceed the highest success probability possible with vacuum ancillas alone.\n\nVisualization:\n\n emitters: [A: mode 0] [B: mode 1]  \n ancilla pair-sources: [C\u2192mode 2, D\u2192mode 3] (two-mode squeezed)  \n    \u2193  \n linear-optics network (beam splitters + phase shifters)  \n    \u2193  \n detectors: [anc. det. 4][anc. det. 5] | [output A\u2032: det 0][output B\u2032: det 1]  \n\nConfiguration sketch for Pytheus optimization:  \n{  \n  \"description\": \"Heralded two-qubit SWAP gate assisted by a squeezed reservoir\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"SqueezedRes_SWAP\",  \n  \"edges_tried\": 40,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 2,                           # two ancilla detectors  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],              # input qubits at modes 0,1  \n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]],  \n  \"number_resolving\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 20,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [                     # SWAP truth-table events  \n    \"000011\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"010100\",  # |01>\u2192|10>  \n    \"101000\",  # |10>\u2192|01>  \n    \"111101\"   # |11>\u2192|11>  \n  ],  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\"  \n}  \n\nThe Expert can hand off this target to Pytheus to find a minimal linear-optics network that realizes a squeezed-reservoir\u2013boosted SWAP gate.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This \u201csqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013powered SWAP\u201d is a trivial extension of existing squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell and CNOT analyzers (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL 110, 260501 and related works).     "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine \u201cquantum thermodynamics\u201d and a \u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d in a purely linear-optical, Pytheus-compatible quantum-network task (no state generation):\n  1) A squeezed-reservoir-assisted Bell analyzer (tried, known in the literature).\n  2) A squeezed-powered two-stage teleportation line (teleport A\u2192B\u2192C with reservoir ancillas), but Pytheus can\u2019t handle cascaded channel metrics or feed-forward.\n  3) A squeezed-reservoir-assisted entanglement-percolation network: Use a two-mode squeezed ancilla at the central link of a four-node chain to boost the success of entanglement swapping between the end nodes.  \n\nStep 2: Check novelty & feasibility:\n  \u2013 (1) is well known (Zaidi\u2009&\u2009van Loock PRL 110).\n  \u2013 (2) is conceptually nice but Pytheus can\u2019t optimize sequential fidelity measures.\n  \u2013 (3) hasn\u2019t been done: we take the standard four-node percolation/entanglement- swapping network (A\u2013B and C\u2013D each share Bell pairs, B\u2013C perform swapping) and inject a squeezed reservoir at B\u2013C to raise swapping success and reduce ancilla cost.  \n  Pytheus can optimize: probabilistic pair sources (for AB, CD, and the squeezed ancilla BC), linear-optics interferometer, and post-selected photon-number-resolving detection.  \n\nStep 3: Select idea (3).\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because it combines quantum-thermo resources (a squeezed bath modeled by a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla) with the percolation/swapping paradigm in a multi-node network, showing that squeezing can catalyze long-distance entanglement with fewer resources. No previous Pytheus-designed experiment injects a squeezed reservoir into an entanglement-percolation network.\n\nStep 5: This is feasible in Pytheus: it uses only probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources (AB, CD, and BC-squeezed ancilla), a linear-optics circuit, and post-selected detectors. There is no forbidden state generation or dynamic feedback; the goal is a measurement network (the percolation swap), enhanced by a squeezed-reservoir ancilla.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir-assisted entanglement percolation in a four-node chain\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe consider four parties A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D in a line.  \n  \u2022 A\u2013B share an unknown Bell pair (modes 0\u20131).  \n  \u2022 C\u2013D share an unknown Bell pair (modes 2\u20133).  \n  \u2022 B\u2013C additionally share a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 4\u20135), modeling a \u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d in thermodynamic language.  \n\nGoal: By mixing all six modes in a linear-optics interferometer and post-selecting on two ancilla detectors at the B\u2013C squeezed outputs, realize an entanglement-swapping measurement that nonlocally entangles A and D with success probability exceeding what vacuum ancillas allow.  \n\nVisualization:\n\n emitters / pair sources:\n   \u2013 Source AB \u2192 modes 0,1  \n   \u2013 Source CD \u2192 modes 2,3  \n   \u2013 Source BC_squeeze \u2192 modes 4,5  \n       \u2193  \n interferometer: beam splitters & phase shifters mix modes 0\u20135  \n       \u2193  \n detectors:\n   \u2013 Out A\u2032: detector 0  \n   \u2013 Out D\u2032: detector 1  \n   \u2013 Ancilla B_s: detector 2  \n   \u2013 Ancilla C_s: detector 3  \n   \u2013 (if number_resolving \u2192 detectors 4,5 record photons from modes 4,5)  \n\nSuccess herald: exactly one photon in each ancilla detector (2,3,4,5) and one photon at detectors 0 and 1. Conditioned on that pattern, A\u2032\u2013D\u2032 share a Bell pair.  \n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-assisted percolation entanglement swapping in A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D chain\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_perc_4node\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\": 4,                        # detectors for the squeezed reservoir outputs\n  \"samples\": 10,\n  \"single_emitters\": [],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]],  # no direct AB\u2013CD cross\u2010pair sources\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_quantum\": [\n    # six-mode detection patterns heralding a successful swap:\n    # out modes 0,1 have 1 photon each, ancilla modes 2\u20135 each have 1 photon\n    \"111111\"\n  ]\n}\n\nThe Expert can hand this target to Pytheus to optimize the beam-splitter network and assign amplitudes for the three pair sources to maximize the heralded success of A\u2013D entanglement, demonstrating how a squeezed reservoir lowers resource requirements in entanglement percolation."
