    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. This yields a high-fidelity Bell pair between Alice and Bob (the explicit target) within PytHeus\u2019s static linear-optical framework, using two SPDC sources and ancilla detectors without any dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Photonic Realization of the Three-Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring-Exchange\n\nAbstract: We propose and optimize a heralded linear-optics network that implements the nontrivial cyclic-shift unitary U_cycle: |a,b,c\u27e9\u2192|b,c,a\u27e9 via entanglement swapping and Bell-measurement\u2013induced teleportation on a three-node triangular topology. A specific three-click herald pattern routes the remaining photons in the cyclic order, directly mimicking the ring-exchange term of the triangular Heisenberg spin-liquid without generating any static entangled state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid-Frequency Triangle-Network Nonlocality Test with Photonic-Resonator Joint Measurements\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a self-contained three-party triangle nonlocality experiment in which two optical and one THz probabilistic Bell-pair sources feed three nodes arranged in a loop, with node B employing a small photonic-resonator interferometer to mix optical and THz modes for heralded two-outcome joint measurements. Encoded entirely in the Pytheus framework using beam splitters, phase shifters and number-resolving detectors, the scheme allows optimization of local measurement phases to maximize violation of Fritz\u2019s triangle network Bell inequality in a mixed-frequency architecture.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Collision\u2010Mode Photonic MPO Simulation of Lindblad Open\u2010System Dynamics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract: We propose a static one\u2010dimensional photonic matrix\u2010product\u2010operator (MPO) network\u2014built from probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, tunable beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014to stroboscopically enact the small\u2010time Kraus maps E_k = e^{L\u0394t} that realize the target Lindblad generator L over total time T = N\u0394t. By heralding jump/non\u2010jump outcomes on ancilla detectors and optimizing fixed optical connections in PyTheus, this scheme approximates arbitrary Markovian (and, via memory links, non\u2010Markovian) open\u2010system dynamics without dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). By mixing modes A\u2082 and B\u2081 with ancilla photons in an optimized interferometer and employing photon-number-resolving detection, the scheme heralds successful swapping and compression of multi-level entanglement into a qubit link between the Kerr and transmon nodes without feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Cyclic Indefinite\u2010Order Entanglement\u2010Swapping Switch for the Three-State Bargmann Invariant\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static linear-optical network that path-controls a single photon to cyclically superpose three successive Bell\u2013swap orders among unknown qubits A, B, and C, recombining all nine modes in a fixed nine-port interferometer and reading out a binary \u201c+\u201d/\u201c\u2013\u201d outcome. The target is the real part of the three-state Bargmann invariant Re\u2009Tr(\u03c1_A\u2009\u03c1_B\u2009\u03c1_C), whose quantized response statistics directly realize a genuine three-point quantum metric beyond pairwise SWAP tests.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a purely measurement-based photonic quantum network protocol that targets the Zak phase of the one-dimensional Su\u2013Schrieffer\u2013Heeger (SSH) model by teleporting a qubit sequentially around a four-site periodic ring using four probabilistic Bell swaps. Conditioned on four ancilla heralding clicks, the qubit returns to its original spatial mode with a relative phase shift exactly equal to the target Zak phase of the SSH band, which is then read out by a simple two-mode interferometer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. By conditioning on heralding detector clicks, the experiment realizes interference between the \u201csend-it\u201d and \u201cteleport-it\u201d arrival modes at the receiver, demonstrating coherent superposition of two fundamentally different quantum communication channels without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ring\u2010Swapped Tri\u2010Mode Optical Interferometer for Simultaneous Estimation of Three Relative Phases\n\nAbstract: We implement a closed\u2010loop network of three SPDC two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources linked by sequential Bell swaps at a central node X, apply unknown phase shifts \u03c6A, \u03c6B, and \u03c6C at parties A, B, and C, and route the resulting modes through a PythEUS\u2010optimized 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical multiport with photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Using three probabilistic EPR sources, linear-optics routing into two Bell-measurement stations, and post-selection on the control measurement, this experiment realizes the target entanglement-switch quantum switch primitive without state-generation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 Bell Pairs\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a single-step quantum repeater node that simultaneously swaps and concentrates two non-maximally entangled SPDC links into a heralded maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between remote modes. By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 2\u20133), realized abstractly by two probabilistic photon-pair sources, and then routing all four photons through a linear-optics interferometer plus post-selected detection, we aim to unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states on modes 0\u20131. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2. As stated, this is essentially the known approach of injecting squeezed\u2010vacuum resources to raise success probabilities beyond the passive\u2010optics bound. There is no new twist beyond what has already been proposed and even experimentally explored.    \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your \u201csqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013assisted\u201d Bell analyser replicates published schemes that use two\u2010mode squeezers to exceed the 50 % linear\u2010optics limit (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL 110, 260501 (2013)). To be novel at the PRL level you must introduce a genuinely new mechanism or measurement target\u2014not just repackage existing squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell analyzers under a thermodynamic narrative.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:  \nHeralded two-qubit SWAP gate powered by a squeezed reservoir  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe aim to design a linear-optics network that implements the SWAP operation on two unknown photonic qubits (modes A and B) in a heralded fashion, using a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla (modes C and D) as a nonclassical thermodynamic resource (\u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d). By mixing all four modes in a network of beam splitters and phase shifters and then performing photon-number-resolving detection on the ancilla outputs, we herald events in which the remaining two output modes carry the swapped qubit state |a\u27e9_A\u2009|b\u27e9_B \u2192 |b\u27e9_A\u2009|a\u27e9_B. The squeezing in modes C\u2013D supplies the \u201cwork\u201d needed to exceed the highest success probability possible with vacuum ancillas alone.\n\nVisualization:\n\n emitters: [A: mode 0] [B: mode 1]  \n ancilla pair-sources: [C\u2192mode 2, D\u2192mode 3] (two-mode squeezed)  \n    \u2193  \n linear-optics network (beam splitters + phase shifters)  \n    \u2193  \n detectors: [anc. det. 4][anc. det. 5] | [output A\u2032: det 0][output B\u2032: det 1]  \n\nConfiguration sketch for Pytheus optimization:  \n{  \n  \"description\": \"Heralded two-qubit SWAP gate assisted by a squeezed reservoir\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"SqueezedRes_SWAP\",  \n  \"edges_tried\": 40,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 2,                           # two ancilla detectors  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],              # input qubits at modes 0,1  \n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]],  \n  \"number_resolving\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 20,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [                     # SWAP truth-table events  \n    \"000011\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"010100\",  # |01>\u2192|10>  \n    \"101000\",  # |10>\u2192|01>  \n    \"111101\"   # |11>\u2192|11>  \n  ],  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\"  \n}  \n\nThe Expert can hand off this target to Pytheus to find a minimal linear-optics network that realizes a squeezed-reservoir\u2013boosted SWAP gate.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal of a squeezed\u2010reservoir\u2013assisted SWAP gate is essentially the same trick already explored for Bell measurements and CNOT/Toffoli improvements: you inject squeezed\u2010vacuum ancillas into a linear\u2010optics network to boost heralded success rates.     "output": "Thought: This \u201csqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013assisted entanglement percolation\u201d is just the same recipe you\u2019ve already applied to Bell measurements and SWAP gates\u2014inject a two-mode squeezing ancilla into a passive linear-optics network to boost heralding rates. It adds no genuinely new resource or nontrivial multi-node transformation beyond standard entanglement swapping with squeezed vacua, which has been studied in various contexts (e.g. squeezed-ancilla Bell analyzers, squeezed-boosted SWAP, Zaidi & van Loock PRL 110 260501). A PRL target must introduce a qualitatively new measurement primitive, topology, or resource usage, not merely extend the same squeezing trick to a four-node chain.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To reach PRL novelty, you need a fundamentally different mechanism\u2014e.g. a non-Gaussian joint measurement that can\u2019t be emulated with Gaussian ancillas, a multi-way indefinite causal-order swap among more than two links, or a genuinely new network primitive (beyond 1\u21922 node percolation) that leverages a resource other than simple two-mode squeezing."

For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"quantum thermodynamics\" and \"squeezed reservoir\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 2\u20133), realized abstractly by two probabilistic photon-pair sources, and then routing all four photons through a linear-optics interferometer plus post-selected detection, we aim to unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states on modes 0\u20131. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine \u201cquantum thermodynamics\u201d and a \u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d in a purely linear-optical, Pytheus-compatible quantum-network task (no state generation):\n  1) A squeezed-reservoir-assisted Bell analyzer (tried, known in the literature).\n  2) A squeezed-powered two-stage teleportation line (teleport A\u2192B\u2192C with reservoir ancillas), but Pytheus can\u2019t handle cascaded channel metrics or feed-forward.\n  3) A squeezed-reservoir-assisted entanglement-percolation network: Use a two-mode squeezed ancilla at the central link of a four-node chain to boost the success of entanglement swapping between the end nodes.  \n\nStep 2: Check novelty & feasibility:\n  \u2013 (1) is well known (Zaidi\u2009&\u2009van Loock PRL 110).\n  \u2013 (2) is conceptually nice but Pytheus can\u2019t optimize sequential fidelity measures.\n  \u2013 (3) hasn\u2019t been done: we take the standard four-node percolation/entanglement- swapping network (A\u2013B and C\u2013D each share Bell pairs, B\u2013C perform swapping) and inject a squeezed reservoir at B\u2013C to raise swapping success and reduce ancilla cost.  \n  Pytheus can optimize: probabilistic pair sources (for AB, CD, and the squeezed ancilla BC), linear-optics interferometer, and post-selected photon-number-resolving detection.  \n\nStep 3: Select idea (3).\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because it combines quantum-thermo resources (a squeezed bath modeled by a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla) with the percolation/swapping paradigm in a multi-node network, showing that squeezing can catalyze long-distance entanglement with fewer resources. No previous Pytheus-designed experiment injects a squeezed reservoir into an entanglement-percolation network.\n\nStep 5: This is feasible in Pytheus: it uses only probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources (AB, CD, and BC-squeezed ancilla), a linear-optics circuit, and post-selected detectors. There is no forbidden state generation or dynamic feedback; the goal is a measurement network (the percolation swap), enhanced by a squeezed-reservoir ancilla.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir-assisted entanglement percolation in a four-node chain\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe consider four parties A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D in a line.  \n  \u2022 A\u2013B share an unknown Bell pair (modes 0\u20131).  \n  \u2022 C\u2013D share an unknown Bell pair (modes 2\u20133).  \n  \u2022 B\u2013C additionally share a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 4\u20135), modeling a \u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d in thermodynamic language.  \n\nGoal: By mixing all six modes in a linear-optics interferometer and post-selecting on two ancilla detectors at the B\u2013C squeezed outputs, realize an entanglement-swapping measurement that nonlocally entangles A and D with success probability exceeding what vacuum ancillas allow.  \n\nVisualization:\n\n emitters / pair sources:\n   \u2013 Source AB \u2192 modes 0,1  \n   \u2013 Source CD \u2192 modes 2,3  \n   \u2013 Source BC_squeeze \u2192 modes 4,5  \n       \u2193  \n interferometer: beam splitters & phase shifters mix modes 0\u20135  \n       \u2193  \n detectors:\n   \u2013 Out A\u2032: detector 0  \n   \u2013 Out D\u2032: detector 1  \n   \u2013 Ancilla B_s: detector 2  \n   \u2013 Ancilla C_s: detector 3  \n   \u2013 (if number_resolving \u2192 detectors 4,5 record photons from modes 4,5)  \n\nSuccess herald: exactly one photon in each ancilla detector (2,3,4,5) and one photon at detectors 0 and 1. Conditioned on that pattern, A\u2032\u2013D\u2032 share a Bell pair.  \n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-assisted percolation entanglement swapping in A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D chain\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_perc_4node\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\": 4,                        # detectors for the squeezed reservoir outputs\n  \"samples\": 10,\n  \"single_emitters\": [],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]],  # no direct AB\u2013CD cross\u2010pair sources\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_quantum\": [\n    # six-mode detection patterns heralding a successful swap:\n    # out modes 0,1 have 1 photon each, ancilla modes 2\u20135 each have 1 photon\n    \"111111\"\n  ]\n}\n\nThe Expert can hand this target to Pytheus to optimize the beam-splitter network and assign amplitudes for the three pair sources to maximize the heralded success of A\u2013D entanglement, demonstrating how a squeezed reservoir lowers resource requirements in entanglement percolation.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To reach PRL novelty, you need a fundamentally different mechanism\u2014e.g. a non-Gaussian joint measurement that can\u2019t be emulated with Gaussian ancillas, a multi-way indefinite causal-order swap among more than two links, or a genuinely new network primitive (beyond 1\u21922 node percolation) that leverages a resource other than simple two-mode squeezing.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus-compatible ways to combine \u201cquantum thermodynamics\u201d and \u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d in a quantum-network task (no pure state generation):\n  1) Squeezed-ancilla Bell analyser (well known, Zaidi & van Loock PRL 110).\n  2) Two-stage teleportation line boosted by squeezing (requires sequential channel metrics, hard for Pytheus).\n  3) Squeezed-reservoir-assisted entanglement percolation in a four-node chain using swapping.\n\nStep 2: Check novelty & Pytheus barriers:\n  \u2022 (1) already in literature.\n  \u2022 (2) Pytheus cannot optimize cascaded fidelities or dynamic feed-forward.\n  \u2022 (3) No prior Pytheus experiment injects a squeezed ancilla into a multi-link swapping/percolation network. It uses only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, and post-selection.\n\nStep 3: Pick idea (3): \u201cSqueezed-reservoir-assisted entanglement percolation.\u201d\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because it merges a nonclassical thermodynamic resource (two-mode squeezed vacuum) into a four-node entanglement-swapping (percolation) network, showing how squeezing catalyzes long-distance entanglement with fewer resources.\n\nStep 5: It is feasible in Pytheus\u2014uses only probabilistic photon-pair sources for AB, CD and the squeezed ancilla BC, a linear-optics interferometer, photon-number-resolving detectors, and post-selection. No forbidden state preparation or dynamic feedback.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nSqueezed-reservoir-assisted entanglement percolation in a four-node chain\n\nExplanation:\nFour parties A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D are arranged linearly.  \n \u2022 A\u2013B share an unknown Bell pair (modes 0\u20131).  \n \u2022 C\u2013D share an unknown Bell pair (modes 2\u20133).  \n \u2022 B\u2013C share a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 4\u20135), modeling a \u201csqueezed reservoir.\u201d\n\nWe mix all six modes in a linear-optics network (beam splitters + phase shifters) and post-select on detections of exactly one photon in each of the four ancilla detectors (modes 2\u20135). Conditioned on that pattern, modes 0 and 1 collapse into an entangled Bell pair between A and D, achieving entanglement percolation (swapping) with success probability beyond the vacuum-ancilla bound. This demonstrates how a squeezed reservoir enhances network performance and reduces ancillary cost.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n   \u2013 AB Bell source \u2192 modes 0,1  \n   \u2013 CD Bell source \u2192 modes 2,3  \n   \u2013 BC squeezed-vacuum source \u2192 modes 4,5  \n \u2022 Interferometer:\n   \u2013 Beam splitters & phase shifters mixing modes 0\u20135  \n \u2022 Detectors:\n   \u2013 Out A\u2032: det 0  \n   \u2013 Out D\u2032: det 1  \n   \u2013 Ancilla detectors: dets 2\u20135  \n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-assisted percolation entanglement swapping in A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D chain\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_perc_4node\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\": 4,\n  \"samples\": 10,\n  \"single_emitters\": [],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"111111\"]\n}"

{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. This yields a high-fidelity Bell pair between Alice and Bob (the explicit target) within PytHeus\u2019s static linear-optical framework, using two SPDC sources and ancilla detectors without any dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Photonic Realization of the Three-Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring-Exchange\n\nAbstract: We propose and optimize a heralded linear-optics network that implements the nontrivial cyclic-shift unitary U_cycle: |a,b,c\u27e9\u2192|b,c,a\u27e9 via entanglement swapping and Bell-measurement\u2013induced teleportation on a three-node triangular topology. A specific three-click herald pattern routes the remaining photons in the cyclic order, directly mimicking the ring-exchange term of the triangular Heisenberg spin-liquid without generating any static entangled state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid-Frequency Triangle-Network Nonlocality Test with Photonic-Resonator Joint Measurements\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a self-contained three-party triangle nonlocality experiment in which two optical and one THz probabilistic Bell-pair sources feed three nodes arranged in a loop, with node B employing a small photonic-resonator interferometer to mix optical and THz modes for heralded two-outcome joint measurements. Encoded entirely in the Pytheus framework using beam splitters, phase shifters and number-resolving detectors, the scheme allows optimization of local measurement phases to maximize violation of Fritz\u2019s triangle network Bell inequality in a mixed-frequency architecture.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Collision\u2010Mode Photonic MPO Simulation of Lindblad Open\u2010System Dynamics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract: We propose a static one\u2010dimensional photonic matrix\u2010product\u2010operator (MPO) network\u2014built from probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, tunable beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014to stroboscopically enact the small\u2010time Kraus maps E_k = e^{L\u0394t} that realize the target Lindblad generator L over total time T = N\u0394t. By heralding jump/non\u2010jump outcomes on ancilla detectors and optimizing fixed optical connections in PyTheus, this scheme approximates arbitrary Markovian (and, via memory links, non\u2010Markovian) open\u2010system dynamics without dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). By mixing modes A\u2082 and B\u2081 with ancilla photons in an optimized interferometer and employing photon-number-resolving detection, the scheme heralds successful swapping and compression of multi-level entanglement into a qubit link between the Kerr and transmon nodes without feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Cyclic Indefinite\u2010Order Entanglement\u2010Swapping Switch for the Three-State Bargmann Invariant\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static linear-optical network that path-controls a single photon to cyclically superpose three successive Bell\u2013swap orders among unknown qubits A, B, and C, recombining all nine modes in a fixed nine-port interferometer and reading out a binary \u201c+\u201d/\u201c\u2013\u201d outcome. The target is the real part of the three-state Bargmann invariant Re\u2009Tr(\u03c1_A\u2009\u03c1_B\u2009\u03c1_C), whose quantized response statistics directly realize a genuine three-point quantum metric beyond pairwise SWAP tests.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a purely measurement-based photonic quantum network protocol that targets the Zak phase of the one-dimensional Su\u2013Schrieffer\u2013Heeger (SSH) model by teleporting a qubit sequentially around a four-site periodic ring using four probabilistic Bell swaps. Conditioned on four ancilla heralding clicks, the qubit returns to its original spatial mode with a relative phase shift exactly equal to the target Zak phase of the SSH band, which is then read out by a simple two-mode interferometer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. By conditioning on heralding detector clicks, the experiment realizes interference between the \u201csend-it\u201d and \u201cteleport-it\u201d arrival modes at the receiver, demonstrating coherent superposition of two fundamentally different quantum communication channels without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ring\u2010Swapped Tri\u2010Mode Optical Interferometer for Simultaneous Estimation of Three Relative Phases\n\nAbstract: We implement a closed\u2010loop network of three SPDC two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources linked by sequential Bell swaps at a central node X, apply unknown phase shifts \u03c6A, \u03c6B, and \u03c6C at parties A, B, and C, and route the resulting modes through a PythEUS\u2010optimized 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical multiport with photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 Bell Pairs\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a single-step quantum repeater node that simultaneously swaps and concentrates two non-maximally entangled SPDC links into a heralded maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between remote modes. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nPT-Symmetric Gain\u2013Loss Filter\u2013Enhanced Teleportation for High-Fidelity Remote CNOT\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe demonstrate a heralded, non-unitary PT-symmetric gain\u2013loss filter embedded in the Bell-state measurement of a teleportation-based CNOT between photonic qubit A (control) and qubit C (target). By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. This proof-of-principle experiment doubles qubit throughput in one step without dynamic feed-forward or cavity interfaces, using on-demand SiV\u2013photon entanglement and a bespoke four\u2010click Bell analyzer to herald cross-teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Coherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a generalized three-photon entanglement-swapping protocol\u2014targeting \u201cCoherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\u201d\u2014in which two probabilistic Bell-pair sources and an auxiliary single-photon coherence qubit each traverse independent amplitude-damping channels. A three-mode linear-optics interferometer with photon-number-resolving heralding converts the residual local coherence into nonlocal entanglement between distant output photons A and D, outperforming conventional two-link swapping in the presence of loss.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Quantum SWITCH Superactivates Entanglement via Indefinite Causal Order\n\nMini-abstract: We implement the target measurement-induced photonic quantum SWITCH of two entanglement-breaking dephasing channels using ancilla photons, passive linear optics, and post-selection to emulate a discrete cross-Kerr coupling between a control and two data paths. Embedding this device in an entanglement-distribution protocol, we show that, conditioned on the SWITCH herald, a qubit emerging from two individually entanglement-destroying channels remains entangled with a remote partner\u2014demonstrating entanglement superactivation by indefinite causal order.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: PT-Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non-Hermitian Bell-State Projection\n\nAbstract: We implement entanglement swapping on two polarization-encoded Bell pairs using a central PT-symmetric, non-unitary Bell-state analyser. By heralding the projector onto the PT-modified Bell state (the target map) and tuning its gain/loss parameter \u03b3, the protocol controllably generates a two-photon output |\u03a8_AD\u27e9\u221d|HH\u27e9+\u03b3\u2009e^{i\u03d5}|VV\u27e9 with adjustable, non-maximal entanglement.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a single-shot four-body stabilizer readout for the smallest toric-code plaquette by Bell-entangling each of four data photons with an ancilla photon and sending all ancilla modes through a 4\u00d74 passive interferometer equipped with number-resolving detectors. Heralded two-photon click patterns in even or odd detector pairs directly project the data qubits onto the \u00b11 eigenstates of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084, realizing a direct stabilizer measurement without any feed-forward or dynamic control.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 2\u20133), realized abstractly by two probabilistic photon-pair sources, and then routing all four photons through a linear-optics interferometer plus post-selected detection, we aim to unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states on modes 0\u20131. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2. To be novel at the PRL level you must introduce a genuinely new mechanism or measurement target\u2014not just repackage existing squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell analyzers under a thermodynamic narrative.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:  \nHeralded two-qubit SWAP gate powered by a squeezed reservoir  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe aim to design a linear-optics network that implements the SWAP operation on two unknown photonic qubits (modes A and B) in a heralded fashion, using a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla (modes C and D) as a nonclassical thermodynamic resource (\u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d). By mixing all four modes in a network of beam splitters and phase shifters and then performing photon-number-resolving detection on the ancilla outputs, we herald events in which the remaining two output modes carry the swapped qubit state |a\u27e9_A\u2009|b\u27e9_B \u2192 |b\u27e9_A\u2009|a\u27e9_B. The squeezing in modes C\u2013D supplies the \u201cwork\u201d needed to exceed the highest success probability possible with vacuum ancillas alone.\n\nVisualization:\n\n emitters: [A: mode 0] [B: mode 1]  \n ancilla pair-sources: [C\u2192mode 2, D\u2192mode 3] (two-mode squeezed)  \n    \u2193  \n linear-optics network (beam splitters + phase shifters)  \n    \u2193  \n detectors: [anc. det. 4][anc. det. 5] | [output A\u2032: det 0][output B\u2032: det 1]  \n\nConfiguration sketch for Pytheus optimization:  \n{  \n  \"description\": \"Heralded two-qubit SWAP gate assisted by a squeezed reservoir\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"SqueezedRes_SWAP\",  \n  \"edges_tried\": 40,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 2,                           # two ancilla detectors  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],              # input qubits at modes 0,1  \n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]],  \n  \"number_resolving\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 20,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [                     # SWAP truth-table events  \n    \"000011\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"010100\",  # |01>\u2192|10>  \n    \"101000\",  # |10>\u2192|01>  \n    \"111101\"   # |11>\u2192|11>  \n  ],  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\"  \n}  \n\nThe Expert can hand off this target to Pytheus to find a minimal linear-optics network that realizes a squeezed-reservoir\u2013boosted SWAP gate.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal of a squeezed\u2010reservoir\u2013assisted SWAP gate is essentially the same trick already explored for Bell measurements and CNOT/Toffoli improvements: you inject squeezed\u2010vacuum ancillas into a linear\u2010optics network to boost heralded success rates. Conditioned on that pattern, modes 0 and 1 collapse into an entangled Bell pair between A and D, achieving entanglement percolation (swapping) with success probability beyond the vacuum-ancilla bound. This demonstrates how a squeezed reservoir enhances network performance and reduces ancillary cost.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n   \u2013 AB Bell source \u2192 modes 0,1  \n   \u2013 CD Bell source \u2192 modes 2,3  \n   \u2013 BC squeezed-vacuum source \u2192 modes 4,5  \n \u2022 Interferometer:\n   \u2013 Beam splitters & phase shifters mixing modes 0\u20135  \n \u2022 Detectors:\n   \u2013 Out A\u2032: det 0  \n   \u2013 Out D\u2032: det 1  \n   \u2013 Ancilla detectors: dets 2\u20135  \n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-assisted percolation entanglement swapping in A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D chain\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_perc_4node\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\": 4,\n  \"samples\": 10,\n  \"single_emitters\": [],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"111111\"]\n}\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",

As such, it fails to meet the bar for a genuinely novel PRL-level target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your \u201csqueezed-reservoir\u2013assisted percolation\u201d is just the same Gaussian-ancilla enhancement already explored for two-node Bell analyzers and small-node repeaters. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"quantum thermodynamics\" and \"squeezed reservoir\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 2\u20133), realized abstractly by two probabilistic photon-pair sources, and then routing all four photons through a linear-optics interferometer plus post-selected detection, we aim to unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states on modes 0\u20131. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2.     "output": "Description:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir-assisted entanglement concentration network\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a purely linear-optical measurement network that uses a minimal \u201csqueezed thermal reservoir\u201d to catalyze entanglement concentration. Two distant parties (A\u2013B, modes 0\u20131) and (C\u2013D, modes 2\u20133) each hold a copy of the same partially entangled qubit pair. At a central station we inject a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla (modes 4\u20135), which acts as the thermodynamic \u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d supplying nonclassical work. All six modes are interfered in a beam-splitter + phase-shifter network. Four of the output modes (the two ancilla outputs plus two specific Bell-measurement ports on the partially entangled inputs) are measured with photon-number-resolving detectors. A successful heralding pattern on those ancilla detectors signals that the remaining two modes (one from the A\u2013B pair and one from the C\u2013D pair) collapse into a near\u2013maximally entangled Bell state. By comparing to the same network without squeezing, one directly measures the thermodynamic advantage (in resource consumption vs. success probability) provided by the squeezed reservoir.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters/pair sources:\n   \u2022 Partially entangled source AB \u2192 modes 0,1  \n   \u2022 Partially entangled source CD \u2192 modes 2,3  \n   \u2022 Squeezed-vacuum source \u2192 modes 4,5  \n\n     \u2193  \n interferometer (BS + PS) mixing modes 0\u20135  \n\n     \u2193  \n detectors:\n   \u2022 Bell-measurement ports: D0, D1  \n   \u2022 Reservoir outputs: D2, D3  \n   \u2022 Heralding triggers on \u201c1 photon in each of D0\u2013D3\u201d  \n   \u2022 Remaining modes (A\u2032, D\u2032) carry the concentrated Bell pair  \n\nKey Pytheus config sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Entanglement concentration assisted by a squeezed reservoir\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_conc_6m\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\": 4,                       # detectors D0\u2013D3 used for heralding\n  \"single_emitters\": [],  \n  \"removed_connections\": [            # forbid direct cross-pair sources\n    [0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"target_measurement\": {\n    # heralding patterns: exactly one photon in each ancilla detector D0\u2013D3,\n    # leaving two photons in the output modes A\u2032 (mode X) and D\u2032 (mode Y)\n  }\n}\n\nWhy this is novel:\n\u2022 No prior Pytheus experiment injects a squeezed reservoir into an entanglement-concentration analyzer.  \n\u2022 It connects quantum thermodynamics (nonclassical work from squeezing) with a foundational quantum-network primitive (entanglement concentration) in a way that can be generalized to more copies or higher dimensions.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s feasible:\n\u2022 Uses only probabilistic photon-pair sources (for the two input pairs and the squeezed ancilla), beam splitters + phase shifters, and photon-number-resolving detectors with post-selection.  \n\u2022 Does not require dynamic feedback or cavities/resonances\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities."

In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2.
