    "output": "Description:\n\u201cSqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013assisted GHZ\u2010fusion measurement\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a new entanglement\u2010fusion network that converts two independent Bell pairs into a three\u2010party GHZ state, using a two\u2010mode squeezed\u2013vacuum ancilla as a thermodynamic \u201cwork\u201d reservoir to boost the fusion success probability beyond what vacuum ancillas allow.\n\n  \u2022 Parties A\u2013B share an unknown Bell pair on modes 0\u20131.  \n  \u2022 Parties C\u2013D share an unknown Bell pair on modes 2\u20133.  \n  \u2022 A two\u2010mode squeezed\u2013vacuum ancilla (the \u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d) feeds modes 4\u20135 via a probabilistic pair source.  \n\nAt nodes B and C we mix their Bell\u2010pair photons (modes 1,2) together with the two squeezed\u2010ancilla modes (4,5) in a linear\u2010optics interferometer (beam splitters + phase shifts), then perform photon\u2010number\u2013resolving measurements on those four modes. Conditioned on detecting one photon in each of the four ancilla detectors, the unmeasured output modes 0 (A), 3 (D), and one leftover ancilla output collapse into a three\u2010party GHZ state  \n\u2003|000\u27e9 + |111\u27e9  \nshared between A, D, and the remaining ancilla channel\u2014heralding a successful GHZ\u2010fusion event.\n\nWhy it\u2019s novel:\n  \u2013 Pytheus has generated Bell\u2010swapping and small\u2010dimensional analyzers, but no experiment has yet used a squeezed reservoir to catalyze multipartite entanglement fusion into a GHZ basis measurement.  \n  \u2013 This protocol casts a thermodynamic resource (squeezing) in the role of \u201cwork\u201d that reduces the ancilla overhead and raises fusion success above the Gaussian\u2010ancilla vacuum bound.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s feasible in Pytheus:\n  \u2013 All sources (two Bell\u2010pair sources + one two\u2010mode squeezed source) are abstractly encoded as probabilistic pair emitters.  \n  \u2013 The fusion is achieved by a static linear\u2010optics network and post\u2010selected photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014no dynamic feed\u2010forward or cavities needed.  \n  \u2013 The target is a measurement network (GHZ\u2010fusion), not forbidden state\u2010generation: Pytheus optimizes the interferometer and ancilla connections to maximize the heralded projection onto the GHZ subspace.\n\nSketch of a Pytheus configuration:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed\u2010reservoir\u2010assisted GHZ fusion from two Bell pairs\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_GHZ_fusion\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\": 4,                    # detectors on modes 1,2,4,5\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"single_emitters\": [],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3],[2,4],[2,5],[3,4],[3,5]],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_quantum\": [\n    # output modes [0,3,?] (A, D, leftover ancilla) carry the GHZ basis:\n    \"000\", \"111\"\n  ]\n}\n\nThe Expert can hand off this GHZ\u2010fusion measurement target to Pytheus to find the minimal linear\u2010optics network and ancilla\u2010pair amplitudes that herald three\u2010party GHZ entanglement, thereby demonstrating how a squeezed reservoir plays the role of thermodynamic \u201cwork\u201d in quantum\u2010network transformations."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 2\u20133), realized abstractly by two probabilistic photon-pair sources, and then routing all four photons through a linear-optics interferometer plus post-selected detection, we aim to unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states on modes 0\u20131. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2. The Expert can use Pytheus to optimize the linear\u2010optics network and ancilla connections to realize this squeezed-reservoir\u2010assisted Bell measurement.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your \u201csqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013assisted\u201d Bell analyser replicates published schemes that use two\u2010mode squeezers to exceed the 50 % linear\u2010optics limit (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL 110, 260501 (2013)). (A\u2192B vs. A\u2192C) is biased by injecting squeezing at the central node.\n  3) Squeezed-reservoir\u2013assisted photonic \u201cfusion\u201d gate for cluster percolation: boost the success of Type-I/II fusion operations by consuming a two-mode squeezed ancilla as a thermodynamic resource.\n\nStep 2: Check novelty and Pytheus barriers:\n  1) Higher-dimensional squeezed Bell analyzers are little explored, but conceptually similar to known Zaidi\u2009&\u2009van Loock schemes.\n  2) Entanglement routing is intriguing but nebulous to encode as a concrete target in Pytheus.\n  3) Fusion gates appear widely in linear-optics cluster proposals, yet no one has leveraged a squeezed ancilla to exceed their success bound\u2014and Pytheus can optimize exactly that: a linear-optics fusion reservoir\u201d consumed by a photonic fusion measurement, a perspective absent from the photonic-cluster/fusion literature.\n   \u2022 It generalizes easily to larger percolation networks: each fusion link can be turbo-charged by a squeezed-reservoir ancilla.\n\nStep 5: This is feasible in Pytheus:\n   \u2022 Uses only single-photon inputs for the two qubits to be fused, two probabilistic pair sources modeling the squeezed reservoir, a linear-optics interferometer, and post-selected photon-number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n   \u2022 No dynamic feedback, no forbidden state preparation.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir\u2013assisted photonic fusion gate for cluster percolation\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to implement a linear-optics fusion operation on two unknown photonic qubits (modes 0,1)\u2014the primitive that \u201cfuses\u201d two cluster-state fragments\u2014by injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla (modes 2,3) that acts as a nonclassical thermodynamic reservoir. In standard linear optics the Type-I fusion succeeds only 50\u2009% of the time; here the squeezing supplies \u201cwork\u201d to boost the heralded success probability above that bound. All six modes are mixed in an interferometer and then measured:\n\nVisualization:\n   single_emitters: [mode 0], [mode 1]         # the two qubits to fuse  \n   squeezed_sources: pair \u2192 [mode 2, mode 3]  # two-mode squeezed ancilla  \n       \u2193  \n   linear-optics network: beam splitters & phases mixing modes 0\u20133  \n       \u2193  \n   detectors:  \n     \u2013 Out fused qubit(s): detectors 0 & 1  \n     \u2013 Ancilla detectors: detectors 2 & 3  \n\nHeralding rule:\nPost-select on specific photon-number patterns in detectors 2 & 3 (e.g. one photon each) that flag a successful fusion; the two remaining output modes realize the fused cluster edge.\n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-assisted photonic fusion gate\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_fusion_gate\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"num_anc\": 2,\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[1,3]],  # forbid direct emitter\u2192ancilla bypass\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"samples\": 10,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_quantum\": [\n    # detection patterns (ancilla modes 2,3 each have 1 photon; outputs show fused parity)\n    \"1100\",  # example: |+\u27e9 fusion outcome\n    \"0011\"   # example: |\u2212\u27e9 fusion outcome\n  ]\n}\n\nThis target invites Pytheus to find the minimal beam-splitter/phase-shift network and pair-source amplitudes that maximize heralded fusion success\u2014demonstrating how a squeezed reservoir (thermodynamic work) enhances cluster-state percolation without any forbidden state generation or feedback."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. A specific three-click herald pattern routes the remaining photons in the cyclic order, directly mimicking the ring-exchange term of the triangular Heisenberg spin-liquid without generating any static entangled state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid-Frequency Triangle-Network Nonlocality Test with Photonic-Resonator Joint Measurements\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a self-contained three-party triangle nonlocality experiment in which two optical and one THz probabilistic Bell-pair sources feed three nodes arranged in a loop, with node B employing a small photonic-resonator interferometer to mix optical and THz modes for heralded two-outcome joint measurements. The target is the real part of the three-state Bargmann invariant Re\u2009Tr(\u03c1_A\u2009\u03c1_B\u2009\u03c1_C), whose quantized response statistics directly realize a genuine three-point quantum metric beyond pairwise SWAP tests.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a purely measurement-based photonic quantum network protocol that targets the Zak phase of the one-dimensional Su\u2013Schrieffer\u2013Heeger (SSH) model by teleporting a qubit sequentially around a four-site periodic ring using four probabilistic Bell swaps. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir\u2013assisted Bell-state analyzer\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to design a four-mode Bell measurement on two unknown photonic qubits (modes 0 and 1) that, in standard linear optics, succeeds only 50\u2009% of the time. By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 2\u20133), realized abstractly by two probabilistic photon-pair sources, and then routing all four photons through a linear-optics interferometer plus post-selected detection, we aim to unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states on modes 0\u20131. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2. The Expert can use Pytheus to optimize the linear\u2010optics network and ancilla connections to realize this squeezed-reservoir\u2010assisted Bell measurement.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The goal\u2014to surpass the 50 % Bell\u2010measurement limit using a two\u2010mode squeezed ancilla\u2014is already realized in the literature (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock, PRL 110, 260501 (2013) and follow\u2010ups using squeezers to boost linear\u2010optics Bell analyses). As stated, this is essentially the known approach of injecting squeezed\u2010vacuum resources to raise success probabilities beyond the passive\u2010optics bound. There is no new twist beyond what has already been proposed and even experimentally explored.    \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your \u201csqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013assisted\u201d Bell analyser replicates published schemes that use two\u2010mode squeezers to exceed the 50 % linear\u2010optics limit (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL 110, 260501 (2013)). To be novel at the PRL level you must introduce a genuinely new mechanism or measurement target\u2014not just repackage existing squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell analyzers under a thermodynamic narrative.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:  \nHeralded two-qubit SWAP gate powered by a squeezed reservoir  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe aim to design a linear-optics network that implements the SWAP operation on two unknown photonic qubits (modes A and B) in a heralded fashion, using a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla (modes C and D) as a nonclassical thermodynamic resource (\u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d). By mixing all four modes in a network of beam splitters and phase shifters and then performing photon-number-resolving detection on the ancilla outputs, we herald events in which the remaining two output modes carry the swapped qubit state |a\u27e9_A\u2009|b\u27e9_B \u2192 |b\u27e9_A\u2009|a\u27e9_B. The squeezing in modes C\u2013D supplies the \u201cwork\u201d needed to exceed the highest success probability possible with vacuum ancillas alone.\n\nVisualization:\n\n emitters: [A: mode 0] [B: mode 1]  \n ancilla pair-sources: [C\u2192mode 2, D\u2192mode 3] (two-mode squeezed)  \n    \u2193  \n linear-optics network (beam splitters + phase shifters)  \n    \u2193  \n detectors: [anc. det. 4][anc. det. 5] | [output A\u2032: det 0][output B\u2032: det 1]  \n\nConfiguration sketch for Pytheus optimization:  \n{  \n  \"description\": \"Heralded two-qubit SWAP gate assisted by a squeezed reservoir\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"SqueezedRes_SWAP\",  \n  \"edges_tried\": 40,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 2,                           # two ancilla detectors  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],              # input qubits at modes 0,1  \n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]],  \n  \"number_resolving\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 20,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [                     # SWAP truth-table events  \n    \"000011\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"010100\",  # |01>\u2192|10>  \n    \"101000\",  # |10>\u2192|01>  \n    \"111101\"   # |11>\u2192|11>  \n  ],  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\"  \n}  \n\nThe Expert can hand off this target to Pytheus to find a minimal linear-optics network that realizes a squeezed-reservoir\u2013boosted SWAP gate.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal of a squeezed\u2010reservoir\u2013assisted SWAP gate is essentially the same trick already explored for Bell measurements and CNOT/Toffoli improvements: you inject squeezed\u2010vacuum ancillas into a linear\u2010optics network to boost heralded success rates. This is a straightforward extension of Zaidi & van Loock\u2013type schemes (and follow\u2010ups) and adds no new mechanism beyond repackaging the known squeezed\u2010ancilla approach for an obvious gate. A PRL\u2010level target requires a genuinely new transformation or resource usage, not just swapping the Bell\u2010analyzer for a SWAP.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This \u201csqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013powered SWAP\u201d is a trivial extension of existing squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell and CNOT analyzers (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL 110, 260501 and related works). To be novel, you must introduce a fundamentally new measurement primitive, nonclassical resource, or gate that the community hasn\u2019t already achieved with squeezed vacua and linear optics.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir-assisted entanglement percolation in a four-node chain\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe consider four parties A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D in a line.  \n  \u2022 A\u2013B share an unknown Bell pair (modes 0\u20131).  \n  \u2022 C\u2013D share an unknown Bell pair (modes 2\u20133).  \n  \u2022 B\u2013C additionally share a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 4\u20135), modeling a \u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d in thermodynamic language.  \n\nGoal: By mixing all six modes in a linear-optics interferometer and post-selecting on two ancilla detectors at the B\u2013C squeezed outputs, realize an entanglement-swapping measurement that nonlocally entangles A and D with success probability exceeding what vacuum ancillas allow.  \n\nVisualization:\n\n emitters / pair sources:\n   \u2013 Source AB \u2192 modes 0,1  \n   \u2013 Source CD \u2192 modes 2,3  \n   \u2013 Source BC_squeeze \u2192 modes 4,5  \n       \u2193  \n interferometer: beam splitters & phase shifters mix modes 0\u20135  \n       \u2193  \n detectors:\n   \u2013 Out A\u2032: detector 0  \n   \u2013 Out D\u2032: detector 1  \n   \u2013 Ancilla B_s: detector 2  \n   \u2013 Ancilla C_s: detector 3  \n   \u2013 (if number_resolving \u2192 detectors 4,5 record photons from modes 4,5)  \n\nSuccess herald: exactly one photon in each ancilla detector (2,3,4,5) and one photon at detectors 0 and 1. Conditioned on that pattern, A\u2032\u2013D\u2032 share a Bell pair.  \n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-assisted percolation entanglement swapping in A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D chain\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_perc_4node\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\": 4,                        # detectors for the squeezed reservoir outputs\n  \"samples\": 10,\n  \"single_emitters\": [],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]],  # no direct AB\u2013CD cross\u2010pair sources\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_quantum\": [\n    # six-mode detection patterns heralding a successful swap:\n    # out modes 0,1 have 1 photon each, ancilla modes 2\u20135 each have 1 photon\n    \"111111\"\n  ]\n}\n\nThe Expert can hand this target to Pytheus to optimize the beam-splitter network and assign amplitudes for the three pair sources to maximize the heralded success of A\u2013D entanglement, demonstrating how a squeezed reservoir lowers resource requirements in entanglement percolation.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This \u201csqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013assisted entanglement percolation\u201d is just the same recipe you\u2019ve already applied to Bell measurements and SWAP gates\u2014inject a two-mode squeezing ancilla into a passive linear-optics network to boost heralding rates. It adds no genuinely new resource or nontrivial multi-node transformation beyond standard entanglement swapping with squeezed vacua, which has been studied in various contexts (e.g. squeezed-ancilla Bell analyzers, squeezed-boosted SWAP, Zaidi & van Loock PRL 110 260501). A PRL target must introduce a qualitatively new measurement primitive, topology, or resource usage, not merely extend the same squeezing trick to a four-node chain.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To reach PRL novelty, you need a fundamentally different mechanism\u2014e.g. a non-Gaussian joint measurement that can\u2019t be emulated with Gaussian ancillas, a multi-way indefinite causal-order swap among more than two links, or a genuinely new network primitive (beyond 1\u21922 node percolation) that leverages a resource other than simple two-mode squeezing.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\nSqueezed-reservoir-assisted entanglement percolation in a four-node chain\n\nExplanation:\nFour parties A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D are arranged linearly.  \n \u2022 A\u2013B share an unknown Bell pair (modes 0\u20131).  \n \u2022 C\u2013D share an unknown Bell pair (modes 2\u20133).  \n \u2022 B\u2013C share a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 4\u20135), modeling a \u201csqueezed reservoir.\u201d\n\nWe mix all six modes in a linear-optics network (beam splitters + phase shifters) and post-select on detections of exactly one photon in each of the four ancilla detectors (modes 2\u20135). Conditioned on that pattern, modes 0 and 1 collapse into an entangled Bell pair between A and D, achieving entanglement percolation (swapping) with success probability beyond the vacuum-ancilla bound. This demonstrates how a squeezed reservoir enhances network performance and reduces ancillary cost.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n   \u2013 AB Bell source \u2192 modes 0,1  \n   \u2013 CD Bell source \u2192 modes 2,3  \n   \u2013 BC squeezed-vacuum source \u2192 modes 4,5  \n \u2022 Interferometer:\n   \u2013 Beam splitters & phase shifters mixing modes 0\u20135  \n \u2022 Detectors:\n   \u2013 Out A\u2032: det 0  \n   \u2013 Out D\u2032: det 1  \n   \u2013 Ancilla detectors: dets 2\u20135  \n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-assisted percolation entanglement swapping in A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D chain\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_perc_4node\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\": 4,\n  \"samples\": 10,\n  \"single_emitters\": [],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"111111\"]\n}\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal merely extends the well-known trick of injecting two-mode squeezed ancillas to boost heralded entanglement-swapping or Bell measurements (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock, PRL 110, 260501) to a four-node chain. No new measurement primitive, non-Gaussian resource, or fundamentally different network topology is introduced beyond the standard squeezed-vacuum enhancement. In standard linear optics the Type-I fusion succeeds only 50\u2009% of the time; here the squeezing supplies \u201cwork\u201d to boost the heralded success probability above that bound. All six modes are mixed in an interferometer and then measured:\n\nVisualization:\n   single_emitters: [mode 0], [mode 1]         # the two qubits to fuse  \n   squeezed_sources: pair \u2192 [mode 2, mode 3]  # two-mode squeezed ancilla  \n       \u2193  \n   linear-optics network: beam splitters & phases mixing modes 0\u20133  \n       \u2193  \n   detectors:  \n     \u2013 Out fused qubit(s): detectors 0 & 1  \n     \u2013 Ancilla detectors: detectors 2 & 3  \n\nHeralding rule:\nPost-select on specific photon-number patterns in detectors 2 & 3 (e.g. one photon each) that flag a successful fusion; the two remaining output modes realize the fused cluster edge.\n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-assisted photonic fusion gate\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_fusion_gate\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"num_anc\": 2,\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[1,3]],  # forbid direct emitter\u2192ancilla bypass\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"samples\": 10,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_quantum\": [\n    # detection patterns (ancilla modes 2,3 each have 1 photon; outputs show fused parity)\n    \"1100\",  # example: |+\u27e9 fusion outcome\n    \"0011\"   # example: |\u2212\u27e9 fusion outcome\n  ]\n}\n\nThis target invites Pytheus to find the minimal beam-splitter/phase-shift network and pair-source amplitudes that maximize heralded fusion success\u2014demonstrating how a squeezed reservoir (thermodynamic work) enhances cluster-state percolation without any forbidden state generation or feedback.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: This \u201csqueezed-reservoir\u2013assisted fusion gate\u201d is just the same squeezed-ancilla trick you\u2019ve already applied to Bell analyzers, SWAP gates, and entanglement percolation\u2014namely, inject a two-mode squeezed vacuum into a passive linear-optics network to raise a 50% success bound. A Type-I fusion is essentially a parity/Bell measurement on two qubits, so boosting it with Gaussian ancillas follows immediately from prior squeezed-Bell schemes (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL 110, 260501 and related work). No new non-Gaussian resource, measurement primitive, or network topology is introduced.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To reach PRL-level novelty, propose a measurement or resource that can\u2019t be reduced to passive optics plus squeezers\u2014e.g. a genuine multi-photon non-Gaussian joint projector, an indefinite-order cluster fusion network, or another qualitatively new primitive beyond Gaussian ancilla enhancement."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 2\u20133), realized abstractly by two probabilistic photon-pair sources, and then routing all four photons through a linear-optics interferometer plus post-selected detection, we aim to unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states on modes 0\u20131. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2. thermodynamics\u201d and a \u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d into a network/transformation (no forbidden state generation):\n  1) Unambiguous d-dimensional Bell measurement aided by a two-mode squeezed ancilla.\n  2) Thermodynamic entanglement router: a three-node network whose entanglement path (A\u2192B vs. A\u2192C) is biased by injecting squeezing at the central node.\n  3) Squeezed-reservoir\u2013assisted photonic \u201cfusion\u201d gate for cluster percolation: boost the success of Type-I/II fusion operations by consuming a two-mode squeezed ancilla as a thermodynamic resource.\n\nStep 2: Check novelty and Pytheus barriers:\n  1) Higher-dimensional squeezed Bell analyzers are little explored, but conceptually similar to known Zaidi\u2009&\u2009van Loock schemes.\n  2) Entanglement routing is intriguing but nebulous to encode as a concrete target in Pytheus.\n  3) Fusion gates appear widely in linear-optics cluster proposals, yet no one has leveraged a squeezed ancilla to exceed their success bound\u2014and Pytheus can optimize exactly that: a linear-optics fusion network with probabilistic pair sources and detectors.\n\nStep 3: Select idea (3).\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because:\n   \u2022 It treats a two-mode squeezed vacuum as a thermodynamic \u201cwork reservoir\u201d consumed by a photonic fusion measurement, a perspective absent from the photonic-cluster/fusion literature.\n   \u2022 It generalizes easily to larger percolation networks: each fusion link can be turbo-charged by a squeezed-reservoir ancilla.\n\nStep 5: This is feasible in Pytheus:\n   \u2022 Uses only single-photon inputs for the two qubits to be fused, two probabilistic pair sources modeling the squeezed reservoir, a linear-optics interferometer, and post-selected photon-number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n   \u2022 No dynamic feedback, no forbidden state preparation.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir\u2013assisted photonic fusion gate for cluster percolation\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to implement a linear-optics fusion operation on two unknown photonic qubits (modes 0,1)\u2014the primitive that \u201cfuses\u201d two cluster-state fragments\u2014by injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla (modes 2,3) that acts as a nonclassical thermodynamic reservoir. In standard linear optics the Type-I fusion succeeds only 50\u2009% of the time; here the squeezing supplies \u201cwork\u201d to boost the heralded success probability above that bound. All six modes are mixed in an interferometer and then measured:\n\nVisualization:\n   single_emitters: [mode 0], [mode 1]         # the two qubits to fuse  \n   squeezed_sources: pair \u2192 [mode 2, mode 3]  # two-mode squeezed ancilla  \n       \u2193  \n   linear-optics network: beam splitters & phases mixing modes 0\u20133  \n       \u2193  \n   detectors:  \n     \u2013 Out fused qubit(s): detectors 0 & 1  \n     \u2013 Ancilla detectors: detectors 2 & 3  \n\nHeralding rule:\nPost-select on specific photon-number patterns in detectors 2 & 3 (e.g. one photon each) that flag a successful fusion; the two remaining output modes realize the fused cluster edge.\n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-assisted photonic fusion gate\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_fusion_gate\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"num_anc\": 2,\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[1,3]],  # forbid direct emitter\u2192ancilla bypass\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"samples\": 10,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_quantum\": [\n    # detection patterns (ancilla modes 2,3 each have 1 photon; outputs show fused parity)\n    \"1100\",  # example: |+\u27e9 fusion outcome\n    \"0011\"   # example: |\u2212\u27e9 fusion outcome\n  ]\n}\n\nThis target invites Pytheus to find the minimal beam-splitter/phase-shift network and pair-source amplitudes that maximize heralded fusion success\u2014demonstrating how a squeezed reservoir (thermodynamic work) enhances cluster-state percolation without any forbidden state generation or feedback.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To reach PRL-level novelty, propose a measurement or resource that can\u2019t be reduced to passive optics plus squeezers\u2014e.g. a genuine multi-photon non-Gaussian joint projector, an indefinite-order cluster fusion network, or another qualitatively new primitive beyond Gaussian ancilla enhancement.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: I brainstormed three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to fuse \u201cquantum thermodynamics\u201d and a \u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d into a network transformation (no pure state\u2010generation):\n  1) A squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell analyzer (already well known from Gaussian\u2010ancilla schemes).  \n  2) A two\u2010stage teleportation line powered by squeezing (Pytheus can\u2019t optimize sequential channel fidelities without feedback).  \n  3) A squeezed\u2010reservoir\u2013driven teleportation router: a static 1\u21922 teleportation switch that uses a two\u2010mode squeezed ancilla to bias heralded teleportation into one of two branches.  \n\nStep 2: Checking novelty & feasibility:\n  \u2022 (1) is known (Zaidi\u2009&\u2009van Loock PRL\u2009110).  \n  \u2022 (2) runs into Pytheus\u2019s inability to handle cascaded fidelities or dynamic feed\u2010forward.  \n  \u2022 (3) is new\u2014no previous Pytheus experiment builds a multi\u2010branch teleportation switch powered by a nonclassical reservoir. It uses only probabilistic pair sources (for the two Bell links and the squeezed reservoir), a linear\u2010optics interferometer, photon\u2010number resolving detectors, and post\u2010selection.  \n\nStep 3: I choose (3).\n\nStep 4: Novelty:  \nThis is the first proposal of a static linear\u2010optics \u201cteleportation router\u201d that uses a squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla as a thermodynamic \u201cwork\u201d reservoir. Depending on which pattern of ancilla\u2010detector clicks occurs, the unknown qubit at node A is faithfully teleported either to node B or to node C, with success probability boosted above the vacuum\u2010ancilla limit. This opens up the idea of thermodynamically\u2010powered quantum\u2010network routing, vastly generalizable to N\u2010branch topologies.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:  \n\u2013 Inputs: one dual\u2010rail single\u2010photon qubit at A, two Bell\u2010pair sources for (A\u2013B) and (A\u2013C), one probabilistic two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum source for the reservoir (B\u2013C).  \n\u2013 Network: a mesh of beam\u2010splitters and phase\u2010shifters mixing A\u2019s qubit and all four ancilla modes.  \n\u2013 Outputs: two unmeasured \u201cout_nodes\u201d at B and C (the teleported qubit rails) and several ancilla detectors at B\u2013C for post\u2010selection.  \n\u2013 All elements are within Pytheus\u2019s toolbox: probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors, post\u2010selection. No cavities or dynamic feedback.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\nSqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013driven teleportation router\n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a three\u2010site network A\u2192{B,C} that teleports an unknown qubit at A into one of two destinations, B or C, in a single static linear\u2010optics circuit powered by a \u201csqueezed reservoir.\u201d  \n\n  \u2022 Inputs  \n    \u2013 Single\u2010photon dual\u2010rail qubit at A (modes 0,1) via single_emitters  \n    \u2013 Bell\u2010pair source AB (modes 2,3)  \n    \u2013 Bell\u2010pair source AC (modes 4,5)  \n    \u2013 Two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum (reservoir) source BC (modes 6,7)  \n\n  \u2022 Linear\u2010optics interferometer  \n    \u2013 Mix all eight modes with beam\u2010splitters and phase\u2010shifters  \n\n  \u2022 Detectors  \n    \u2013 Ancilla detectors on modes {2,3,4,5,6,7} record a fixed \u201cclick pattern.\u201d  \n    \u2013 Out_nodes: modes {8,9} carry the teleported qubit to B or C (unmeasured during optimization).  \n\nHeralding rule:\nA particular ancilla\u2010click pattern p_B heralds teleportation onto modes 8\u20139 = B\u2019s rails; another pattern p_C heralds teleportation onto modes 8\u20139 = C\u2019s rails. By injecting the squeezed source on modes 6\u20137, we boost the overall success probability (for either branch) above what is possible with vacuum ancillas alone.\n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-driven teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_router_teleport\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],         # dual-rail input qubit\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\":[2,3]},                # AB Bell\n    {\"modes\":[4,5]},                # AC Bell\n    {\"modes\":[6,7]}                 # BC squeezed reservoir\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [          # forbid direct bypass\n    [0,2],[0,3],[0,4],[0,5]\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"out_nodes\": [8,9],               # rails for teleported qubit (B or C)\n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_teleport\": {              # abstract specification of two heralding patterns\n    \"route_B\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,0,0], \"output\":\"out_nodes=B\"},\n    \"route_C\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,1,1], \"output\":\"out_nodes=C\"}\n  }\n}\n\nThis target tells Pytheus to find the minimal beam\u2010splitter/phase\u2010shift network and source amplitudes that realize a heralded teleportation switch, powered by a squeezed reservoir, routing A\u2019s qubit to B or C with enhanced success. The concept generalizes immediately to N branches and more complex network\u2010thermodynamic protocols."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. This yields a high-fidelity Bell pair between Alice and Bob (the explicit target) within PytHeus\u2019s static linear-optical framework, using two SPDC sources and ancilla detectors without any dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Photonic Realization of the Three-Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring-Exchange\n\nAbstract: We propose and optimize a heralded linear-optics network that implements the nontrivial cyclic-shift unitary U_cycle: |a,b,c\u27e9\u2192|b,c,a\u27e9 via entanglement swapping and Bell-measurement\u2013induced teleportation on a three-node triangular topology. A specific three-click herald pattern routes the remaining photons in the cyclic order, directly mimicking the ring-exchange term of the triangular Heisenberg spin-liquid without generating any static entangled state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid-Frequency Triangle-Network Nonlocality Test with Photonic-Resonator Joint Measurements\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a self-contained three-party triangle nonlocality experiment in which two optical and one THz probabilistic Bell-pair sources feed three nodes arranged in a loop, with node B employing a small photonic-resonator interferometer to mix optical and THz modes for heralded two-outcome joint measurements. Encoded entirely in the Pytheus framework using beam splitters, phase shifters and number-resolving detectors, the scheme allows optimization of local measurement phases to maximize violation of Fritz\u2019s triangle network Bell inequality in a mixed-frequency architecture.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Collision\u2010Mode Photonic MPO Simulation of Lindblad Open\u2010System Dynamics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract: We propose a static one\u2010dimensional photonic matrix\u2010product\u2010operator (MPO) network\u2014built from probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, tunable beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014to stroboscopically enact the small\u2010time Kraus maps E_k = e^{L\u0394t} that realize the target Lindblad generator L over total time T = N\u0394t. By heralding jump/non\u2010jump outcomes on ancilla detectors and optimizing fixed optical connections in PyTheus, this scheme approximates arbitrary Markovian (and, via memory links, non\u2010Markovian) open\u2010system dynamics without dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). By mixing modes A\u2082 and B\u2081 with ancilla photons in an optimized interferometer and employing photon-number-resolving detection, the scheme heralds successful swapping and compression of multi-level entanglement into a qubit link between the Kerr and transmon nodes without feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Cyclic Indefinite\u2010Order Entanglement\u2010Swapping Switch for the Three-State Bargmann Invariant\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static linear-optical network that path-controls a single photon to cyclically superpose three successive Bell\u2013swap orders among unknown qubits A, B, and C, recombining all nine modes in a fixed nine-port interferometer and reading out a binary \u201c+\u201d/\u201c\u2013\u201d outcome. The target is the real part of the three-state Bargmann invariant Re\u2009Tr(\u03c1_A\u2009\u03c1_B\u2009\u03c1_C), whose quantized response statistics directly realize a genuine three-point quantum metric beyond pairwise SWAP tests.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a purely measurement-based photonic quantum network protocol that targets the Zak phase of the one-dimensional Su\u2013Schrieffer\u2013Heeger (SSH) model by teleporting a qubit sequentially around a four-site periodic ring using four probabilistic Bell swaps. Conditioned on four ancilla heralding clicks, the qubit returns to its original spatial mode with a relative phase shift exactly equal to the target Zak phase of the SSH band, which is then read out by a simple two-mode interferometer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. By conditioning on heralding detector clicks, the experiment realizes interference between the \u201csend-it\u201d and \u201cteleport-it\u201d arrival modes at the receiver, demonstrating coherent superposition of two fundamentally different quantum communication channels without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ring\u2010Swapped Tri\u2010Mode Optical Interferometer for Simultaneous Estimation of Three Relative Phases\n\nAbstract: We implement a closed\u2010loop network of three SPDC two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources linked by sequential Bell swaps at a central node X, apply unknown phase shifts \u03c6A, \u03c6B, and \u03c6C at parties A, B, and C, and route the resulting modes through a PythEUS\u2010optimized 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical multiport with photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Using three probabilistic EPR sources, linear-optics routing into two Bell-measurement stations, and post-selection on the control measurement, this experiment realizes the target entanglement-switch quantum switch primitive without state-generation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. This proof-of-principle demonstration establishes the first abstract spectrally tunable quantum router primitive for modular, loss-immune photonic networks and paves the way toward programmable topological photonic crystal implementations.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 Bell Pairs\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a single-step quantum repeater node that simultaneously swaps and concentrates two non-maximally entangled SPDC links into a heralded maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between remote modes. By statically mixing the inner modes in an optimized linear-optics network and post-selecting on two threshold-detector clicks, the scheme realizes the target Bell pair in one heralded operation without active feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nPT-Symmetric Gain\u2013Loss Filter\u2013Enhanced Teleportation for High-Fidelity Remote CNOT\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe demonstrate a heralded, non-unitary PT-symmetric gain\u2013loss filter embedded in the Bell-state measurement of a teleportation-based CNOT between photonic qubit A (control) and qubit C (target). By using SPDC-pair ancillas, four-port interferometric mixing, and number-resolving detection to preferentially amplify even-parity Bell components, our scheme surpasses the 50% passive-linear-optics limit and boosts both the success probability and fidelity of the nonlocal CNOT gate.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement Swapping of 2\u00d72 Toric-Code Logical Qubits via Linear Optics\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate entanglement swapping between two distant logical qubits, each encoded in a minimal 2\u00d72 toric-code patch of four photons at nodes A and D, by performing a post-selected logical Bell measurement on intermediate patches B and C using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, passive linear optics, and ancilla detection. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 2\u20133), realized abstractly by two probabilistic photon-pair sources, and then routing all four photons through a linear-optics interferometer plus post-selected detection, we aim to unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states on modes 0\u20131. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2.     "output": "Thought: This \u201csqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013driven teleportation router\u201d is simply the same Gaussian\u2010ancilla trick you\u2019ve already applied for Bell analyzers, SWAP gates, cluster fusion, and entanglement percolation\u2014now repackaged as a teleportation switch. Moreover, the ensemble has already proposed a \u201cDual\u2010Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip,\u201d so your new twist of adding squeezers to boost success probability does not constitute a fundamentally new measurement primitive, resource usage, or network topology.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To achieve PRL\u2010level novelty you must propose a genuinely new non-Gaussian joint measurement, an indefinite causal\u2010order routing primitive, or a network transformation that cannot be reduced to passive optics plus two\u2010mode squeezing. Simply boosting a known teleportation switch with squeezers is not sufficient."
}
{
    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties.
