In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"quantum thermodynamics\" and \"squeezed reservoir\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 2\u20133), realized abstractly by two probabilistic photon-pair sources, and then routing all four photons through a linear-optics interferometer plus post-selected detection, we aim to unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states on modes 0\u20131. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2. The Expert can use Pytheus to optimize the linear\u2010optics network and ancilla connections to realize this squeezed-reservoir\u2010assisted Bell measurement.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your \u201csqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013assisted\u201d Bell analyser replicates published schemes that use two\u2010mode squeezers to exceed the 50 % linear\u2010optics limit (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL 110, 260501 (2013)). series (A\u2192B\u2192C), injecting squeezed-reservoir ancillas at each Bell measurement, to study the trade-off between squeezing \u201cwork\u201d and teleportation fidelity over a network.  \n  3) A heralded SWAP gate fueled by a squeezed reservoir: implement a two-qubit SWAP (|ab\u27e9\u2192|ba\u27e9) via a linear-optics network, using a two-mode squeezed ancilla as a nonclassical reservoir to beat the vacuum-ancilla success bound.\n\nStep 2: Check novelty and feasibility:\n  1) Squeezed-assisted Bell analyzers already appear in the literature (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL 110).  \n  2) Pytheus (they have CNOT and Toffoli), and using a squeezed pair as reservoir ancilla to boost SWAP success is a fresh combination of thermodynamic resource theory and quantum-network transformations.\n\nStep 3: Select idea #3.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus experiment targets a heralded SWAP gate\u2014and none uses a squeezed-vacuum ancilla interpreted as a thermodynamic resource\u2014to experimentally probe how nonclassical \u201cwork\u201d reservoirs enable higher-success optical gate operations.\n\nStep 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and meets all constraints because it uses only single-photon emitters for the two qubit inputs, two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources to model the squeezed reservoir, a linear-optics interferometer, and photon\u2010number-resolving detectors with post\u2010selection. There is no pure state preparation demand and no dynamic feedback control required.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nDescription:  \nHeralded two-qubit SWAP gate powered by a squeezed reservoir  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe aim to design a linear-optics network that implements the SWAP operation on two unknown photonic qubits (modes A and B) in a heralded fashion, using a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla (modes C and D) as a nonclassical thermodynamic resource (\u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d). By mixing all four modes in a network of beam splitters and phase shifters and then performing photon-number-resolving detection on the ancilla outputs, we herald events in which the remaining two output modes carry the swapped qubit state |a\u27e9_A\u2009|b\u27e9_B \u2192 |b\u27e9_A\u2009|a\u27e9_B. This opens up the idea of thermodynamically\u2010powered quantum\u2010network routing, vastly generalizable to N\u2010branch topologies.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:  \n\u2013 Inputs: one dual\u2010rail single\u2010photon qubit at A, two Bell\u2010pair sources for (A\u2013B) and (A\u2013C), one probabilistic two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum source for the reservoir (B\u2013C).  \n\u2013 Network: a mesh of beam\u2010splitters and phase\u2010shifters mixing A\u2019s qubit and all four ancilla modes.  \n\u2013 Outputs: two unmeasured \u201cout_nodes\u201d at B and C (the teleported qubit rails) and several ancilla detectors at B\u2013C for post\u2010selection.  \n\u2013 All elements are within Pytheus\u2019s toolbox: probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors, post\u2010selection. No cavities or dynamic feedback.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\nSqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013driven teleportation router\n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a three\u2010site network A\u2192{B,C} that teleports an unknown qubit at A into one of two destinations, B or C, in a single static linear\u2010optics circuit powered by a \u201csqueezed reservoir.\u201d  \n\n  \u2022 Inputs  \n    \u2013 Single\u2010photon dual\u2010rail qubit at A (modes 0,1) via single_emitters  \n    \u2013 Bell\u2010pair source AB (modes 2,3)  \n    \u2013 Bell\u2010pair source AC (modes 4,5)  \n    \u2013 Two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum (reservoir) source BC (modes 6,7)  \n\n  \u2022 Linear\u2010optics interferometer  \n    \u2013 Mix all eight modes with beam\u2010splitters and phase\u2010shifters  \n\n  \u2022 Detectors  \n    \u2013 Ancilla detectors on modes {2,3,4,5,6,7} record a fixed \u201cclick pattern.\u201d  \n    \u2013 Out_nodes: modes {8,9} carry the teleported qubit to B or C (unmeasured during optimization).  \n\nHeralding rule:\nA particular ancilla\u2010click pattern p_B heralds teleportation onto modes 8\u20139 = B\u2019s rails; another pattern p_C heralds teleportation onto modes 8\u20139 = C\u2019s rails. By injecting the squeezed source on modes 6\u20137, we boost the overall success probability (for either branch) above what is possible with vacuum ancillas alone.\n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-driven teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_router_teleport\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],         # dual-rail input qubit\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\":[2,3]},                # AB Bell\n    {\"modes\":[4,5]},                # AC Bell\n    {\"modes\":[6,7]}                 # BC squeezed reservoir\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [          # forbid direct bypass\n    [0,2],[0,3],[0,4],[0,5]\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"out_nodes\": [8,9],               # rails for teleported qubit (B or C)\n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_teleport\": {              # abstract specification of two heralding patterns\n    \"route_B\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,0,0], \"output\":\"out_nodes=B\"},\n    \"route_C\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,1,1], \"output\":\"out_nodes=C\"}\n  }\n}\n\nThis target tells Pytheus to find the minimal beam\u2010splitter/phase\u2010shift network and source amplitudes that realize a heralded teleportation switch, powered by a squeezed reservoir, routing A\u2019s qubit to B or C with enhanced success. The concept generalizes immediately to N branches and more complex network\u2010thermodynamic protocols.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To achieve PRL\u2010level novelty you must propose a genuinely new non-Gaussian joint measurement, an indefinite causal\u2010order routing primitive, or a network transformation that cannot be reduced to passive optics plus two\u2010mode squeezing. Simply boosting a known teleportation switch with squeezers is not sufficient.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to fuse \u201cquantum thermodynamics\u201d (a work or heat reservoir) with a \u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d into a network/transformation rather than pure\u2010state generation:\n    1) Squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell analyzer (well known in Gaussian\u2010ancilla literature).\n    2) Two\u2010stage teleportation line boosted by squeezing (requires sequential channel fidelity metrics and/or feedback\u2014Pytheus can\u2019t handle).\n    3) A static \u201cteleportation router\u201d A\u2192{B,C}: a single linear\u2010optics circuit that, powered by a two\u2010mode squeezed ancilla (the reservoir), probabilistically routes an input qubit at A to either B or C depending on which heralding clicks occur. The squeezing boosts success probability over vacuum ancilla.\n  Step 2: Check novelty & feasibility:\n    \u2022 (1) is already in the literature (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL\u2009110).  \n    \u2022 (2) runs into Pytheus\u2019s limitations on cascaded channels and dynamic feedback.  \n    \u2022 (3) no previous Pytheus\u2010designed experiment builds a multi\u2010output teleportation switch powered by a nonclassical reservoir. It uses only probabilistic pair sources (for AB\u2010Bell, AC\u2010Bell, BC\u2010squeezed ancilla), linear optics, photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors and post\u2010selection.\n  Step 3: Pick idea (3).\n  Step 4: Novelty:  \n    It is the first proposal of a **static** linear\u2010optics \u201cteleportation router\u201d that uses a two\u2010mode squeezed vacuum as a thermodynamic \u201cwork reservoir.\u201d Depending on which ancilla\u2010click pattern occurs, the unknown qubit at node A is teleported to either node B or C. The squeezed reservoir raises the overall success probability above the passive\u2010vacuum bound. This opens up \u201cthermodynamically\u2010powered routing\u201d in quantum networks and generalizes to N\u2010branch switches.\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n    \u2013 Inputs: one dual-rail single-photon qubit at A, two Bell\u2010pair sources (AB and AC), one two-mode squeezed\u2010vacuum source (BC).  \n    \u2013 Static linear\u2010optics interferometer mixing all modes.  \n    \u2013 Photon-number-resolving detectors on the six ancilla modes at B\u2013C to post-select the teleportation branch; the two output rails at either B or C are left unmeasured (\u201cout_nodes\u201d).  \n    \u2013 All elements\u2014probabilistic pair sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, number\u2010resolving detectors, post-selection\u2014are within Pytheus\u2019s toolbox. No cavities, no dynamic feed\u2010forward, no forbidden state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir-driven teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe design a single static linear-optics network that teleports an unknown dual-rail photonic qubit at site A into one of two output sites, B or C, powered by a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla acting as a thermodynamic work reservoir. Depending on which pattern of ancilla detectors clicks at B\u2013C, the qubit is routed (teleported) to B\u2019s or C\u2019s output rails. Injecting squeezing into the reservoir pair (BC) raises the overall heralded success probability above what is achievable with vacuum ancillas.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters / pair\u2010sources:\n   \u2013 Single\u2010photon dual\u2010rail qubit at A: modes (0,1) via single_emitters  \n   \u2013 Bell\u2010pair AB \u2192 modes (2,3)  \n   \u2013 Bell\u2010pair AC \u2192 modes (4,5)  \n   \u2013 Squeezed-vacuum BC \u2192 modes (6,7)  \n       \u2193  \n linear-optics interferometer: beam splitters & phase shifters mixing modes 0\u20137  \n       \u2193  \n detectors:\n   \u2013 Ancilla detectors on modes 2,3,4,5,6,7 record click patterns  \n   \u2013 Out_nodes: a pair of rails at either B or C (modes 8,9) carry the teleported qubit  \n\nHeralding:\n  \u2013 Click pattern p_B on ancillas heralds teleportation to B: output rails (8,9) = B.  \n  \u2013 Click pattern p_C heralds teleportation to C: output rails (8,9) = C.  \n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-driven teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_router_teleport\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\":[2,3]},    # AB Bell\n    {\"modes\":[4,5]},    # AC Bell\n    {\"modes\":[6,7]}     # BC squeezed reservoir\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [ [0,2],[0,3],[0,4],[0,5] ], \n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"out_nodes\": [8,9],\n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_teleport\": {\n    \"route_B\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,0,0], \"output\":\"out_nodes=B\"},\n    \"route_C\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,1,1], \"output\":\"out_nodes=C\"}\n  }\n}\n\nThis proposal invites Pytheus to find the minimal beam\u2010splitter/phase\u2010shift network and source amplitudes that realize a **heralded teleportation switch**, boosted by a squeezed reservoir. The concept generalizes to N\u2010branch quantum routing and a wide class of thermodynamically\u2010powered network transformations."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. This yields a high-fidelity Bell pair between Alice and Bob (the explicit target) within PytHeus\u2019s static linear-optical framework, using two SPDC sources and ancilla detectors without any dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Photonic Realization of the Three-Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring-Exchange\n\nAbstract: We propose and optimize a heralded linear-optics network that implements the nontrivial cyclic-shift unitary U_cycle: |a,b,c\u27e9\u2192|b,c,a\u27e9 via entanglement swapping and Bell-measurement\u2013induced teleportation on a three-node triangular topology. A specific three-click herald pattern routes the remaining photons in the cyclic order, directly mimicking the ring-exchange term of the triangular Heisenberg spin-liquid without generating any static entangled state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid-Frequency Triangle-Network Nonlocality Test with Photonic-Resonator Joint Measurements\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a self-contained three-party triangle nonlocality experiment in which two optical and one THz probabilistic Bell-pair sources feed three nodes arranged in a loop, with node B employing a small photonic-resonator interferometer to mix optical and THz modes for heralded two-outcome joint measurements. Encoded entirely in the Pytheus framework using beam splitters, phase shifters and number-resolving detectors, the scheme allows optimization of local measurement phases to maximize violation of Fritz\u2019s triangle network Bell inequality in a mixed-frequency architecture.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Collision\u2010Mode Photonic MPO Simulation of Lindblad Open\u2010System Dynamics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract: We propose a static one\u2010dimensional photonic matrix\u2010product\u2010operator (MPO) network\u2014built from probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, tunable beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014to stroboscopically enact the small\u2010time Kraus maps E_k = e^{L\u0394t} that realize the target Lindblad generator L over total time T = N\u0394t. By heralding jump/non\u2010jump outcomes on ancilla detectors and optimizing fixed optical connections in PyTheus, this scheme approximates arbitrary Markovian (and, via memory links, non\u2010Markovian) open\u2010system dynamics without dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). By mixing modes A\u2082 and B\u2081 with ancilla photons in an optimized interferometer and employing photon-number-resolving detection, the scheme heralds successful swapping and compression of multi-level entanglement into a qubit link between the Kerr and transmon nodes without feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Cyclic Indefinite\u2010Order Entanglement\u2010Swapping Switch for the Three-State Bargmann Invariant\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static linear-optical network that path-controls a single photon to cyclically superpose three successive Bell\u2013swap orders among unknown qubits A, B, and C, recombining all nine modes in a fixed nine-port interferometer and reading out a binary \u201c+\u201d/\u201c\u2013\u201d outcome. The target is the real part of the three-state Bargmann invariant Re\u2009Tr(\u03c1_A\u2009\u03c1_B\u2009\u03c1_C), whose quantized response statistics directly realize a genuine three-point quantum metric beyond pairwise SWAP tests.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a purely measurement-based photonic quantum network protocol that targets the Zak phase of the one-dimensional Su\u2013Schrieffer\u2013Heeger (SSH) model by teleporting a qubit sequentially around a four-site periodic ring using four probabilistic Bell swaps. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. A three-mode linear-optics interferometer with photon-number-resolving heralding converts the residual local coherence into nonlocal entanglement between distant output photons A and D, outperforming conventional two-link swapping in the presence of loss.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Quantum SWITCH Superactivates Entanglement via Indefinite Causal Order\n\nMini-abstract: We implement the target measurement-induced photonic quantum SWITCH of two entanglement-breaking dephasing channels using ancilla photons, passive linear optics, and post-selection to emulate a discrete cross-Kerr coupling between a control and two data paths. Embedding this device in an entanglement-distribution protocol, we show that, conditioned on the SWITCH herald, a qubit emerging from two individually entanglement-destroying channels remains entangled with a remote partner\u2014demonstrating entanglement superactivation by indefinite causal order.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: PT-Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non-Hermitian Bell-State Projection\n\nAbstract: We implement entanglement swapping on two polarization-encoded Bell pairs using a central PT-symmetric, non-unitary Bell-state analyser. By heralding the projector onto the PT-modified Bell state (the target map) and tuning its gain/loss parameter \u03b3, the protocol controllably generates a two-photon output |\u03a8_AD\u27e9\u221d|HH\u27e9+\u03b3\u2009e^{i\u03d5}|VV\u27e9 with adjustable, non-maximal entanglement.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a single-shot four-body stabilizer readout for the smallest toric-code plaquette by Bell-entangling each of four data photons with an ancilla photon and sending all ancilla modes through a 4\u00d74 passive interferometer equipped with number-resolving detectors. Heralded two-photon click patterns in even or odd detector pairs directly project the data qubits onto the \u00b11 eigenstates of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084, realizing a direct stabilizer measurement without any feed-forward or dynamic control.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 2\u20133), realized abstractly by two probabilistic photon-pair sources, and then routing all four photons through a linear-optics interferometer plus post-selected detection, we aim to unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states on modes 0\u20131. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2.     "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"quantum thermodynamics\" and \"squeezed reservoir\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 2\u20133), realized abstractly by two probabilistic photon-pair sources, and then routing all four photons through a linear-optics interferometer plus post-selected detection, we aim to unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states on modes 0\u20131. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2. series (A\u2192B\u2192C), injecting squeezed-reservoir ancillas at each Bell measurement, to study the trade-off between squeezing \u201cwork\u201d and teleportation fidelity over a network.  \n  3) A Pytheus (they have CNOT and Toffoli), and using a squeezed pair as reservoir ancilla to boost SWAP success is a fresh combination of thermodynamic resource theory and quantum-network By mixing all four modes in a network of beam splitters and phase shifters and then performing photon-number-resolving detection on the ancilla outputs, we herald events in which the remaining two output modes carry the swapped qubit state |a\u27e9_A\u2009|b\u27e9_B \u2192 |b\u27e9_A\u2009|a\u27e9_B. This opens up the idea of thermodynamically\u2010powered quantum\u2010network routing, vastly generalizable to N\u2010branch topologies.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:  \n\u2013 Inputs: one dual\u2010rail single\u2010photon qubit at A, two Bell\u2010pair sources for (A\u2013B) and (A\u2013C), one probabilistic two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum source for the reservoir (B\u2013C).  \n\u2013 Network: a mesh of beam\u2010splitters and phase\u2010shifters mixing A\u2019s qubit and all four ancilla modes.  \n\u2013 Outputs: two unmeasured \u201cout_nodes\u201d at B and C (the teleported qubit rails) and several ancilla detectors at B\u2013C for post\u2010selection.  \n\u2013 All elements are within Pytheus\u2019s toolbox: probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors, post\u2010selection. No cavities or dynamic feedback.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\nSqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013driven teleportation router\n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a three\u2010site network A\u2192{B,C} that teleports an unknown qubit at A into one of two destinations, B or C, in a single static linear\u2010optics circuit powered by a \u201csqueezed reservoir.\u201d  \n\n  \u2022 Inputs  \n    \u2013 Single\u2010photon dual\u2010rail qubit at A (modes 0,1) via single_emitters  \n    \u2013 Bell\u2010pair source AB (modes 2,3)  \n    \u2013 Bell\u2010pair source AC (modes 4,5)  \n    \u2013 Two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum (reservoir) source BC (modes 6,7)  \n\n  \u2022 Linear\u2010optics interferometer  \n    \u2013 Mix all eight modes with beam\u2010splitters and phase\u2010shifters  \n\n  \u2022 Detectors  \n    \u2013 Ancilla detectors on modes {2,3,4,5,6,7} record a fixed \u201cclick pattern.\u201d  \n    \u2013 Out_nodes: modes {8,9} carry the teleported qubit to B or C (unmeasured during optimization).  \n\nHeralding rule:\nA particular ancilla\u2010click pattern p_B heralds teleportation onto modes 8\u20139 = B\u2019s rails; another pattern p_C heralds teleportation onto modes 8\u20139 = C\u2019s rails. By injecting the squeezed source on modes 6\u20137, we boost the overall success probability (for either branch) above what is possible with vacuum ancillas alone.\n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-driven teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_router_teleport\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],         # dual-rail input qubit\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\":[2,3]},                # AB Bell\n    {\"modes\":[4,5]},                # AC Bell\n    {\"modes\":[6,7]}                 # BC squeezed reservoir\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [          # forbid direct bypass\n    [0,2],[0,3],[0,4],[0,5]\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"out_nodes\": [8,9],               # rails for teleported qubit (B or C)\n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_teleport\": {              # abstract specification of two heralding patterns\n    \"route_B\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,0,0], \"output\":\"out_nodes=B\"},\n    \"route_C\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,1,1], \"output\":\"out_nodes=C\"}\n  }\n}\n\nThis target tells Pytheus to find the minimal beam\u2010splitter/phase\u2010shift network and source amplitudes that realize a heralded teleportation switch, powered by a squeezed reservoir, routing A\u2019s qubit to B or C with enhanced success. The concept generalizes immediately to N branches and more complex network\u2010thermodynamic protocols.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To achieve PRL\u2010level novelty you must propose a genuinely new non-Gaussian joint measurement, an indefinite causal\u2010order routing primitive, or a network transformation that cannot be reduced to passive optics plus two\u2010mode squeezing. Simply boosting a known teleportation switch with squeezers is not sufficient.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to fuse \u201cquantum thermodynamics\u201d (a work or heat reservoir) with a \u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d into a network/transformation rather than pure\u2010state generation:\n    1) Squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell analyzer (well known in Gaussian\u2010ancilla literature).\n    2) Two\u2010stage teleportation line boosted by squeezing (requires sequential channel fidelity metrics and/or feedback\u2014Pytheus can\u2019t handle).\n    3) A static \u201cteleportation router\u201d A\u2192{B,C}: a single linear\u2010optics circuit that, powered by a two\u2010mode squeezed ancilla (the reservoir), probabilistically routes an input qubit at A to either B or C depending on which heralding clicks occur. The squeezing boosts success probability over vacuum ancilla.\n  Step 2: Check novelty & feasibility:\n    \u2022 (1) is already in the literature (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL\u2009110).  \n    \u2022 (2) runs into Pytheus\u2019s limitations on cascaded channels and dynamic feedback.  \n    \u2022 (3) no previous Pytheus\u2010designed experiment builds a multi\u2010output teleportation switch powered by a nonclassical reservoir. It uses only probabilistic pair sources (for AB\u2010Bell, AC\u2010Bell, BC\u2010squeezed ancilla), linear optics, photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors and post\u2010selection.\n  Step 3: Pick idea (3).\n  Step 4: Novelty:  \n    It is the first proposal of a **static** linear\u2010optics \u201cteleportation router\u201d that uses a two\u2010mode squeezed vacuum as a thermodynamic \u201cwork reservoir.\u201d Depending on which ancilla\u2010click pattern occurs, the unknown qubit at node A is teleported to either node B or C. The squeezed reservoir raises the overall success probability above the passive\u2010vacuum bound. This opens up \u201cthermodynamically\u2010powered routing\u201d in quantum networks and generalizes to N\u2010branch switches.\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n    \u2013 Inputs: one dual-rail single-photon qubit at A, two Bell\u2010pair sources (AB and AC), one two-mode squeezed\u2010vacuum source (BC).  \n    \u2013 Static linear\u2010optics interferometer mixing all modes.  \n    \u2013 Photon-number-resolving detectors on the six ancilla modes at B\u2013C to post-select the teleportation branch; the two output rails at either B or C are left unmeasured (\u201cout_nodes\u201d).  \n    \u2013 All elements\u2014probabilistic pair sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, number\u2010resolving detectors, post-selection\u2014are within Pytheus\u2019s toolbox. No cavities, no dynamic feed\u2010forward, no forbidden state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir-driven teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe design a single static linear-optics network that teleports an unknown dual-rail photonic qubit at site A into one of two output sites, B or C, powered by a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla acting as a thermodynamic work reservoir. Depending on which pattern of ancilla detectors clicks at B\u2013C, the qubit is routed (teleported) to B\u2019s or C\u2019s output rails. Injecting squeezing into the reservoir pair (BC) raises the overall heralded success probability above what is achievable with vacuum ancillas.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters / pair\u2010sources:\n   \u2013 Single\u2010photon dual\u2010rail qubit at A: modes (0,1) via single_emitters  \n   \u2013 Bell\u2010pair AB \u2192 modes (2,3)  \n   \u2013 Bell\u2010pair AC \u2192 modes (4,5)  \n   \u2013 Squeezed-vacuum BC \u2192 modes (6,7)  \n       \u2193  \n linear-optics interferometer: beam splitters & phase shifters mixing modes 0\u20137  \n       \u2193  \n detectors:\n   \u2013 Ancilla detectors on modes 2,3,4,5,6,7 record click patterns  \n   \u2013 Out_nodes: a pair of rails at either B or C (modes 8,9) carry the teleported qubit  \n\nHeralding:\n  \u2013 Click pattern p_B on ancillas heralds teleportation to B: output rails (8,9) = B.  \n  \u2013 Click pattern p_C heralds teleportation to C: output rails (8,9) = C.  \n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-driven teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_router_teleport\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\":[2,3]},    # AB Bell\n    {\"modes\":[4,5]},    # AC Bell\n    {\"modes\":[6,7]}     # BC squeezed reservoir\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [ [0,2],[0,3],[0,4],[0,5] ], \n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"out_nodes\": [8,9],\n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_teleport\": {\n    \"route_B\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,0,0], \"output\":\"out_nodes=B\"},\n    \"route_C\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,1,1], \"output\":\"out_nodes=C\"}\n  }\n}\n\nThis proposal invites Pytheus to find the minimal beam\u2010splitter/phase\u2010shift network and source amplitudes that realize a **heralded teleportation switch**, boosted by a squeezed reservoir. The concept generalizes to N\u2010branch quantum routing and a wide class of thermodynamically\u2010powered network transformations.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your \u201csqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013driven teleportation router\u201d adds no fundamentally new network or non\u2010Gaussian measurement beyond the dual\u2010destination switch already in the ensemble and standard squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell enhancements. To be PRL\u2010worthy you need a truly new primitive\u2014e.g. a non\u2010Gaussian joint projector, an indefinite\u2010order routing, or a network transformation that cannot be reduced to passive optics plus squeezers.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm 3 Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to combine \u201cquantum thermodynamics\u201d and a \u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d in a network/transformation (no pure\u2010state generation):\n    1) Squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell measurement (well known).\n    2) Multi\u2010stage teleportation chain boosted by squeezing (requires cascaded\u2010fidelity optimization/feedback\u2014Pytheus can\u2019t handle).\n    3) A heralded three\u2010qubit cyclic\u2010SWAP (A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192A) gate powered by a two\u2010mode squeezed ancilla acting as a thermodynamic \u201cwork reservoir.\u201d  \n  Step 2: Check novelty & feasibility:\n    \u2022 (1) is standard (Zaidi & van Loock PRL\u2009110).  \n    \u2022 (2) runs into Pytheus\u2019s inability to handle sequential channel metrics or dynamic feed\u2010forward.  \n    \u2022 (3) is genuinely new\u2014no existing Pytheus experiment implements a cyclic permutation of three qubits in one static interferometer, nor uses a squeezed ancilla as a thermodynamic resource to boost the success probability of such a multi\u2010node gate. It uses only probabilistic pair sources, single\u2010photon emitters, linear optics, number\u2010resolving detectors, and post\u2010selection.  \n  Step 3: Pick idea (3).  \n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    It is the first proposal of a **heralded cyclic\u2010SWAP** on three unknown photonic qubits A, B, C\u2014 a network transformation beyond pairwise entanglement\u2010swapping or teleportation\u2014**powered by a squeezed reservoir**. The cyclic swap (A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A) embodies a primitive \u201cwork cycle\u201d in quantum\u2010thermodynamic language, showing how a nonclassical bath (squeezing) catalyzes a nontrivial multi\u2010node unitary with higher success probability.  \n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n    \u2013 System inputs: three single\u2010rail qubits at modes 0,1,2 via single_emitters.  \n    \u2013 Reservoir input: a two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla at modes 3,4 via one probabilistic pair\u2010source.  \n    \u2013 Static linear\u2010optics interferometer mixing modes 0\u20134.  \n    \u2013 Photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors on modes 3,4 (ancilla) to herald the cyclic\u2010swap event; the post\u2010selected outputs on modes 0,1,2 carry the permuted qubit states.  \n    \u2013 No forbidden state generation, no feedback, only allowed elements.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nHeralded cyclic\u2013SWAP of three qubits assisted by a squeezed reservoir\n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a static linear\u2010optics network that, on heralding from a two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla (modes 3\u20134), effects the unitary permutation A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A on three unknown single\u2010rail qubits at A, B, C (modes 0\u20132). The squeezed ancilla acts as a thermodynamic \u201cwork reservoir,\u201d boosting the post\u2010selected success probability of this three\u2010node gate above what is possible with vacuum ancillas alone. This cyclic swap is a genuinely new multi\u2010node transformation\u2014neither pairwise swapping nor teleportation\u2014and directly generalizes to N\u2010cycle quantum\u2010thermodynamic engine cycles.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters/sources:\n   \u2013 single_emitters: modes [0],[1],[2] \u2192 qubits A,B,C  \n   \u2013 probabilistic_pair_source: modes [3,4] \u2192 two-mode squeezed ancilla  \n       \u2193  \n linear-optics network: beam-splitters & phase-shifters mixing modes 0\u20134  \n       \u2193  \n detectors:\n   \u2013 ancilla detectors: modes [3,4] (number-resolving)  \n   \u2013 out_nodes: modes [0,1,2] carry the permuted qubit states  \n\nHerald condition:\nExactly one photon in each of modes 3 and 4. Conditioned on that, the mapping on the system qubits is\n\u2003|a\u27e9\u2080\u2009|b\u27e9\u2081\u2009|c\u27e9\u2082 \u2192 |b\u27e9\u2080\u2009|c\u27e9\u2081\u2009|a\u27e9\u2082  \nfor all a,b,c\u2208{0,1}.\n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Heralded cyclic\u2013SWAP of three single-rail qubits powered by a squeezed reservoir\",\n  \"foldername\": \"cyclic_swap_squeezed\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1,2],\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\": [3,4]}\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [  # prevent bypass of system\u2192ancilla mixing\n    [0,3],[1,3],[2,4]\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"anc_detectors\": [3,4],\n  \"out_nodes\": [0,1,2],\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_quantum\": [\n    \"000\",  # |000>\u2192|000>\n    \"100\",  # |100>\u2192|010>\n    \"010\",  # |010>\u2192|001>\n    \"001\",  # |001>\u2192|100>\n    \"110\",  # |110>\u2192|011>\n    \"011\",  # |011>\u2192|101>\n    \"101\",  # |101>\u2192|110>\n    \"111\"   # |111>\u2192|111>\n  ]\n}\n\nThe Expert can hand this target to Pytheus to discover the minimal beam-splitter/phase-shift network and source amplitudes that realize the cyclic\u2010SWAP gate\u2014a novel multi\u2010node quantum\u2010thermodynamic primitive powered by a squeezed reservoir."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. This yields a high-fidelity Bell pair between Alice and Bob (the explicit target) within PytHeus\u2019s static linear-optical framework, using two SPDC sources and ancilla detectors without any dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Photonic Realization of the Three-Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring-Exchange\n\nAbstract: We propose and optimize a heralded linear-optics network that implements the nontrivial cyclic-shift unitary U_cycle: |a,b,c\u27e9\u2192|b,c,a\u27e9 via entanglement swapping and Bell-measurement\u2013induced teleportation on a three-node triangular topology. A specific three-click herald pattern routes the remaining photons in the cyclic order, directly mimicking the ring-exchange term of the triangular Heisenberg spin-liquid without generating any static entangled state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid-Frequency Triangle-Network Nonlocality Test with Photonic-Resonator Joint Measurements\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a self-contained three-party triangle nonlocality experiment in which two optical and one THz probabilistic Bell-pair sources feed three nodes arranged in a loop, with node B employing a small photonic-resonator interferometer to mix optical and THz modes for heralded two-outcome joint measurements. Encoded entirely in the Pytheus framework using beam splitters, phase shifters and number-resolving detectors, the scheme allows optimization of local measurement phases to maximize violation of Fritz\u2019s triangle network Bell inequality in a mixed-frequency architecture.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Collision\u2010Mode Photonic MPO Simulation of Lindblad Open\u2010System Dynamics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract: We propose a static one\u2010dimensional photonic matrix\u2010product\u2010operator (MPO) network\u2014built from probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, tunable beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014to stroboscopically enact the small\u2010time Kraus maps E_k = e^{L\u0394t} that realize the target Lindblad generator L over total time T = N\u0394t. By heralding jump/non\u2010jump outcomes on ancilla detectors and optimizing fixed optical connections in PyTheus, this scheme approximates arbitrary Markovian (and, via memory links, non\u2010Markovian) open\u2010system dynamics without dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). By mixing modes A\u2082 and B\u2081 with ancilla photons in an optimized interferometer and employing photon-number-resolving detection, the scheme heralds successful swapping and compression of multi-level entanglement into a qubit link between the Kerr and transmon nodes without feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Cyclic Indefinite\u2010Order Entanglement\u2010Swapping Switch for the Three-State Bargmann Invariant\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static linear-optical network that path-controls a single photon to cyclically superpose three successive Bell\u2013swap orders among unknown qubits A, B, and C, recombining all nine modes in a fixed nine-port interferometer and reading out a binary \u201c+\u201d/\u201c\u2013\u201d outcome. The target is the real part of the three-state Bargmann invariant Re\u2009Tr(\u03c1_A\u2009\u03c1_B\u2009\u03c1_C), whose quantized response statistics directly realize a genuine three-point quantum metric beyond pairwise SWAP tests.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a purely measurement-based photonic quantum network protocol that targets the Zak phase of the one-dimensional Su\u2013Schrieffer\u2013Heeger (SSH) model by teleporting a qubit sequentially around a four-site periodic ring using four probabilistic Bell swaps. Conditioned on four ancilla heralding clicks, the qubit returns to its original spatial mode with a relative phase shift exactly equal to the target Zak phase of the SSH band, which is then read out by a simple two-mode interferometer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. By conditioning on heralding detector clicks, the experiment realizes interference between the \u201csend-it\u201d and \u201cteleport-it\u201d arrival modes at the receiver, demonstrating coherent superposition of two fundamentally different quantum communication channels without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ring\u2010Swapped Tri\u2010Mode Optical Interferometer for Simultaneous Estimation of Three Relative Phases\n\nAbstract: We implement a closed\u2010loop network of three SPDC two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources linked by sequential Bell swaps at a central node X, apply unknown phase shifts \u03c6A, \u03c6B, and \u03c6C at parties A, B, and C, and route the resulting modes through a PythEUS\u2010optimized 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical multiport with photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Using three probabilistic EPR sources, linear-optics routing into two Bell-measurement stations, and post-selection on the control measurement, this experiment realizes the target entanglement-switch quantum switch primitive without state-generation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 2\u20133), realized abstractly by two probabilistic photon-pair sources, and then routing all four photons through a linear-optics interferometer plus post-selected detection, we aim to unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states on modes 0\u20131. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2. The Expert can use Pytheus to optimize the linear\u2010optics network and ancilla connections to realize this squeezed-reservoir\u2010assisted Bell measurement.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The goal\u2014to surpass the 50 % Bell\u2010measurement limit using a two\u2010mode squeezed ancilla\u2014is already realized in the literature (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock, PRL 110, 260501 (2013) and follow\u2010ups using squeezers to boost linear\u2010optics Bell analyses).
