A Type-I fusion is essentially a parity/Bell measurement on two qubits, so boosting it with Gaussian ancillas follows immediately from prior squeezed-Bell schemes (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL 110, 260501 and related work). No new non-Gaussian resource, measurement primitive, or network topology is introduced.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To reach PRL-level novelty, propose a measurement or resource that can\u2019t be reduced to passive optics plus squeezers\u2014e.g. a genuine multi-photon non-Gaussian joint projector, an indefinite-order cluster fusion network, or another qualitatively new primitive beyond Gaussian ancilla enhancement.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\nSqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013driven teleportation router\n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a three\u2010site network A\u2192{B,C} that teleports an unknown qubit at A into one of two destinations, B or C, in a single static linear\u2010optics circuit powered by a \u201csqueezed reservoir.\u201d  \n\n  \u2022 Inputs  \n    \u2013 Single\u2010photon dual\u2010rail qubit at A (modes 0,1) via single_emitters  \n    \u2013 Bell\u2010pair source AB (modes 2,3)  \n    \u2013 Bell\u2010pair source AC (modes 4,5)  \n    \u2013 Two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum (reservoir) source BC (modes 6,7)  \n\n  \u2022 Linear\u2010optics interferometer  \n    \u2013 Mix all eight modes with beam\u2010splitters and phase\u2010shifters  \n\n  \u2022 Detectors  \n    \u2013 Ancilla detectors on modes {2,3,4,5,6,7} record a fixed \u201cclick pattern.\u201d  \n    \u2013 Out_nodes: modes {8,9} carry the teleported qubit to B or C (unmeasured during optimization).  \n\nHeralding rule:\nA particular ancilla\u2010click pattern p_B heralds teleportation onto modes 8\u20139 = B\u2019s rails; another pattern p_C heralds teleportation onto modes 8\u20139 = C\u2019s rails. By injecting the squeezed source on modes 6\u20137, we boost the overall success probability (for either branch) above what is possible with vacuum ancillas alone.\n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-driven teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_router_teleport\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],         # dual-rail input qubit\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\":[2,3]},                # AB Bell\n    {\"modes\":[4,5]},                # AC Bell\n    {\"modes\":[6,7]}                 # BC squeezed reservoir\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [          # forbid direct bypass\n    [0,2],[0,3],[0,4],[0,5]\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"out_nodes\": [8,9],               # rails for teleported qubit (B or C)\n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_teleport\": {              # abstract specification of two heralding patterns\n    \"route_B\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,0,0], \"output\":\"out_nodes=B\"},\n    \"route_C\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,1,1], \"output\":\"out_nodes=C\"}\n  }\n}\n\nThis target tells Pytheus to find the minimal beam\u2010splitter/phase\u2010shift network and source amplitudes that realize a heralded teleportation switch, powered by a squeezed reservoir, routing A\u2019s qubit to B or C with enhanced success. The concept generalizes immediately to N branches and more complex network\u2010thermodynamic protocols.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This \u201csqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013driven teleportation router\u201d is simply the same Gaussian\u2010ancilla trick you\u2019ve already applied for Bell analyzers, SWAP gates, cluster fusion, and entanglement percolation\u2014now repackaged as a teleportation switch. Moreover, the ensemble has already proposed a \u201cDual\u2010Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip,\u201d so your new twist of adding squeezers to boost success probability does not constitute a fundamentally new measurement primitive, resource usage, or network topology.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To achieve PRL\u2010level novelty you must propose a genuinely new non-Gaussian joint measurement, an indefinite causal\u2010order routing primitive, or a network transformation that cannot be reduced to passive optics plus two\u2010mode squeezing. Simply boosting a known teleportation switch with squeezers is not sufficient.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir-driven teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe design a single static linear-optics network that teleports an unknown dual-rail photonic qubit at site A into one of two output sites, B or C, powered by a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla acting as a thermodynamic work reservoir. Depending on which pattern of ancilla detectors clicks at B\u2013C, the qubit is routed (teleported) to B\u2019s or C\u2019s output rails. Injecting squeezing into the reservoir pair (BC) raises the overall heralded success probability above what is achievable with vacuum ancillas.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters / pair\u2010sources:\n   \u2013 Single\u2010photon dual\u2010rail qubit at A: modes (0,1) via single_emitters  \n   \u2013 Bell\u2010pair AB \u2192 modes (2,3)  \n   \u2013 Bell\u2010pair AC \u2192 modes (4,5)  \n   \u2013 Squeezed-vacuum BC \u2192 modes (6,7)  \n       \u2193  \n linear-optics interferometer: beam splitters & phase shifters mixing modes 0\u20137  \n       \u2193  \n detectors:\n   \u2013 Ancilla detectors on modes 2,3,4,5,6,7 record click patterns  \n   \u2013 Out_nodes: a pair of rails at either B or C (modes 8,9) carry the teleported qubit  \n\nHeralding:\n  \u2013 Click pattern p_B on ancillas heralds teleportation to B: output rails (8,9) = B.  \n  \u2013 Click pattern p_C heralds teleportation to C: output rails (8,9) = C.  \n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-driven teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_router_teleport\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\":[2,3]},    # AB Bell\n    {\"modes\":[4,5]},    # AC Bell\n    {\"modes\":[6,7]}     # BC squeezed reservoir\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [ [0,2],[0,3],[0,4],[0,5] ], \n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"out_nodes\": [8,9],\n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_teleport\": {\n    \"route_B\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,0,0], \"output\":\"out_nodes=B\"},\n    \"route_C\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,1,1], \"output\":\"out_nodes=C\"}\n  }\n}\n\nThis proposal invites Pytheus to find the minimal beam\u2010splitter/phase\u2010shift network and source amplitudes that realize a **heralded teleportation switch**, boosted by a squeezed reservoir. The concept generalizes to N\u2010branch quantum routing and a wide class of thermodynamically\u2010powered network transformations.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially a trivial extension of the already\u2010proposed dual\u2010destination teleportation switch (see \u201cDual\u2010Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\u201d) by tacking on a two\u2010mode squeezed ancilla to boost success rates. The squeezed ancilla acts as a thermodynamic \u201cwork reservoir,\u201d boosting the post\u2010selected success probability of this three\u2010node gate above what is possible with vacuum ancillas alone. This cyclic swap is a genuinely new multi\u2010node transformation\u2014neither pairwise swapping nor teleportation\u2014and directly generalizes to N\u2010cycle quantum\u2010thermodynamic engine cycles.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters/sources:\n   \u2013 single_emitters: modes [0],[1],[2] \u2192 qubits A,B,C  \n   \u2013 probabilistic_pair_source: modes [3,4] \u2192 two-mode squeezed ancilla  \n       \u2193  \n linear-optics network: beam-splitters & phase-shifters mixing modes 0\u20134  \n       \u2193  \n detectors:\n   \u2013 ancilla detectors: modes [3,4] (number-resolving)  \n   \u2013 out_nodes: modes [0,1,2] carry the permuted qubit states  \n\nHerald condition:\nExactly one photon in each of modes 3 and 4. Conditioned on that, the mapping on the system qubits is\n\u2003|a\u27e9\u2080\u2009|b\u27e9\u2081\u2009|c\u27e9\u2082 \u2192 |b\u27e9\u2080\u2009|c\u27e9\u2081\u2009|a\u27e9\u2082  \nfor all a,b,c\u2208{0,1}.\n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Heralded cyclic\u2013SWAP of three single-rail qubits powered by a squeezed reservoir\",\n  \"foldername\": \"cyclic_swap_squeezed\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1,2],\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\": [3,4]}\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [  # prevent bypass of system\u2192ancilla mixing\n    [0,3],[1,3],[2,4]\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"anc_detectors\": [3,4],\n  \"out_nodes\": [0,1,2],\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_quantum\": [\n    \"000\",  # |000>\u2192|000>\n    \"100\",  # |100>\u2192|010>\n    \"010\",  # |010>\u2192|001>\n    \"001\",  # |001>\u2192|100>\n    \"110\",  # |110>\u2192|011>\n    \"011\",  # |011>\u2192|101>\n    \"101\",  # |101>\u2192|110>\n    \"111\"   # |111>\u2192|111>\n  ]\n}\n\nThe Expert can hand this target to Pytheus to discover the minimal beam-splitter/phase-shift network and source amplitudes that realize the cyclic\u2010SWAP gate\u2014a novel multi\u2010node quantum\u2010thermodynamic primitive powered by a squeezed reservoir.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: This proposal targets exactly the three\u2010qubit cyclic SWAP unitary U_cycle: |a,b,c\u27e9\u2192|b,c,a\u27e9\u2014the same transformation already put forward in the ensemble suggestion \u201cMeasurement-Induced Photonic Realization of the Three-Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring-Exchange.\u201d Merely tacking on a two-mode squeezed ancilla to boost the heralded success probability is the same Gaussian-ancilla trick repeatedly used above and does not introduce a fundamentally new measurement primitive or non-Gaussian resource. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"quantum thermodynamics\" and \"squeezed reservoir\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus-compatible ways to fuse \u201cquantum thermodynamics\u201d and a \u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d into a network/transformation (no forbidden state generation):\n  1) Unambiguous d-dimensional Bell measurement aided by a two-mode squeezed ancilla.\n  2) Thermodynamic entanglement router: a three-node network whose entanglement path (A\u2192B vs. A\u2192C) is biased by injecting squeezing at the central node.\n  3) Squeezed-reservoir\u2013assisted photonic \u201cfusion\u201d gate for cluster percolation: boost the success of Type-I/II fusion operations by consuming a two-mode squeezed ancilla as a thermodynamic resource.\n\nStep 2: Check novelty and Pytheus barriers:\n  1) Higher-dimensional squeezed Bell analyzers are little explored, but conceptually similar to known Zaidi\u2009&\u2009van Loock schemes.\n  2) Entanglement routing is intriguing but nebulous to encode as a concrete target in Pytheus.\n  3) Fusion gates appear widely in linear-optics cluster proposals, yet no one has leveraged a squeezed ancilla to exceed their success bound\u2014and Pytheus can optimize exactly that: a linear-optics fusion network with probabilistic pair sources and detectors.\n\nStep 3: Select idea (3).\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because:\n   \u2022 It treats a two-mode squeezed vacuum as a thermodynamic \u201cwork reservoir\u201d consumed by a photonic fusion measurement, a perspective absent from the photonic-cluster/fusion literature.\n   \u2022 It generalizes easily to larger percolation networks: each fusion link can be turbo-charged by a squeezed-reservoir ancilla.\n\nStep 5: This is feasible in Pytheus:\n   \u2022 Uses only single-photon inputs for the two qubits to be fused, two probabilistic pair sources modeling the squeezed reservoir, a linear-optics interferometer, and post-selected photon-number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n   \u2022 No dynamic feedback, no forbidden state preparation.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir\u2013assisted photonic fusion gate for cluster percolation\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to implement a linear-optics fusion operation on two unknown photonic qubits (modes 0,1)\u2014the primitive that \u201cfuses\u201d two cluster-state fragments\u2014by injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla (modes 2,3) that acts as a nonclassical thermodynamic reservoir. In standard linear optics the Type-I fusion succeeds only 50\u2009% of the time; here the squeezing supplies \u201cwork\u201d to boost the heralded success probability above that bound. All six modes are mixed in an interferometer and then measured:\n\nVisualization:\n   single_emitters: [mode 0], [mode 1]         # the two qubits to fuse  \n   squeezed_sources: pair \u2192 [mode 2, mode 3]  # two-mode squeezed ancilla  \n       \u2193  \n   linear-optics network: beam splitters & phases mixing modes 0\u20133  \n       \u2193  \n   detectors:  \n     \u2013 Out fused qubit(s): detectors 0 & 1  \n     \u2013 Ancilla detectors: detectors 2 & 3  \n\nHeralding rule:\nPost-select on specific photon-number patterns in detectors 2 & 3 (e.g. one photon each) that flag a successful fusion; the two remaining output modes realize the fused cluster edge.\n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-assisted photonic fusion gate\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_fusion_gate\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"num_anc\": 2,\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[1,3]],  # forbid direct emitter\u2192ancilla bypass\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"samples\": 10,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_quantum\": [\n    # detection patterns (ancilla modes 2,3 each have 1 photon; outputs show fused parity)\n    \"1100\",  # example: |+\u27e9 fusion outcome\n    \"0011\"   # example: |\u2212\u27e9 fusion outcome\n  ]\n}\n\nThis target invites Pytheus to find the minimal beam-splitter/phase-shift network and pair-source amplitudes that maximize heralded fusion success\u2014demonstrating how a squeezed reservoir (thermodynamic work) enhances cluster-state percolation without any forbidden state generation or feedback.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To reach PRL-level novelty, propose a measurement or resource that can\u2019t be reduced to passive optics plus squeezers\u2014e.g. a genuine multi-photon non-Gaussian joint projector, an indefinite-order cluster fusion network, or another qualitatively new primitive beyond Gaussian ancilla enhancement.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: I brainstormed three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to fuse \u201cquantum thermodynamics\u201d and a \u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d into a network transformation (no pure state\u2010generation):\n  1) A squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell analyzer (already well known from Gaussian\u2010ancilla schemes).  \n  2) A two\u2010stage teleportation line powered by squeezing (Pytheus can\u2019t optimize sequential channel fidelities without feedback).  \n  3) A squeezed\u2010reservoir\u2013driven teleportation router: a static 1\u21922 teleportation switch that uses a two\u2010mode squeezed ancilla to bias heralded teleportation into one of two branches.  \n\nStep 2: Checking novelty & feasibility:\n  \u2022 (1) is known (Zaidi\u2009&\u2009van Loock PRL\u2009110).  \n  \u2022 (2) runs into Pytheus\u2019s inability to handle cascaded fidelities or dynamic feed\u2010forward.  \n  \u2022 (3) is new\u2014no previous Pytheus experiment builds a multi\u2010branch teleportation switch powered by a nonclassical reservoir. It uses only probabilistic pair sources (for the two Bell links and the squeezed reservoir), a linear\u2010optics interferometer, photon\u2010number resolving detectors, and post\u2010selection.  \n\nStep 3: I choose (3).\n\nStep 4: Novelty:  \nThis is the first proposal of a static linear\u2010optics \u201cteleportation router\u201d that uses a squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla as a thermodynamic \u201cwork\u201d reservoir. Depending on which pattern of ancilla\u2010detector clicks occurs, the unknown qubit at node A is faithfully teleported either to node B or to node C, with success probability boosted above the vacuum\u2010ancilla limit. This opens up the idea of thermodynamically\u2010powered quantum\u2010network routing, vastly generalizable to N\u2010branch topologies.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:  \n\u2013 Inputs: one dual\u2010rail single\u2010photon qubit at A, two Bell\u2010pair sources for (A\u2013B) and (A\u2013C), one probabilistic two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum source for the reservoir (B\u2013C).  \n\u2013 Network: a mesh of beam\u2010splitters and phase\u2010shifters mixing A\u2019s qubit and all four ancilla modes.  \n\u2013 Outputs: two unmeasured \u201cout_nodes\u201d at B and C (the teleported qubit rails) and several ancilla detectors at B\u2013C for post\u2010selection.  \n\u2013 All elements are within Pytheus\u2019s toolbox: probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors, post\u2010selection. No cavities or dynamic feedback.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\nSqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013driven teleportation router\n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a three\u2010site network A\u2192{B,C} that teleports an unknown qubit at A into one of two destinations, B or C, in a single static linear\u2010optics circuit powered by a \u201csqueezed reservoir.\u201d  \n\n  \u2022 Inputs  \n    \u2013 Single\u2010photon dual\u2010rail qubit at A (modes 0,1) via single_emitters  \n    \u2013 Bell\u2010pair source AB (modes 2,3)  \n    \u2013 Bell\u2010pair source AC (modes 4,5)  \n    \u2013 Two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum (reservoir) source BC (modes 6,7)  \n\n  \u2022 Linear\u2010optics interferometer  \n    \u2013 Mix all eight modes with beam\u2010splitters and phase\u2010shifters  \n\n  \u2022 Detectors  \n    \u2013 Ancilla detectors on modes {2,3,4,5,6,7} record a fixed \u201cclick pattern.\u201d  \n    \u2013 Out_nodes: modes {8,9} carry the teleported qubit to B or C (unmeasured during optimization).  \n\nHeralding rule:\nA particular ancilla\u2010click pattern p_B heralds teleportation onto modes 8\u20139 = B\u2019s rails; another pattern p_C heralds teleportation onto modes 8\u20139 = C\u2019s rails. By injecting the squeezed source on modes 6\u20137, we boost the overall success probability (for either branch) above what is possible with vacuum ancillas alone.\n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-driven teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_router_teleport\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],         # dual-rail input qubit\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\":[2,3]},                # AB Bell\n    {\"modes\":[4,5]},                # AC Bell\n    {\"modes\":[6,7]}                 # BC squeezed reservoir\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [          # forbid direct bypass\n    [0,2],[0,3],[0,4],[0,5]\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"out_nodes\": [8,9],               # rails for teleported qubit (B or C)\n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_teleport\": {              # abstract specification of two heralding patterns\n    \"route_B\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,0,0], \"output\":\"out_nodes=B\"},\n    \"route_C\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,1,1], \"output\":\"out_nodes=C\"}\n  }\n}\n\nThis target tells Pytheus to find the minimal beam\u2010splitter/phase\u2010shift network and source amplitudes that realize a heralded teleportation switch, powered by a squeezed reservoir, routing A\u2019s qubit to B or C with enhanced success. The concept generalizes immediately to N branches and more complex network\u2010thermodynamic protocols.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To achieve PRL\u2010level novelty you must propose a genuinely new non-Gaussian joint measurement, an indefinite causal\u2010order routing primitive, or a network transformation that cannot be reduced to passive optics plus two\u2010mode squeezing. Simply boosting a known teleportation switch with squeezers is not sufficient.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to fuse \u201cquantum thermodynamics\u201d (a work or heat reservoir) with a \u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d into a network/transformation rather than pure\u2010state generation:\n    1) Squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell analyzer (well known in Gaussian\u2010ancilla literature).\n    2) Two\u2010stage teleportation line boosted by squeezing (requires sequential channel fidelity metrics and/or feedback\u2014Pytheus can\u2019t handle).\n    3) A static \u201cteleportation router\u201d A\u2192{B,C}: a single linear\u2010optics circuit that, powered by a two\u2010mode squeezed ancilla (the reservoir), probabilistically routes an input qubit at A to either B or C depending on which heralding clicks occur. The squeezing boosts success probability over vacuum ancilla.\n  Step 2: Check novelty & feasibility:\n    \u2022 (1) is already in the literature (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL\u2009110).  \n    \u2022 (2) runs into Pytheus\u2019s limitations on cascaded channels and dynamic feedback.  \n    \u2022 (3) no previous Pytheus\u2010designed experiment builds a multi\u2010output teleportation switch powered by a nonclassical reservoir. It uses only probabilistic pair sources (for AB\u2010Bell, AC\u2010Bell, BC\u2010squeezed ancilla), linear optics, photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors and post\u2010selection.\n  Step 3: Pick idea (3).\n  Step 4: Novelty:  \n    It is the first proposal of a **static** linear\u2010optics \u201cteleportation router\u201d that uses a two\u2010mode squeezed vacuum as a thermodynamic \u201cwork reservoir.\u201d Depending on which ancilla\u2010click pattern occurs, the unknown qubit at node A is teleported to either node B or C. The squeezed reservoir raises the overall success probability above the passive\u2010vacuum bound. This opens up \u201cthermodynamically\u2010powered routing\u201d in quantum networks and generalizes to N\u2010branch switches.\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n    \u2013 Inputs: one dual-rail single-photon qubit at A, two Bell\u2010pair sources (AB and AC), one two-mode squeezed\u2010vacuum source (BC).  \n    \u2013 Static linear\u2010optics interferometer mixing all modes.  \n    \u2013 Photon-number-resolving detectors on the six ancilla modes at B\u2013C to post-select the teleportation branch; the two output rails at either B or C are left unmeasured (\u201cout_nodes\u201d).  \n    \u2013 All elements\u2014probabilistic pair sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, number\u2010resolving detectors, post-selection\u2014are within Pytheus\u2019s toolbox. No cavities, no dynamic feed\u2010forward, no forbidden state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir-driven teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe design a single static linear-optics network that teleports an unknown dual-rail photonic qubit at site A into one of two output sites, B or C, powered by a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla acting as a thermodynamic work reservoir. Depending on which pattern of ancilla detectors clicks at B\u2013C, the qubit is routed (teleported) to B\u2019s or C\u2019s output rails. Injecting squeezing into the reservoir pair (BC) raises the overall heralded success probability above what is achievable with vacuum ancillas.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters / pair\u2010sources:\n   \u2013 Single\u2010photon dual\u2010rail qubit at A: modes (0,1) via single_emitters  \n   \u2013 Bell\u2010pair AB \u2192 modes (2,3)  \n   \u2013 Bell\u2010pair AC \u2192 modes (4,5)  \n   \u2013 Squeezed-vacuum BC \u2192 modes (6,7)  \n       \u2193  \n linear-optics interferometer: beam splitters & phase shifters mixing modes 0\u20137  \n       \u2193  \n detectors:\n   \u2013 Ancilla detectors on modes 2,3,4,5,6,7 record click patterns  \n   \u2013 Out_nodes: a pair of rails at either B or C (modes 8,9) carry the teleported qubit  \n\nHeralding:\n  \u2013 Click pattern p_B on ancillas heralds teleportation to B: output rails (8,9) = B.  \n  \u2013 Click pattern p_C heralds teleportation to C: output rails (8,9) = C.  \n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-driven teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_router_teleport\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\":[2,3]},    # AB Bell\n    {\"modes\":[4,5]},    # AC Bell\n    {\"modes\":[6,7]}     # BC squeezed reservoir\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [ [0,2],[0,3],[0,4],[0,5] ], \n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"out_nodes\": [8,9],\n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_teleport\": {\n    \"route_B\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,0,0], \"output\":\"out_nodes=B\"},\n    \"route_C\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,1,1], \"output\":\"out_nodes=C\"}\n  }\n}\n\nThis proposal invites Pytheus to find the minimal beam\u2010splitter/phase\u2010shift network and source amplitudes that realize a **heralded teleportation switch**, boosted by a squeezed reservoir. The concept generalizes to N\u2010branch quantum routing and a wide class of thermodynamically\u2010powered network transformations.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your \u201csqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013driven teleportation router\u201d adds no fundamentally new network or non\u2010Gaussian measurement beyond the dual\u2010destination switch already in the ensemble and standard squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell enhancements. It uses only probabilistic pair sources, single\u2010photon emitters, linear optics, number\u2010resolving detectors, and post\u2010selection.  \n  Step 3: Pick idea (3).  \n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    It is the first proposal of a **heralded cyclic\u2010SWAP** on three unknown photonic qubits A, B, C\u2014 a network transformation beyond pairwise entanglement\u2010swapping or teleportation\u2014**powered by a squeezed reservoir**. The cyclic swap (A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A) embodies a primitive \u201cwork cycle\u201d in quantum\u2010thermodynamic language, showing how a nonclassical bath (squeezing) catalyzes a nontrivial multi\u2010node unitary with higher success probability.  \n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n    \u2013 System inputs: three single\u2010rail qubits at modes 0,1,2 via single_emitters.  \n    \u2013 Reservoir input: a two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla at modes 3,4 via one probabilistic pair\u2010source.  \n    \u2013 Static linear\u2010optics interferometer mixing modes 0\u20134.  \n    \u2013 Photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors on modes 3,4 (ancilla) to herald the cyclic\u2010swap event; the post\u2010selected outputs on modes 0,1,2 carry the permuted qubit states.  \n    \u2013 No forbidden state generation, no feedback, only allowed elements.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nHeralded cyclic\u2013SWAP of three qubits assisted by a squeezed reservoir\n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a static linear\u2010optics network that, on heralding from a two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla (modes 3\u20134), effects the unitary permutation A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A on three unknown single\u2010rail qubits at A, B, C (modes 0\u20132). The squeezed ancilla acts as a thermodynamic \u201cwork reservoir,\u201d boosting the post\u2010selected success probability of this three\u2010node gate above what is possible with vacuum ancillas alone. This cyclic swap is a genuinely new multi\u2010node transformation\u2014neither pairwise swapping nor teleportation\u2014and directly generalizes to N\u2010cycle quantum\u2010thermodynamic engine cycles.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters/sources:\n   \u2013 single_emitters: modes [0],[1],[2] \u2192 qubits A,B,C  \n   \u2013 probabilistic_pair_source: modes [3,4] \u2192 two-mode squeezed ancilla  \n       \u2193  \n linear-optics network: beam-splitters & phase-shifters mixing modes 0\u20134  \n       \u2193  \n detectors:\n   \u2013 ancilla detectors: modes [3,4] (number-resolving)  \n   \u2013 out_nodes: modes [0,1,2] carry the permuted qubit states  \n\nHerald condition:\nExactly one photon in each of modes 3 and 4. Conditioned on that, the mapping on the system qubits is\n\u2003|a\u27e9\u2080\u2009|b\u27e9\u2081\u2009|c\u27e9\u2082 \u2192 |b\u27e9\u2080\u2009|c\u27e9\u2081\u2009|a\u27e9\u2082  \nfor all a,b,c\u2208{0,1}.\n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Heralded cyclic\u2013SWAP of three single-rail qubits powered by a squeezed reservoir\",\n  \"foldername\": \"cyclic_swap_squeezed\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1,2],\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\": [3,4]}\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [  # prevent bypass of system\u2192ancilla mixing\n    [0,3],[1,3],[2,4]\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"anc_detectors\": [3,4],\n  \"out_nodes\": [0,1,2],\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_quantum\": [\n    \"000\",  # |000>\u2192|000>\n    \"100\",  # |100>\u2192|010>\n    \"010\",  # |010>\u2192|001>\n    \"001\",  # |001>\u2192|100>\n    \"110\",  # |110>\u2192|011>\n    \"011\",  # |011>\u2192|101>\n    \"101\",  # |101>\u2192|110>\n    \"111\"   # |111>\u2192|111>\n  ]\n}\n\nThe Expert can hand this target to Pytheus to discover the minimal beam-splitter/phase-shift network and source amplitudes that realize the cyclic\u2010SWAP gate\u2014a novel multi\u2010node quantum\u2010thermodynamic primitive powered by a squeezed reservoir.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your \u201csqueezed-reservoir\u2013assisted cyclic-SWAP\u201d duplicates the ensemble\u2019s cyclic SWAP ring-exchange target and only adds a standard squeezed-vacuum ancilla to raise success rates.     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to combine \u201cquantum thermodynamics\u201d with a \u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d in a network/transformation (no pure\u2010state generation):\n    1) A squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell analyser (well known, e.g. Zaidi\u2009&\u2009van Loock PRL\u2009110).  \n    2) A squeezed\u2010powered teleportation router A\u2192{B,C} (adds no new primitive beyond known Bell-plus-switch networks).  \n    3) Squeezed-reservoir-assisted entanglement purification: use two noisy Bell-pair sources plus a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla to herald the distillation of a higher-fidelity Bell pair.  \n  Step 2: Check novelty & feasibility:\n    \u2022 (1) and (2) are either standard or require sequential metrics/feedback.  \n    \u2022 (3) has not been done in Pytheus: it is a genuine network transformation (purification), it uses only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, number\u2010resolving detectors, and post\u2010selection.  \n  Step 3: Select idea (3).  \n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    This is the first proposal to treat a two\u2010mode squeezed vacuum as a thermodynamic reservoir that reduces entropy in an entanglement\u2010purification network. Unlike pure\u2010state generation, it is a transformation that consumes a squeezed reservoir to distill entanglement.  \n  Step 5: Feasibility:\n    Uses only two noisy Bell pair sources (AB, CD), one squeezed-vacuum pair (reservoir), beam splitters, phase shifters, photon-number\u2010resolving detectors, and post-selection. No forbidden state generation or dynamic feedback.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cSqueezed\u2010reservoir-assisted entanglement purification of two Bell pairs\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe provide two noisy Bell pairs AB (modes 0\u20131) and CD (modes 2\u20133) via probabilistic pair sources, plus a two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla (modes 4\u20135) modeling a nonclassical thermodynamic reservoir. All six modes are mixed in a static linear-optics interferometer (beam splitters + phase shifters). We place photon-number-resolving detectors on modes 1,2,4,5 and leave modes 0,3 unmeasured (\u201cout_nodes\u201d). By post-selecting the click pattern \u201cexactly one photon in each ancilla/system detector,\u201d the remaining modes 0 and 3 collapse into a purified Bell pair with higher fidelity. The squeezing reduces entropy, acting as \u201cwork,\u201d and enhances distillation success above the vacuum-ancilla bound.\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources \u2192 Interferometer \u2192 Detectors\n   \u2022 Pair source AB \u2192 modes 0,1  \n   \u2022 Pair source CD \u2192 modes 2,3  \n   \u2022 Squeezed-vacuum reservoir \u2192 modes 4,5  \n   \u2193  \n   \u2022 Beam splitters & phase shifters mix modes 0\u20135  \n   \u2193  \n   \u2022 Detectors on modes 1,2,4,5 (number-resolving)  \n   \u2022 Out_nodes: modes 0,3 carry purified Bell pair  \n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-assisted entanglement purification of two Bell pairs\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_entang_purif\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\": [0,1]},   # noisy AB Bell\n    {\"modes\": [2,3]},   # noisy CD Bell\n    {\"modes\": [4,5]}    # squeezed-vacuum reservoir\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]],  # forbid direct cross-pair sources\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"anc_detectors\": [1,2,4,5],\n  \"out_nodes\": [0,3],\n  \"samples\": 10,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"111111\"]  # one photon in each of the 6 modes; with out_nodes left unmeasured, this heralds purification\n}"
}

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. A specific three-click herald pattern routes the remaining photons in the cyclic order, directly mimicking the ring-exchange term of the triangular Heisenberg spin-liquid without generating any static entangled state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid-Frequency Triangle-Network Nonlocality Test with Photonic-Resonator Joint Measurements\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a self-contained three-party triangle nonlocality experiment in which two optical and one THz probabilistic Bell-pair sources feed three nodes arranged in a loop, with node B employing a small photonic-resonator interferometer to mix optical and THz modes for heralded two-outcome joint measurements. Conditioned on four ancilla heralding clicks, the qubit returns to its original spatial mode with a relative phase shift exactly equal to the target Zak phase of the SSH band, which is then read out by a simple two-mode interferometer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. Heralded two-photon click patterns in even or odd detector pairs directly project the data qubits onto the \u00b11 eigenstates of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084, realizing a direct stabilizer measurement without any feed-forward or dynamic control.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir\u2013assisted Bell-state analyzer\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to design a four-mode Bell measurement on two unknown photonic qubits (modes 0 and 1) that, in standard linear optics, succeeds only 50\u2009% of the time. By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 2\u20133), realized abstractly by two probabilistic photon-pair sources, and then routing all four photons through a linear-optics interferometer plus post-selected detection, we aim to unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states on modes 0\u20131. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2. The Expert can use Pytheus to optimize the linear\u2010optics network and ancilla connections to realize this squeezed-reservoir\u2010assisted Bell measurement.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The goal\u2014to surpass the 50 % Bell\u2010measurement limit using a two\u2010mode squeezed ancilla\u2014is already realized in the literature (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock, PRL 110, 260501 (2013) and follow\u2010ups using squeezers to boost linear\u2010optics Bell analyses). As stated, this is essentially the known approach of injecting squeezed\u2010vacuum resources to raise success probabilities beyond the passive\u2010optics bound. By mixing all four modes in a network of beam splitters and phase shifters and then performing photon-number-resolving detection on the ancilla outputs, we herald events in which the remaining two output modes carry the swapped qubit state |a\u27e9_A\u2009|b\u27e9_B \u2192 |b\u27e9_A\u2009|a\u27e9_B. We place photon-number-resolving detectors on modes 1,2,4,5 and leave modes 0,3 unmeasured (\u201cout_nodes\u201d). By post-selecting the click pattern \u201cexactly one photon in each ancilla/system detector,\u201d the remaining modes 0 and 3 collapse into a purified Bell pair with higher fidelity. The squeezing reduces entropy, acting as \u201cwork,\u201d and enhances distillation success above the vacuum-ancilla bound.\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources \u2192 Interferometer \u2192 Detectors\n   \u2022 Pair source AB \u2192 modes 0,1  \n   \u2022 Pair source CD \u2192 modes 2,3  \n   \u2022 Squeezed-vacuum reservoir \u2192 modes 4,5  \n   \u2193  \n   \u2022 Beam splitters & phase shifters mix modes 0\u20135  \n   \u2193  \n   \u2022 Detectors on modes 1,2,4,5 (number-resolving)  \n   \u2022 Out_nodes: modes 0,3 carry purified Bell pair  \n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-assisted entanglement purification of two Bell pairs\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_entang_purif\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\": [0,1]},   # noisy AB Bell\n    {\"modes\": [2,3]},   # noisy CD Bell\n    {\"modes\": [4,5]}    # squeezed-vacuum reservoir\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]],  # forbid direct cross-pair sources\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"anc_detectors\": [1,2,4,5],\n  \"out_nodes\": [0,3],\n  \"samples\": 10,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"111111\"]  # one photon in each of the 6 modes; with out_nodes left unmeasured, this heralds purification\n}\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The \u201csqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013assisted entanglement purification\u201d you propose is essentially a Gaussian\u2010ancilla\u2010boosted version of the one\u2010shot entanglement concentration/purification already in the ensemble (\u201cOne\u2010Shot Swap\u2010and\u2010Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 Bell Pairs\u201d). Merely replacing vacuum ancillas with a two\u2010mode squeezed reservoir to raise success or fidelity does not introduce a new measurement primitive, non\u2010Gaussian joint projector, or network topology. This fails to meet the PRL bar for genuinely novel quantum\u2010optics targets.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your scheme duplicates the static linear\u2010optics, post\u2010selected entanglement purification already proposed and only adds standard two\u2010mode squeezing to marginally boost heralding rates. To be novel, you need a qualitatively new non\u2010Gaussian measurement, an indefinite\u2010order purification primitive, or another transformation that cannot be reduced to passive optics plus a squeezed vacuum reservoir."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. There is no forbidden state\u2010generation demand\u2014the goal is a measurement network (Bell analyzer) enhanced by an ancilla resource.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input: \nDescription:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir\u2013assisted Bell-state analyzer\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to design a four-mode Bell measurement on two unknown photonic qubits (modes 0 and 1) that, in standard linear optics, succeeds only 50\u2009% of the time. By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 2\u20133), realized abstractly by two probabilistic photon-pair sources, and then routing all four photons through a linear-optics interferometer plus post-selected detection, we aim to unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states on modes 0\u20131. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2. The Expert can use Pytheus to optimize the linear\u2010optics network and ancilla connections to realize this squeezed-reservoir\u2010assisted Bell measurement.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your \u201csqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013assisted\u201d Bell analyser replicates published schemes that use two\u2010mode squeezers to exceed the 50 % linear\u2010optics limit (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL 110, 260501 (2013)). It uses only probabilistic pair sources (for the two Bell links and the squeezed reservoir), a linear\u2010optics interferometer, photon\u2010number resolving detectors, and post\u2010selection.  \n\nStep 3: I choose (3).\n\nStep 4: Novelty:  \nThis is the first proposal of a static linear\u2010optics \u201cteleportation router\u201d that uses a squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla as a thermodynamic \u201cwork\u201d reservoir. Depending on which pattern of ancilla\u2010detector clicks occurs, the unknown qubit at node A is faithfully teleported either to node B or to node C, with success probability boosted above the vacuum\u2010ancilla limit. This opens up the idea of thermodynamically\u2010powered quantum\u2010network routing, vastly generalizable to N\u2010branch topologies.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:  \n\u2013 Inputs: one dual\u2010rail single\u2010photon qubit at A, two Bell\u2010pair sources for (A\u2013B) and (A\u2013C), one probabilistic two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum source for the reservoir (B\u2013C).  \n\u2013 Network: a mesh of beam\u2010splitters and phase\u2010shifters mixing A\u2019s qubit and all four ancilla modes.  \n\u2013 Outputs: two unmeasured \u201cout_nodes\u201d at B and C (the teleported qubit rails) and several ancilla detectors at B\u2013C for post\u2010selection.  \n\u2013 All elements are within Pytheus\u2019s toolbox: probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors, post\u2010selection. No cavities or dynamic feedback.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\nSqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013driven teleportation router\n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a three\u2010site network A\u2192{B,C} that teleports an unknown qubit at A into one of two destinations, B or C, in a single static linear\u2010optics circuit powered by a \u201csqueezed reservoir.\u201d  \n\n  \u2022 Inputs  \n    \u2013 Single\u2010photon dual\u2010rail qubit at A (modes 0,1) via single_emitters  \n    \u2013 Bell\u2010pair source AB (modes 2,3)  \n    \u2013 Bell\u2010pair source AC (modes 4,5)  \n    \u2013 Two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum (reservoir) source BC (modes 6,7)  \n\n  \u2022 Linear\u2010optics interferometer  \n    \u2013 Mix all eight modes with beam\u2010splitters and phase\u2010shifters  \n\n  \u2022 Detectors  \n    \u2013 Ancilla detectors on modes {2,3,4,5,6,7} record a fixed \u201cclick pattern.\u201d  \n    \u2013 Out_nodes: modes {8,9} carry the teleported qubit to B or C (unmeasured during optimization).  \n\nHeralding rule:\nA particular ancilla\u2010click pattern p_B heralds teleportation onto modes 8\u20139 = B\u2019s rails; another pattern p_C heralds teleportation onto modes 8\u20139 = C\u2019s rails. By injecting the squeezed source on modes 6\u20137, we boost the overall success probability (for either branch) above what is possible with vacuum ancillas alone.\n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-driven teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_router_teleport\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],         # dual-rail input qubit\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\":[2,3]},                # AB Bell\n    {\"modes\":[4,5]},                # AC Bell\n    {\"modes\":[6,7]}                 # BC squeezed reservoir\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [          # forbid direct bypass\n    [0,2],[0,3],[0,4],[0,5]\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"out_nodes\": [8,9],               # rails for teleported qubit (B or C)\n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_teleport\": {              # abstract specification of two heralding patterns\n    \"route_B\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,0,0], \"output\":\"out_nodes=B\"},\n    \"route_C\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,1,1], \"output\":\"out_nodes=C\"}\n  }\n}\n\nThis target tells Pytheus to find the minimal beam\u2010splitter/phase\u2010shift network and source amplitudes that realize a heralded teleportation switch, powered by a squeezed reservoir, routing A\u2019s qubit to B or C with enhanced success. The concept generalizes immediately to N branches and more complex network\u2010thermodynamic protocols.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To achieve PRL\u2010level novelty you must propose a genuinely new non-Gaussian joint measurement, an indefinite causal\u2010order routing primitive, or a network transformation that cannot be reduced to passive optics plus two\u2010mode squeezing. Simply boosting a known teleportation switch with squeezers is not sufficient.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to fuse \u201cquantum thermodynamics\u201d (a work or heat reservoir) with a \u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d into a network/transformation rather than pure\u2010state generation:\n    1) Squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell analyzer (well known in Gaussian\u2010ancilla literature).\n    2) Two\u2010stage teleportation line boosted by squeezing (requires sequential channel fidelity metrics and/or feedback\u2014Pytheus can\u2019t handle).\n    3) A static \u201cteleportation router\u201d A\u2192{B,C}: a single linear\u2010optics circuit that, powered by a two\u2010mode squeezed ancilla (the reservoir), probabilistically routes an input qubit at A to either B or C depending on which heralding clicks occur. The squeezing boosts success probability over vacuum ancilla.\n  Step 2: Check novelty & feasibility:\n    \u2022 (1) is already in the literature (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL\u2009110).  \n    \u2022 (2) runs into Pytheus\u2019s limitations on cascaded channels and dynamic feedback.  \n    \u2022 (3) no previous Pytheus\u2010designed experiment builds a multi\u2010output teleportation switch powered by a nonclassical reservoir. It uses only probabilistic pair sources (for AB\u2010Bell, AC\u2010Bell, BC\u2010squeezed ancilla), linear optics, photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors and post\u2010selection.\n  Step 3: Pick idea (3).\n  Step 4: Novelty:  \n    It is the first proposal of a **static** linear\u2010optics \u201cteleportation router\u201d that uses a two\u2010mode squeezed vacuum as a thermodynamic \u201cwork reservoir.\u201d Depending on which ancilla\u2010click pattern occurs, the unknown qubit at node A is teleported to either node B or C. The squeezed reservoir raises the overall success probability above the passive\u2010vacuum bound. This opens up \u201cthermodynamically\u2010powered routing\u201d in quantum networks and generalizes to N\u2010branch switches.\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n    \u2013 Inputs: one dual-rail single-photon qubit at A, two Bell\u2010pair sources (AB and AC), one two-mode squeezed\u2010vacuum source (BC).  \n    \u2013 Static linear\u2010optics interferometer mixing all modes.  \n    \u2013 Photon-number-resolving detectors on the six ancilla modes at B\u2013C to post-select the teleportation branch; the two output rails at either B or C are left unmeasured (\u201cout_nodes\u201d).  \n    \u2013 All elements\u2014probabilistic pair sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, number\u2010resolving detectors, post-selection\u2014are within Pytheus\u2019s toolbox. No cavities, no dynamic feed\u2010forward, no forbidden state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir-driven teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe design a single static linear-optics network that teleports an unknown dual-rail photonic qubit at site A into one of two output sites, B or C, powered by a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla acting as a thermodynamic work reservoir. Depending on which pattern of ancilla detectors clicks at B\u2013C, the qubit is routed (teleported) to B\u2019s or C\u2019s output rails. Injecting squeezing into the reservoir pair (BC) raises the overall heralded success probability above what is achievable with vacuum ancillas.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters / pair\u2010sources:\n   \u2013 Single\u2010photon dual\u2010rail qubit at A: modes (0,1) via single_emitters  \n   \u2013 Bell\u2010pair AB \u2192 modes (2,3)  \n   \u2013 Bell\u2010pair AC \u2192 modes (4,5)  \n   \u2013 Squeezed-vacuum BC \u2192 modes (6,7)  \n       \u2193  \n linear-optics interferometer: beam splitters & phase shifters mixing modes 0\u20137  \n       \u2193  \n detectors:\n   \u2013 Ancilla detectors on modes 2,3,4,5,6,7 record click patterns  \n   \u2013 Out_nodes: a pair of rails at either B or C (modes 8,9) carry the teleported qubit  \n\nHeralding:\n  \u2013 Click pattern p_B on ancillas heralds teleportation to B: output rails (8,9) = B.  \n  \u2013 Click pattern p_C heralds teleportation to C: output rails (8,9) = C.  \n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-driven teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_router_teleport\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\":[2,3]},    # AB Bell\n    {\"modes\":[4,5]},    # AC Bell\n    {\"modes\":[6,7]}     # BC squeezed reservoir\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [ [0,2],[0,3],[0,4],[0,5] ], \n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"out_nodes\": [8,9],\n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_teleport\": {\n    \"route_B\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,0,0], \"output\":\"out_nodes=B\"},\n    \"route_C\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,1,1], \"output\":\"out_nodes=C\"}\n  }\n}\n\nThis proposal invites Pytheus to find the minimal beam\u2010splitter/phase\u2010shift network and source amplitudes that realize a **heralded teleportation switch**, boosted by a squeezed reservoir. The cyclic swap (A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A) embodies a primitive \u201cwork cycle\u201d in quantum\u2010thermodynamic language, showing how a nonclassical bath (squeezing) catalyzes a nontrivial multi\u2010node unitary with higher success probability.  \n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n    \u2013 System inputs: three single\u2010rail qubits at modes 0,1,2 via single_emitters.  \n    \u2013 Reservoir input: a two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla at modes 3,4 via one probabilistic pair\u2010source.  \n    \u2013 Static linear\u2010optics interferometer mixing modes 0\u20134.  \n    \u2013 Photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors on modes 3,4 (ancilla) to herald the cyclic\u2010swap event; the post\u2010selected outputs on modes 0,1,2 carry the permuted qubit states.  \n    \u2013 No forbidden state generation, no feedback, only allowed elements.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nHeralded cyclic\u2013SWAP of three qubits assisted by a squeezed reservoir\n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a static linear\u2010optics network that, on heralding from a two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla (modes 3\u20134), effects the unitary permutation A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A on three unknown single\u2010rail qubits at A, B, C (modes 0\u20132). The squeezed ancilla acts as a thermodynamic \u201cwork reservoir,\u201d boosting the post\u2010selected success probability of this three\u2010node gate above what is possible with vacuum ancillas alone. This cyclic swap is a genuinely new multi\u2010node transformation\u2014neither pairwise swapping nor teleportation\u2014and directly generalizes to N\u2010cycle quantum\u2010thermodynamic engine cycles.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters/sources:\n   \u2013 single_emitters: modes [0],[1],[2] \u2192 qubits A,B,C  \n   \u2013 probabilistic_pair_source: modes [3,4] \u2192 two-mode squeezed ancilla  \n       \u2193  \n linear-optics network: beam-splitters & phase-shifters mixing modes 0\u20134  \n       \u2193  \n detectors:\n   \u2013 ancilla detectors: modes [3,4] (number-resolving)  \n   \u2013 out_nodes: modes [0,1,2] carry the permuted qubit states  \n\nHerald condition:\nExactly one photon in each of modes 3 and 4. Unlike pure\u2010state generation, it is a transformation that consumes a squeezed reservoir to distill entanglement.  \n  Step 5: Feasibility:\n    Uses only two noisy Bell pair sources (AB, CD), one squeezed-vacuum pair (reservoir), beam splitters, phase shifters, photon-number\u2010resolving detectors, and post-selection. No forbidden state generation or dynamic feedback.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cSqueezed\u2010reservoir-assisted entanglement purification of two Bell pairs\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe provide two noisy Bell pairs AB (modes 0\u20131) and CD (modes 2\u20133) via probabilistic pair sources, plus a two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla (modes 4\u20135) modeling a nonclassical thermodynamic reservoir. All six modes are mixed in a static linear-optics interferometer (beam splitters + phase shifters). We place photon-number-resolving detectors on modes 1,2,4,5 and leave modes 0,3 unmeasured (\u201cout_nodes\u201d). By post-selecting the click pattern \u201cexactly one photon in each ancilla/system detector,\u201d the remaining modes 0 and 3 collapse into a purified Bell pair with higher fidelity. The squeezing reduces entropy, acting as \u201cwork,\u201d and enhances distillation success above the vacuum-ancilla bound.\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources \u2192 Interferometer \u2192 Detectors\n   \u2022 Pair source AB \u2192 modes 0,1  \n   \u2022 Pair source CD \u2192 modes 2,3  \n   \u2022 Squeezed-vacuum reservoir \u2192 modes 4,5  \n   \u2193  \n   \u2022 Beam splitters & phase shifters mix modes 0\u20135  \n   \u2193  \n   \u2022 Detectors on modes 1,2,4,5 (number-resolving)  \n   \u2022 Out_nodes: modes 0,3 carry purified Bell pair  \n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-assisted entanglement purification of two Bell pairs\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_entang_purif\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\": [0,1]},   # noisy AB Bell\n    {\"modes\": [2,3]},   # noisy CD Bell\n    {\"modes\": [4,5]}    # squeezed-vacuum reservoir\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]],  # forbid direct cross-pair sources\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"anc_detectors\": [1,2,4,5],\n  \"out_nodes\": [0,3],\n  \"samples\": 10,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"111111\"]  # one photon in each of the 6 modes; with out_nodes left unmeasured, this heralds purification\n}\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the static linear\u2010optics, post\u2010selected entanglement purification already proposed and only adds standard two\u2010mode squeezing to marginally boost heralding rates.     "output": "Description:\nHeralded squeezed-reservoir\u2013assisted Fredkin gate (controlled-SWAP) \n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a static linear-optics network that implements the three-qubit Fredkin gate \n|c\u27e9\u2080|a\u27e9\u2081|b\u27e9\u2082 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080\u2009|a\u2295(c\u00b7(a\u2295b))\u27e9\u2081\u2009|b\u2295(c\u00b7(a\u2295b))\u27e9\u2082 \n(i.e. if control c=1 swap targets a,b; if c=0 do nothing), by consuming a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla (modes 3,4) which we interpret as a nonclassical thermodynamic \u201cwork reservoir.\u201d Post-selection on one photon in each ancilla detector heralds successful Fredkin action with a probability exceeding the vacuum-ancilla bound.  \n \nThis network is a genuine multi-node transformation (beyond CNOT/Toffoli) and directly ties the free-energy of squeezing to the success of a conditional photonic gate\u2014opening the path to \u201cthermodynamically-powered\u201d quantum-network primitives.  \n\nVisualization:\n\n emitters / sources:  \n   \u2022 single_emitters: modes [0],[1],[2] \u2192 qubits C (control), A, B (targets)  \n   \u2022 probabilistic_pair_source (squeezed reservoir): modes [3,4]  \n\n     \u2193  \n\n linear-optics interferometer (beam splitters & phase shifters mixing modes 0\u20134)\n\n     \u2193  \n\n detectors:  \n   \u2022 ancilla detectors (number-resolving) on modes [3,4]  \n   \u2022 out_nodes: modes [0,1,2] carry the transformed qubits  \n\nHeralding rule:\nDetect exactly one photon in each ancilla detector (modes 3 & 4); conditionally the 3-mode output on [0,1,2] realizes the Fredkin truth table.\n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Heralded Fredkin gate powered by a squeezed reservoir\",\n  \"foldername\": \"Fredkin_squeezed\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1,2],\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\": [3,4]}       # two-mode squeezed ancilla\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [  # forbid direct input\u2192ancilla bypass\n    [0,3],[0,4],[1,3],[1,4],[2,3],[2,4]\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"anc_detectors\": [3,4],\n  \"out_nodes\": [0,1,2],\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_quantum\": [\n    \"00011\",  # input 000\u2192output 000 + ancilla 11\n    \"00111\",  # 001\u2192001\n    \"01011\",  # 010\u2192010\n    \"01111\",  # 011\u2192011\n    \"10011\",  # 100\u2192100 (swap(0,0)=00)\n    \"11011\",  # 101\u2192110\n    \"10111\",  # 110\u2192101\n    \"11111\"   # 111\u2192111 (swap(1,1)=11)\n  ]\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s novel:\n\u2013 Pytheus has CNOT/Toffoli and SWAP but no multi-node Fredkin gate.  \n\u2013 No prior Pytheus experiment uses a squeezed reservoir as the thermodynamic resource to boost success of a nontrivial three-qubit gate.  \n\u2013 This gate is a genuinely new network primitive (controlled-SWAP) that can be extended to multi-control, higher-dimensional generalizations, or cascaded engine-cycle protocols.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s feasible in Pytheus:\n\u2013 Uses only single_photon emitters, one probabilistic pair source (for squeezing), passive linear optics, number-resolving detectors, and heralding (post-selection).  \n\u2013 No dynamic feedback, no forbidden state-generation, no cavities/resonators\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. There is no forbidden state\u2010generation demand\u2014the goal is a measurement network (Bell analyzer) enhanced by an ancilla resource.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input: \nDescription:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir\u2013assisted Bell-state analyzer\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to design a four-mode Bell measurement on two unknown photonic qubits (modes 0 and 1) that, in standard linear optics, succeeds only 50\u2009% of the time. By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 2\u20133), realized abstractly by two probabilistic photon-pair sources, and then routing all four photons through a linear-optics interferometer plus post-selected detection, we aim to unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states on modes 0\u20131. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2.
