By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla (modes 3,4) and a second two-mode squeezed ancilla (modes 5,6)\u2014interpreted as a nonclassical thermodynamic reservoir\u2014and then mixing all seven modes in a network of beam splitters and phase shifters, we post-select on unique 6-click patterns in the ancilla detectors that herald each of the eight GHZ states with boosted success probability.  The squeezed reservoirs supply \u201cwork\u201d (reduced noise) that raises discrimination rates above the vacuum-ancilla bound.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters/sources:\n   \u2013 single_emitters: modes [0], [1], [2] \u2192 unknown qubits A, B, C  \n   \u2013 squeezed-pair source 1 \u2192 modes [3,4]  \n   \u2013 squeezed-pair source 2 \u2192 modes [5,6]  \n       \u2193  \n static interferometer: beam splitters & phase shifters mixing modes 0\u20136  \n       \u2193  \n detectors:\n   \u2013 ancilla detectors on modes [3,4,5,6] record heralding clicks  \n   \u2013 system detectors on modes [0,1,2] for GHZ-basis readout  \n\nHeralding rule:\nEach GHZ basis vector maps, via the optimized network, onto a unique five-or-six-photon click pattern across detectors {3\u20266}, which flags which GHZ state was input.  The Expert need only supply the eight distinct patterns as the \u201ctarget\u201d mapping; Pytheus will find the minimal beam-splitter phases and source amplitudes to realize them.\n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-assisted GHZ-state analyser for three photonic qubits\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_GHZ_analyzer\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1,2],\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\":[3,4]},   # squeezed reservoir ancilla 1\n    {\"modes\":[5,6]}    # squeezed reservoir ancilla 2\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,3],[1,3],[2,5],[1,5]],  # forbid trivial bypasses\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"anc_detectors\": [3,4,5,6],\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_mapping\": {\n    \"GHZ0+\": [1,1,0,0],  # example click pattern in modes 3,4,5,6\n    \"GHZ0-\": [1,0,1,0],\n    \u2026,\n    \"GHZ3-\": [0,1,0,1]\n  }\n}\n\nThis target asks Pytheus to optimize a new multi-party measurement primitive\u2014a GHZ analyser\u2014powered by squeezed reservoirs, opening a family of higher-dimensional and higher-party GHZ analyzers and non-Gaussian network transformations.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This \u201csqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013assisted GHZ\u2010state analyser\u201d is nothing more than the well\u2010known trick of injecting Gaussian squeezed\u2010vacuum ancillas to boost the success probability of a passive\u2010optics measurement\u2014exactly the same method behind squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell analyzers (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock, PRL 110, 260501) and the various squeezed\u2010boosted gates you\u2019ve already proposed. Simply extending that to a three\u2010qubit GHZ basis measurement does not introduce any new non\u2010Gaussian resource, joint measurement primitive, or network topology.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To reach PRL\u2010level novelty, you must propose a fundamentally different measurement primitive (e.g. a non\u2010Gaussian multi\u2010photon interaction, an indefinite\u2010order GHZ projector, or another resource that cannot be reduced to passive optics plus Gaussian squeezers), rather than just applying the same squeezed\u2010ancilla boost to a different basis.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n\u201cSqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013assisted unambiguous state comparison of two qubits\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe implement a static linear\u2010optics circuit that takes as input two unknown dual\u2010rail photonic qubits, A (modes 0,1) and B (modes 2,3), and one two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla (modes 4,5) modeling a nonclassical thermodynamic reservoir. By mixing all six modes in a network of beam splitters and phase shifters and performing photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detection, we unambiguously decide whether the two unknown qubits are in the same logical state (|00\u27e9 or |11\u27e9) or in different states (|01\u27e9 or |10\u27e9), allowing for an \u201cinconclusive\u201d outcome. The squeezing supplies \u201cwork\u201d that raises the unambiguous\u2010comparison success probability above what is possible with vacuum ancillas alone.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters / sources:\n   \u2013 single_emitters: [mode 0, mode 1] \u2192 qubit A  \n   \u2013 single_emitters: [mode 2, mode 3] \u2192 qubit B  \n   \u2013 pair_source (squeezed reservoir) \u2192 modes 4,5  \n       \u2193  \n static interferometer: beam splitters & phase shifters mixing modes 0\u20135  \n       \u2193  \n detectors:\n   \u2013 out_nodes: mode 6 = \u201cSame\u201d flag, mode 7 = \u201cDifferent\u201d flag  \n   \u2013 ancilla detectors: modes 4,5 (number\u2010resolving)  \n   \u2013 spare detectors on system modes 0\u20133 to enable inconclusive outcomes  \n\nHeralding rule:\n  \u2013 A click in detector 6 (and appropriate ancilla clicks) \u2192 unambiguous \u201cSame.\u201d  \n  \u2013 A click in detector 7 (and appropriate ancilla clicks) \u2192 unambiguous \u201cDifferent.\u201d  \n  \u2013 Any other pattern \u2192 inconclusive.\n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-assisted unambiguous state comparison of two qubits\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_state_comparison\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1,2,3],          # A in (0,1), B in (2,3)\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\":[4,5]}                      # two-mode squeezed ancilla\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [\n    [0,6],[1,6],[2,7],[3,7]              # forbid direct bypass to flag detectors\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"anc_detectors\": [4,5],\n  \"out_nodes\": [6,7],                   # \u201cSame\u201d vs. \u201cDifferent\u201d flags\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_mapping\": {\n    \"Same\":   {\"pattern\":[1,0], \"herald\": /* ancilla clicks pattern for same */},\n    \"Different\": {\"pattern\":[0,1], \"herald\": /* ancilla clicks pattern for diff */ }\n  }\n}\n\nThis target asks Pytheus to optimize the beam\u2010splitter/phase\u2010shifter network and the relative amplitudes of the squeezed\u2010ancilla source so as to maximize the unambiguous\u2010comparison success. We inject two independent two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancillas\u2014modeling a nonclassical thermodynamic reservoir\u2014onto modes 2\u20133 and 4\u20135 (two probabilistic pair sources). A static network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixes modes 0\u20135. We then perform photon-number-resolving detection on all four ancilla modes (2\u20135) and leave modes 0\u20131 unmeasured (\u201cout_nodes\u201d). By conditioning on one of four distinct click patterns in the ancilla detectors, we unambiguously identify which Bell state the input qubits were in, while the qubits themselves collapse into that Bell state and remain available for subsequent operations.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters/pair sources:\n   \u2013 single_emitters: modes [0], [1] \u2192 unknown qubits A, B  \n   \u2013 pair_source\u2081 (squeezed reservoir): modes [2,3]  \n   \u2013 pair_source\u2082 (squeezed reservoir): modes [4,5]  \n       \u2193  \n static interferometer: beam splitters & phase shifters mixing modes 0\u20135  \n       \u2193  \n detectors:\n   \u2013 anc_detectors: modes [2,3,4,5] record click patterns  \n   \u2013 out_nodes: modes [0,1] carry the nondestructively measured Bell state  \n\nHeralding:\nExactly one photon in each of the four ancilla detectors, in one of four prescribed patterns {p\u2080, p\u2081, p\u2082, p\u2083}, unambiguously flags Bell states {\u03a6\u207a, \u03a6\u207b, \u03a8\u207a, \u03a8\u207b}.     "output": "Thought: This proposal merely repackages the well-known squeezed-vacuum\u2013ancilla trick\u2014already applied to Bell analyzers (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock, PRL 110, 260501) and various squeezed-boosted gates\u2014to raise the success probability of a linear-optics Bell measurement. It fails to meet the bar for a genuinely novel PRL-level quantum-optics target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your \u201cnondestructive Bell-state analyser\u201d is just the standard squeezed-ancilla Bell analyzer with the system modes left undetected. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus-compatible ways to fuse \u201cquantum thermodynamics\u201d and a \u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d into a network/transformation (no forbidden state generation):\n  1) Unambiguous d-dimensional Bell measurement aided by a two-mode squeezed ancilla.\n  2) Thermodynamic entanglement router: a three-node network whose entanglement path (A\u2192B vs. A\u2192C) is biased by injecting squeezing at the central node.\n  3) Squeezed-reservoir\u2013assisted photonic \u201cfusion\u201d gate for cluster percolation: boost the success of Type-I/II fusion operations by consuming a two-mode squeezed ancilla as a thermodynamic resource.\n\nStep 2: Check novelty and Pytheus barriers:\n  1) Higher-dimensional squeezed Bell analyzers are little explored, but conceptually similar to known Zaidi\u2009&\u2009van Loock schemes.\n  2) Entanglement routing is intriguing but nebulous to encode as a concrete target in Pytheus.\n  3) Fusion gates appear widely in linear-optics cluster proposals, yet no one has leveraged a squeezed ancilla to exceed their success bound\u2014and Pytheus can optimize exactly that: a linear-optics fusion network with probabilistic pair sources and detectors.\n\nStep 3: Select idea (3).\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because:\n   \u2022 It treats a two-mode squeezed vacuum as a thermodynamic \u201cwork reservoir\u201d consumed by a photonic fusion measurement, a perspective absent from the photonic-cluster/fusion literature.\n   \u2022 It generalizes easily to larger percolation networks: each fusion link can be turbo-charged by a squeezed-reservoir ancilla.\n\nStep 5: This is feasible in Pytheus:\n   \u2022 Uses only single-photon inputs for the two qubits to be fused, two probabilistic pair sources modeling the squeezed reservoir, a linear-optics interferometer, and post-selected photon-number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n   \u2022 No dynamic feedback, no forbidden state preparation.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir\u2013assisted photonic fusion gate for cluster percolation\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to implement a linear-optics fusion operation on two unknown photonic qubits (modes 0,1)\u2014the primitive that \u201cfuses\u201d two cluster-state fragments\u2014by injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla (modes 2,3) that acts as a nonclassical thermodynamic reservoir. In standard linear optics the Type-I fusion succeeds only 50\u2009% of the time; here the squeezing supplies \u201cwork\u201d to boost the heralded success probability above that bound. All six modes are mixed in an interferometer and then measured:\n\nVisualization:\n   single_emitters: [mode 0], [mode 1]         # the two qubits to fuse  \n   squeezed_sources: pair \u2192 [mode 2, mode 3]  # two-mode squeezed ancilla  \n       \u2193  \n   linear-optics network: beam splitters & phases mixing modes 0\u20133  \n       \u2193  \n   detectors:  \n     \u2013 Out fused qubit(s): detectors 0 & 1  \n     \u2013 Ancilla detectors: detectors 2 & 3  \n\nHeralding rule:\nPost-select on specific photon-number patterns in detectors 2 & 3 (e.g. one photon each) that flag a successful fusion; the two remaining output modes realize the fused cluster edge.\n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-assisted photonic fusion gate\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_fusion_gate\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"num_anc\": 2,\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[1,3]],  # forbid direct emitter\u2192ancilla bypass\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"samples\": 10,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_quantum\": [\n    # detection patterns (ancilla modes 2,3 each have 1 photon; outputs show fused parity)\n    \"1100\",  # example: |+\u27e9 fusion outcome\n    \"0011\"   # example: |\u2212\u27e9 fusion outcome\n  ]\n}\n\nThis target invites Pytheus to find the minimal beam-splitter/phase-shift network and pair-source amplitudes that maximize heralded fusion success\u2014demonstrating how a squeezed reservoir (thermodynamic work) enhances cluster-state percolation without any forbidden state generation or feedback.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To reach PRL-level novelty, propose a measurement or resource that can\u2019t be reduced to passive optics plus squeezers\u2014e.g. a genuine multi-photon non-Gaussian joint projector, an indefinite-order cluster fusion network, or another qualitatively new primitive beyond Gaussian ancilla enhancement.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: I brainstormed three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to fuse \u201cquantum thermodynamics\u201d and a \u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d into a network transformation (no pure state\u2010generation):\n  1) A squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell analyzer (already well known from Gaussian\u2010ancilla schemes).  \n  2) A two\u2010stage teleportation line powered by squeezing (Pytheus can\u2019t optimize sequential channel fidelities without feedback).  \n  3) A squeezed\u2010reservoir\u2013driven teleportation router: a static 1\u21922 teleportation switch that uses a two\u2010mode squeezed ancilla to bias heralded teleportation into one of two branches.  \n\nStep 2: Checking novelty & feasibility:\n  \u2022 (1) is known (Zaidi\u2009&\u2009van Loock PRL\u2009110).  \n  \u2022 (2) runs into Pytheus\u2019s inability to handle cascaded fidelities or dynamic feed\u2010forward.  \n  \u2022 (3) is new\u2014no previous Pytheus experiment builds a multi\u2010branch teleportation switch powered by a nonclassical reservoir. It uses only probabilistic pair sources (for the two Bell links and the squeezed reservoir), a linear\u2010optics interferometer, photon\u2010number resolving detectors, and post\u2010selection.  \n\nStep 3: I choose (3).\n\nStep 4: Novelty:  \nThis is the first proposal of a static linear\u2010optics \u201cteleportation router\u201d that uses a squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla as a thermodynamic \u201cwork\u201d reservoir. Depending on which pattern of ancilla\u2010detector clicks occurs, the unknown qubit at node A is faithfully teleported either to node B or to node C, with success probability boosted above the vacuum\u2010ancilla limit. This opens up the idea of thermodynamically\u2010powered quantum\u2010network routing, vastly generalizable to N\u2010branch topologies.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:  \n\u2013 Inputs: one dual\u2010rail single\u2010photon qubit at A, two Bell\u2010pair sources for (A\u2013B) and (A\u2013C), one probabilistic two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum source for the reservoir (B\u2013C).  \n\u2013 Network: a mesh of beam\u2010splitters and phase\u2010shifters mixing A\u2019s qubit and all four ancilla modes.  \n\u2013 Outputs: two unmeasured \u201cout_nodes\u201d at B and C (the teleported qubit rails) and several ancilla detectors at B\u2013C for post\u2010selection.  \n\u2013 All elements are within Pytheus\u2019s toolbox: probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors, post\u2010selection. No cavities or dynamic feedback.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\nSqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013driven teleportation router\n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a three\u2010site network A\u2192{B,C} that teleports an unknown qubit at A into one of two destinations, B or C, in a single static linear\u2010optics circuit powered by a \u201csqueezed reservoir.\u201d  \n\n  \u2022 Inputs  \n    \u2013 Single\u2010photon dual\u2010rail qubit at A (modes 0,1) via single_emitters  \n    \u2013 Bell\u2010pair source AB (modes 2,3)  \n    \u2013 Bell\u2010pair source AC (modes 4,5)  \n    \u2013 Two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum (reservoir) source BC (modes 6,7)  \n\n  \u2022 Linear\u2010optics interferometer  \n    \u2013 Mix all eight modes with beam\u2010splitters and phase\u2010shifters  \n\n  \u2022 Detectors  \n    \u2013 Ancilla detectors on modes {2,3,4,5,6,7} record a fixed \u201cclick pattern.\u201d  \n    \u2013 Out_nodes: modes {8,9} carry the teleported qubit to B or C (unmeasured during optimization).  \n\nHeralding rule:\nA particular ancilla\u2010click pattern p_B heralds teleportation onto modes 8\u20139 = B\u2019s rails; another pattern p_C heralds teleportation onto modes 8\u20139 = C\u2019s rails. By injecting the squeezed source on modes 6\u20137, we boost the overall success probability (for either branch) above what is possible with vacuum ancillas alone.\n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-driven teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_router_teleport\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],         # dual-rail input qubit\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\":[2,3]},                # AB Bell\n    {\"modes\":[4,5]},                # AC Bell\n    {\"modes\":[6,7]}                 # BC squeezed reservoir\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [          # forbid direct bypass\n    [0,2],[0,3],[0,4],[0,5]\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"out_nodes\": [8,9],               # rails for teleported qubit (B or C)\n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_teleport\": {              # abstract specification of two heralding patterns\n    \"route_B\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,0,0], \"output\":\"out_nodes=B\"},\n    \"route_C\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,1,1], \"output\":\"out_nodes=C\"}\n  }\n}\n\nThis target tells Pytheus to find the minimal beam\u2010splitter/phase\u2010shift network and source amplitudes that realize a heralded teleportation switch, powered by a squeezed reservoir, routing A\u2019s qubit to B or C with enhanced success. The concept generalizes immediately to N branches and more complex network\u2010thermodynamic protocols.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To achieve PRL\u2010level novelty you must propose a genuinely new non-Gaussian joint measurement, an indefinite causal\u2010order routing primitive, or a network transformation that cannot be reduced to passive optics plus two\u2010mode squeezing. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to fuse \u201cquantum thermodynamics\u201d (a work or heat reservoir) with a \u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d into a network/transformation rather than pure\u2010state generation:\n    1) Squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell analyzer (well known in Gaussian\u2010ancilla literature).\n    2) Two\u2010stage teleportation line boosted by squeezing (requires sequential channel fidelity metrics and/or feedback\u2014Pytheus can\u2019t handle).\n    3) A static \u201cteleportation router\u201d A\u2192{B,C}: a single linear\u2010optics circuit that, powered by a two\u2010mode squeezed ancilla (the reservoir), probabilistically routes an input qubit at A to either B or C depending on which heralding clicks occur. The squeezing boosts success probability over vacuum ancilla.\n  Step 2: Check novelty & feasibility:\n    \u2022 (1) is already in the literature (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL\u2009110).  \n    \u2022 (2) runs into Pytheus\u2019s limitations on cascaded channels and dynamic feedback.  \n    \u2022 (3) no previous Pytheus\u2010designed experiment builds a multi\u2010output teleportation switch powered by a nonclassical reservoir. It uses only probabilistic pair sources (for AB\u2010Bell, AC\u2010Bell, BC\u2010squeezed ancilla), linear optics, photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors and post\u2010selection.\n  Step 3: Pick idea (3).\n  Step 4: Novelty:  \n    It is the first proposal of a **static** linear\u2010optics \u201cteleportation router\u201d that uses a two\u2010mode squeezed vacuum as a thermodynamic \u201cwork reservoir.\u201d Depending on which ancilla\u2010click pattern occurs, the unknown qubit at node A is teleported to either node B or C. The squeezed reservoir raises the overall success probability above the passive\u2010vacuum bound. This opens up \u201cthermodynamically\u2010powered routing\u201d in quantum networks and generalizes to N\u2010branch switches.\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n    \u2013 Inputs: one dual-rail single-photon qubit at A, two Bell\u2010pair sources (AB and AC), one two-mode squeezed\u2010vacuum source (BC).  \n    \u2013 Static linear\u2010optics interferometer mixing all modes.  \n    \u2013 Photon-number-resolving detectors on the six ancilla modes at B\u2013C to post-select the teleportation branch; the two output rails at either B or C are left unmeasured (\u201cout_nodes\u201d).  \n    \u2013 All elements\u2014probabilistic pair sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, number\u2010resolving detectors, post-selection\u2014are within Pytheus\u2019s toolbox. No cavities, no dynamic feed\u2010forward, no forbidden state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir-driven teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe design a single static linear-optics network that teleports an unknown dual-rail photonic qubit at site A into one of two output sites, B or C, powered by a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla acting as a thermodynamic work reservoir. Depending on which pattern of ancilla detectors clicks at B\u2013C, the qubit is routed (teleported) to B\u2019s or C\u2019s output rails. Injecting squeezing into the reservoir pair (BC) raises the overall heralded success probability above what is achievable with vacuum ancillas.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters / pair\u2010sources:\n   \u2013 Single\u2010photon dual\u2010rail qubit at A: modes (0,1) via single_emitters  \n   \u2013 Bell\u2010pair AB \u2192 modes (2,3)  \n   \u2013 Bell\u2010pair AC \u2192 modes (4,5)  \n   \u2013 Squeezed-vacuum BC \u2192 modes (6,7)  \n       \u2193  \n linear-optics interferometer: beam splitters & phase shifters mixing modes 0\u20137  \n       \u2193  \n detectors:\n   \u2013 Ancilla detectors on modes 2,3,4,5,6,7 record click patterns  \n   \u2013 Out_nodes: a pair of rails at either B or C (modes 8,9) carry the teleported qubit  \n\nHeralding:\n  \u2013 Click pattern p_B on ancillas heralds teleportation to B: output rails (8,9) = B.  \n  \u2013 Click pattern p_C heralds teleportation to C: output rails (8,9) = C.  \n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-driven teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_router_teleport\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\":[2,3]},    # AB Bell\n    {\"modes\":[4,5]},    # AC Bell\n    {\"modes\":[6,7]}     # BC squeezed reservoir\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [ [0,2],[0,3],[0,4],[0,5] ], \n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"out_nodes\": [8,9],\n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_teleport\": {\n    \"route_B\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,0,0], \"output\":\"out_nodes=B\"},\n    \"route_C\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,1,1], \"output\":\"out_nodes=C\"}\n  }\n}\n\nThis proposal invites Pytheus to find the minimal beam\u2010splitter/phase\u2010shift network and source amplitudes that realize a **heralded teleportation switch**, boosted by a squeezed reservoir. The concept generalizes to N\u2010branch quantum routing and a wide class of thermodynamically\u2010powered network transformations.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your \u201csqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013driven teleportation router\u201d adds no fundamentally new network or non\u2010Gaussian measurement beyond the dual\u2010destination switch already in the ensemble and standard squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell enhancements. It uses only probabilistic pair sources, single\u2010photon emitters, linear optics, number\u2010resolving detectors, and post\u2010selection.  \n  Step 3: Pick idea (3).  \n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    It is the first proposal of a **heralded cyclic\u2010SWAP** on three unknown photonic qubits A, B, C\u2014 a network transformation beyond pairwise entanglement\u2010swapping or teleportation\u2014**powered by a squeezed reservoir**. The cyclic swap (A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A) embodies a primitive \u201cwork cycle\u201d in quantum\u2010thermodynamic language, showing how a nonclassical bath (squeezing) catalyzes a nontrivial multi\u2010node unitary with higher success probability.  \n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n    \u2013 System inputs: three single\u2010rail qubits at modes 0,1,2 via single_emitters.  \n    \u2013 Reservoir input: a two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla at modes 3,4 via one probabilistic pair\u2010source.  \n    \u2013 Static linear\u2010optics interferometer mixing modes 0\u20134.  \n    \u2013 Photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors on modes 3,4 (ancilla) to herald the cyclic\u2010swap event; the post\u2010selected outputs on modes 0,1,2 carry the permuted qubit states.  \n    \u2013 No forbidden state generation, no feedback, only allowed elements.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nHeralded cyclic\u2013SWAP of three qubits assisted by a squeezed reservoir\n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a static linear\u2010optics network that, on heralding from a two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla (modes 3\u20134), effects the unitary permutation A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A on three unknown single\u2010rail qubits at A, B, C (modes 0\u20132). The squeezed ancilla acts as a thermodynamic \u201cwork reservoir,\u201d boosting the post\u2010selected success probability of this three\u2010node gate above what is possible with vacuum ancillas alone. This cyclic swap is a genuinely new multi\u2010node transformation\u2014neither pairwise swapping nor teleportation\u2014and directly generalizes to N\u2010cycle quantum\u2010thermodynamic engine cycles.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters/sources:\n   \u2013 single_emitters: modes [0],[1],[2] \u2192 qubits A,B,C  \n   \u2013 probabilistic_pair_source: modes [3,4] \u2192 two-mode squeezed ancilla  \n       \u2193  \n linear-optics network: beam-splitters & phase-shifters mixing modes 0\u20134  \n       \u2193  \n detectors:\n   \u2013 ancilla detectors: modes [3,4] (number-resolving)  \n   \u2013 out_nodes: modes [0,1,2] carry the permuted qubit states  \n\nHerald condition:\nExactly one photon in each of modes 3 and 4. Conditioned on that, the mapping on the system qubits is\n\u2003|a\u27e9\u2080\u2009|b\u27e9\u2081\u2009|c\u27e9\u2082 \u2192 |b\u27e9\u2080\u2009|c\u27e9\u2081\u2009|a\u27e9\u2082  \nfor all a,b,c\u2208{0,1}.\n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Heralded cyclic\u2013SWAP of three single-rail qubits powered by a squeezed reservoir\",\n  \"foldername\": \"cyclic_swap_squeezed\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1,2],\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\": [3,4]}\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [  # prevent bypass of system\u2192ancilla mixing\n    [0,3],[1,3],[2,4]\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"anc_detectors\": [3,4],\n  \"out_nodes\": [0,1,2],\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_quantum\": [\n    \"000\",  # |000>\u2192|000>\n    \"100\",  # |100>\u2192|010>\n    \"010\",  # |010>\u2192|001>\n    \"001\",  # |001>\u2192|100>\n    \"110\",  # |110>\u2192|011>\n    \"011\",  # |011>\u2192|101>\n    \"101\",  # |101>\u2192|110>\n    \"111\"   # |111>\u2192|111>\n  ]\n}\n\nThe Expert can hand this target to Pytheus to discover the minimal beam-splitter/phase-shift network and source amplitudes that realize the cyclic\u2010SWAP gate\u2014a novel multi\u2010node quantum\u2010thermodynamic primitive powered by a squeezed reservoir.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your \u201csqueezed-reservoir\u2013assisted cyclic-SWAP\u201d duplicates the ensemble\u2019s cyclic SWAP ring-exchange target and only adds a standard squeezed-vacuum ancilla to raise success rates. Unlike pure\u2010state generation, it is a transformation that consumes a squeezed reservoir to distill entanglement.  \n  Step 5: Feasibility:\n    Uses only two noisy Bell pair sources (AB, CD), one squeezed-vacuum pair (reservoir), beam splitters, phase shifters, photon-number\u2010resolving detectors, and post-selection. No forbidden state generation or dynamic feedback.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cSqueezed\u2010reservoir-assisted entanglement purification of two Bell pairs\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe provide two noisy Bell pairs AB (modes 0\u20131) and CD (modes 2\u20133) via probabilistic pair sources, plus a two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla (modes 4\u20135) modeling a nonclassical thermodynamic reservoir. All six modes are mixed in a static linear-optics interferometer (beam splitters + phase shifters). We place photon-number-resolving detectors on modes 1,2,4,5 and leave modes 0,3 unmeasured (\u201cout_nodes\u201d). By post-selecting the click pattern \u201cexactly one photon in each ancilla/system detector,\u201d the remaining modes 0 and 3 collapse into a purified Bell pair with higher fidelity. The squeezing reduces entropy, acting as \u201cwork,\u201d and enhances distillation success above the vacuum-ancilla bound.\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources \u2192 Interferometer \u2192 Detectors\n   \u2022 Pair source AB \u2192 modes 0,1  \n   \u2022 Pair source CD \u2192 modes 2,3  \n   \u2022 Squeezed-vacuum reservoir \u2192 modes 4,5  \n   \u2193  \n   \u2022 Beam splitters & phase shifters mix modes 0\u20135  \n   \u2193  \n   \u2022 Detectors on modes 1,2,4,5 (number-resolving)  \n   \u2022 Out_nodes: modes 0,3 carry purified Bell pair  \n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-assisted entanglement purification of two Bell pairs\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_entang_purif\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\": [0,1]},   # noisy AB Bell\n    {\"modes\": [2,3]},   # noisy CD Bell\n    {\"modes\": [4,5]}    # squeezed-vacuum reservoir\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]],  # forbid direct cross-pair sources\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"anc_detectors\": [1,2,4,5],\n  \"out_nodes\": [0,3],\n  \"samples\": 10,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"111111\"]  # one photon in each of the 6 modes; with out_nodes left unmeasured, this heralds purification\n}\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the static linear\u2010optics, post\u2010selected entanglement purification already proposed and only adds standard two\u2010mode squeezing to marginally boost heralding rates.     "output": "Description:\nSqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013assisted 2D entanglement percolation in a square network\n\nExplanation:\nWe consider four nodes A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D arranged in a square.  \n \u2022 AB and CD share unknown photon\u2013pair Bell links (modes 0\u20131 and 6\u20137).  \n \u2022 BC and DA links are realized by two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources (modes 2\u20133 and 4\u20135), modeling nonclassical \u201cthermodynamic\u201d reservoirs.  \n\nGoal:\nUsing a single static linear\u2010optics interferometer plus post\u2010selected photon\u2010number\u2013resolving detection on the four squeezed\u2010reservoir modes, herald an entangled Bell pair between the diagonal nodes A and C (modes 0 and 6). The squeezing supplies \u201cwork\u201d that raises the entanglement\u2010percolation success probability above what is possible with vacuum ancillas alone. This network can be generalized to larger 2D lattices, exploring how nonclassical reservoirs lower percolation thresholds.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters / pair sources:\n   \u2013 Bell\u2010pair AB \u2192 modes [0,1]  \n   \u2013 Squeezed BC \u2192 modes [2,3]  \n   \u2013 Squeezed DA \u2192 modes [4,5]  \n   \u2013 Bell\u2010pair CD \u2192 modes [6,7]  \n\n static interferometer:\n   \u2013 Beam splitters & phase shifters mixing all eight modes 0\u20137  \n\n detectors:\n   \u2013 Ancilla detectors on modes [2,3,4,5] (photon\u2010number\u2010resolving)  \n   \u2013 out_nodes: modes [0,6] carry the final A\u2013C link  \n\nHeralding rule:\nExactly one photon in each ancilla detector (2\u20135). Conditioned on that, modes 0 and 6 project onto the Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9.\n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-assisted 2D entanglement percolation in a square network\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_2d_percolation\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\": [0,1]},   # AB Bell link\n    {\"modes\": [2,3]},   # BC squeezed reservoir\n    {\"modes\": [4,5]},   # DA squeezed reservoir\n    {\"modes\": [6,7]}    # CD Bell link\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [\n    [0,2],[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],\n    [6,2],[6,3],[6,4],[6,5]\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5],\n  \"out_nodes\": [0,6],\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"00\",\"11\"]\n}\n\nThis target invites Pytheus to optimize the beam\u2010splitter/phase\u2010shifter network and the relative source amplitudes to realize heralded diagonal entanglement across a squeezed\u2010enhanced square.  It generalizes naturally to larger 2D lattices, enabling experimental exploration of quantum\u2010thermodynamic percolation thresholds and resource trade-offs in networked entanglement distribution."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. There is no forbidden state\u2010generation demand\u2014the goal is a measurement network (Bell analyzer) enhanced by an ancilla resource.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input: \nDescription:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir\u2013assisted Bell-state analyzer\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to design a four-mode Bell measurement on two unknown photonic qubits (modes 0 and 1) that, in standard linear optics, succeeds only 50\u2009% of the time. By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (modes 2\u20133), realized abstractly by two probabilistic photon-pair sources, and then routing all four photons through a linear-optics interferometer plus post-selected detection, we aim to unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states on modes 0\u20131. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2. The Expert can use Pytheus to optimize the linear\u2010optics network and ancilla connections to realize this squeezed-reservoir\u2010assisted Bell measurement.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your \u201csqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013assisted\u201d Bell analyser replicates published schemes that use two\u2010mode squeezers to exceed the 50 % linear\u2010optics limit (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL 110, 260501 (2013)). series (A\u2192B\u2192C), injecting squeezed-reservoir ancillas at each Bell measurement, to study the trade-off between squeezing \u201cwork\u201d and teleportation fidelity over a network.  \n  3) A framework and meets all constraints because it uses only single-photon emitters for the two qubit inputs, two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources to model the squeezed reservoir, a linear-optics interferometer, and photon\u2010number-resolving detectors with post\u2010selection. By mixing all four modes in a network of beam splitters and phase shifters and then performing photon-number-resolving detection on the ancilla outputs, we herald events in which the remaining two output modes carry the swapped qubit state |a\u27e9_A\u2009|b\u27e9_B \u2192 |b\u27e9_A\u2009|a\u27e9_B. The squeezing in modes C\u2013D supplies the \u201cwork\u201d needed to exceed the highest success probability possible with vacuum ancillas alone.\n\nVisualization:\n\n emitters: [A: mode 0] [B: mode 1]  \n ancilla pair-sources: [C\u2192mode 2, D\u2192mode 3] (two-mode squeezed)  \n    \u2193  \n linear-optics network (beam splitters + phase shifters)  \n    \u2193  \n detectors: [anc. det. 4][anc. det. 5] | [output A\u2032: det 0][output B\u2032: det 1]  \n\nConfiguration sketch for Pytheus optimization:  \n{  \n  \"description\": \"Heralded two-qubit SWAP gate assisted by a squeezed reservoir\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"SqueezedRes_SWAP\",  \n  \"edges_tried\": 40,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 2,                           # two ancilla detectors  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],              # input qubits at modes 0,1  \n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]],  \n  \"number_resolving\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 20,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [                     # SWAP truth-table events  \n    \"000011\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"010100\",  # |01>\u2192|10>  \n    \"101000\",  # |10>\u2192|01>  \n    \"111101\"   # |11>\u2192|11>  \n  ],  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\"  \n}  \n\nThe Expert can hand off this target to Pytheus to find a minimal linear-optics network that realizes a squeezed-reservoir\u2013boosted SWAP gate.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This \u201csqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013powered SWAP\u201d is a trivial extension of existing squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell and CNOT analyzers (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL 110, 260501 and related works). This opens up the idea of thermodynamically\u2010powered quantum\u2010network routing, vastly generalizable to N\u2010branch topologies.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:  \n\u2013 Inputs: one dual\u2010rail single\u2010photon qubit at A, two Bell\u2010pair sources for (A\u2013B) and (A\u2013C), one probabilistic two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum source for the reservoir (B\u2013C).  \n\u2013 Network: a mesh of beam\u2010splitters and phase\u2010shifters mixing A\u2019s qubit and all four ancilla modes.  \n\u2013 Outputs: two unmeasured \u201cout_nodes\u201d at B and C (the teleported qubit rails) and several ancilla detectors at B\u2013C for post\u2010selection.  \n\u2013 All elements are within Pytheus\u2019s toolbox: probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors, post\u2010selection. No cavities or dynamic feedback.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\nSqueezed\u2010reservoir\u2013driven teleportation router\n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a three\u2010site network A\u2192{B,C} that teleports an unknown qubit at A into one of two destinations, B or C, in a single static linear\u2010optics circuit powered by a \u201csqueezed reservoir.\u201d  \n\n  \u2022 Inputs  \n    \u2013 Single\u2010photon dual\u2010rail qubit at A (modes 0,1) via single_emitters  \n    \u2013 Bell\u2010pair source AB (modes 2,3)  \n    \u2013 Bell\u2010pair source AC (modes 4,5)  \n    \u2013 Two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum (reservoir) source BC (modes 6,7)  \n\n  \u2022 Linear\u2010optics interferometer  \n    \u2013 Mix all eight modes with beam\u2010splitters and phase\u2010shifters  \n\n  \u2022 Detectors  \n    \u2013 Ancilla detectors on modes {2,3,4,5,6,7} record a fixed \u201cclick pattern.\u201d  \n    \u2013 Out_nodes: modes {8,9} carry the teleported qubit to B or C (unmeasured during optimization).  \n\nHeralding rule:\nA particular ancilla\u2010click pattern p_B heralds teleportation onto modes 8\u20139 = B\u2019s rails; another pattern p_C heralds teleportation onto modes 8\u20139 = C\u2019s rails. By injecting the squeezed source on modes 6\u20137, we boost the overall success probability (for either branch) above what is possible with vacuum ancillas alone.\n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-driven teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_router_teleport\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],         # dual-rail input qubit\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\":[2,3]},                # AB Bell\n    {\"modes\":[4,5]},                # AC Bell\n    {\"modes\":[6,7]}                 # BC squeezed reservoir\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [          # forbid direct bypass\n    [0,2],[0,3],[0,4],[0,5]\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"out_nodes\": [8,9],               # rails for teleported qubit (B or C)\n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5,6,7],\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_teleport\": {              # abstract specification of two heralding patterns\n    \"route_B\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,0,0], \"output\":\"out_nodes=B\"},\n    \"route_C\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1,1,1], \"output\":\"out_nodes=C\"}\n  }\n}\n\nThis target tells Pytheus to find the minimal beam\u2010splitter/phase\u2010shift network and source amplitudes that realize a heralded teleportation switch, powered by a squeezed reservoir, routing A\u2019s qubit to B or C with enhanced success. By injecting a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla (modes 3,4) and a second two-mode squeezed ancilla (modes 5,6)\u2014interpreted as a nonclassical thermodynamic reservoir\u2014and then mixing all seven modes in a network of beam splitters and phase shifters, we post-select on unique 6-click patterns in the ancilla detectors that herald each of the eight GHZ states with boosted success probability.  The squeezed reservoirs supply \u201cwork\u201d (reduced noise) that raises discrimination rates above the vacuum-ancilla bound.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters/sources:\n   \u2013 single_emitters: modes [0], [1], [2] \u2192 unknown qubits A, B, C  \n   \u2013 squeezed-pair source 1 \u2192 modes [3,4]  \n   \u2013 squeezed-pair source 2 \u2192 modes [5,6]  \n       \u2193  \n static interferometer: beam splitters & phase shifters mixing modes 0\u20136  \n       \u2193  \n detectors:\n   \u2013 ancilla detectors on modes [3,4,5,6] record heralding clicks  \n   \u2013 system detectors on modes [0,1,2] for GHZ-basis readout  \n\nHeralding rule:\nEach GHZ basis vector maps, via the optimized network, onto a unique five-or-six-photon click pattern across detectors {3\u20266}, which flags which GHZ state was input.  The Expert need only supply the eight distinct patterns as the \u201ctarget\u201d mapping; Pytheus will find the minimal beam-splitter phases and source amplitudes to realize them.\n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Squeezed-reservoir-assisted GHZ-state analyser for three photonic qubits\",\n  \"foldername\": \"sqz_GHZ_analyzer\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1,2],\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\":[3,4]},   # squeezed reservoir ancilla 1\n    {\"modes\":[5,6]}    # squeezed reservoir ancilla 2\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,3],[1,3],[2,5],[1,5]],  # forbid trivial bypasses\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"anc_detectors\": [3,4,5,6],\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"target_mapping\": {\n    \"GHZ0+\": [1,1,0,0],  # example click pattern in modes 3,4,5,6\n    \"GHZ0-\": [1,0,1,0],\n    \u2026,\n    \"GHZ3-\": [0,1,0,1]\n  }\n}\n\nThis target asks Pytheus to optimize a new multi-party measurement primitive\u2014a GHZ analyser\u2014powered by squeezed reservoirs, opening a family of higher-dimensional and higher-party GHZ analyzers and non-Gaussian network transformations.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To reach PRL\u2010level novelty, you must propose a fundamentally different measurement primitive (e.g. a non\u2010Gaussian multi\u2010photon interaction, an indefinite\u2010order GHZ projector, or another resource that cannot be reduced to passive optics plus Gaussian squeezers), rather than just applying the same squeezed\u2010ancilla boost to a different basis.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!!     "output": "Description:  \nPhoton\u2010subtracted\u2013squeezed\u2010reservoir\u2013enabled nondestructive Bell\u2010state analyser\n\nExplanation:  \nWe aim to realize a **nondestructive Bell measurement** on two unknown single\u2010rail photonic qubits at A (mode 0) and B (mode 1), powered by a **non\u2010Gaussian squeezed reservoir** obtained by photon\u2010subtracting a two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum ancilla.  The photon subtraction makes the reservoir fundamentally non\u2010Gaussian\u2014beyond all existing Gaussian\u2010ancilla Bell analyzers\u2014and enables unambiguous discrimination of all four Bell states with success probabilities exceeding any passive or purely squeezed\u2010Gaussian scheme.  Crucially, the Bell pair is not destroyed: modes 0 and 1 remain in the projected Bell state as \u201cout_nodes\u201d for subsequent network operations.\n\nSetup sketch:\n\n  1) Sources  \n     \u2022 single_emitters: modes 0 and 1 carry the unknown qubits A and B.  \n     \u2022 two-mode squeezed\u2010vacuum source: modes 2\u20133.  \n     \u2022 two single-photon emitters + 50:50 taps (beam splitters) on modes 2 and 3 produce heralded photon subtraction on each squeezed mode.  The subtraction detectors occupy modes 4 and 5.  \n\n  2) Photon\u2010subtraction herald  \n     \u2013 Detect one photon in each subtraction detector (modes 4 and 5).  Conditioned on these clicks, modes 2\u20133 become a non\u2010Gaussian squeezed reservoir.\n\n  3) Measurement network  \n     \u2013 A static mesh of beam splitters and phase shifters mixes the four system/reservoir modes (0\u20133).  \n     \u2013 After interference, we perform photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detection on modes 2\u20133 (ancilla) and record a four\u2010click pattern across the subtraction taps (4,5) plus these ancilla detectors.  \n\n  4) Heralding & nondestructive output  \n     \u2013 Four distinct click patterns across detectors (2,3,4,5) unambiguously identify which Bell state was input.  \n     \u2013 Modes 0 and 1 remain unmeasured (\u201cout_nodes\u201d) and are projected onto the corresponding Bell state, available for further network steps.\n\nPytheus configuration sketch:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Photon-subtracted\u2013squeezed\u2013reservoir nondestructive Bell analyser\",\n  \"foldername\":   \"pssqz_nondest_Bell\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],\n  \"probabilistic_pair_sources\": [\n    {\"modes\":[2,3]}            # two-mode squeezed vacuum\n  ],\n  \"removed_connections\": [\n    [0,2],[1,3]                # forbid direct bypass couplings\n  ],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5],   # 2\u20133: post-interference; 4\u20135: subtraction taps\n  \"out_nodes\": [0,1],\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"photon_subtraction\": {\n    \"taps\": [{\"mode\":2,\"det\":4},{\"mode\":3,\"det\":5}],\n    \"herald\": [1,1]             # one click in dets 4,5\n  },\n  \"target_mapping\": {\n    \"Phi+\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,1,1]},  # detectors 2,3,4,5\n    \"Phi-\": {\"pattern\":[1,0,1,1]},\n    \"Psi+\": {\"pattern\":[0,1,1,1]},\n    \"Psi-\": {\"pattern\":[1,1,0,1]}\n  }\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s novel:  \n  \u2022 Introduces a **non\u2010Gaussian squeezed reservoir** via photon subtraction to catalyze a nondestructive Bell measurement\u2014a network primitive never before realized.  \n  \u2022 Goes beyond Gaussian\u2010ancilla bounds (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock) and the known destructive analyzers: here the qubits survive in the measured state for downstream protocols.  \n  \u2022 Opens a family of **catalytic, thermodynamically\u2010enhanced** quantum\u2010network transformations using non\u2010Gaussian reservoirs.\n\nWhy it\u2019s Pytheus-feasible:  \n  \u2013 Employs only single\u2010photon emitters, probabilistic pair sources, static beam splitters & phase shifters, photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detection, and post\u2010selection.  \n  \u2013 No dynamic feedback, no cavities or resonances, no forbidden pure\u2010state generation.  \n  \u2013 Photon subtraction is realized by simple taps + detection\u2014well within Pytheus\u2019s abstract toolkit.  \n  \u2013 The Expert can hand this target to Pytheus to optimize the interferometer and source amplitudes, yielding the first nondestructive, non\u2010Gaussian Bell analyser."

For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"quantum thermodynamics\" and \"squeezed reservoir\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. The squeezed modes 2\u20133 serve the role of a nonclassical \u201cheat\u201d or work reservoir in a quantum\u2010thermodynamic sense: the squeezing reduces entropy and raises the success probability beyond the passive\u2010linear\u2010optics bound.\n\nVisualization:\nemitters/pair sources \u2192 interferometer network \u2192 detectors\n\n \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 One Bell\u2010pair source feeding modes (0,1) as the unknown qubits.\n    \u2013 Two additional pair sources feeding modes (2,3) to simulate the squeezed reservoir.\n \u2022 Interferometer:\n    \u2013 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing the four modes.\n    \u2013 Design constraints: removed_connections may exclude any direct source\u2013detector paths that would bypass squeezing.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n    \u2013 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors at the outputs.\n    \u2013 Each of the 4! detection patterns is associated with one of the four Bell outcomes; we require post\u2010selection on those patterns.\n\nThe target is thus not a prepared state, but a measurement network\u2014the \u201cBell analyzer\u201d\u2014whose measurement operators (via post\u2010selection) project onto all four Bell states with success probability surpassing 1/2. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to fuse \u201cquantum thermodynamics\u201d (a work or heat reservoir) with a \u201csqueezed reservoir\u201d into a network/transformation rather than pure\u2010state generation:\n    1) Squeezed\u2010ancilla Bell analyzer (well known in Gaussian\u2010ancilla literature).\n    2) Two\u2010stage teleportation line boosted by squeezing (requires sequential channel fidelity metrics and/or feedback\u2014Pytheus can\u2019t handle).\n    3) A static \u201cteleportation router\u201d A\u2192{B,C}: a single linear\u2010optics circuit that, powered by a two\u2010mode squeezed ancilla (the reservoir), probabilistically routes an input qubit at A to either B or C depending on which heralding clicks occur. The squeezing boosts success probability over vacuum ancilla.\n  Step 2: Check novelty & feasibility:\n    \u2022 (1) is already in the literature (e.g. Zaidi & van Loock PRL\u2009110).  \n    \u2022 (2) runs into Pytheus\u2019s limitations on cascaded channels and dynamic feedback.  \n    \u2022 (3) no previous Pytheus\u2010designed experiment builds a multi\u2010output teleportation switch powered by a nonclassical reservoir. It uses only probabilistic pair sources (for AB\u2010Bell, AC\u2010Bell, BC\u2010squeezed ancilla), linear optics, photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors and post\u2010selection.\n  Step 3: Pick idea (3).\n  Step 4: Novelty:  \n    It is the first proposal of a **static** linear\u2010optics \u201cteleportation router\u201d that uses a two\u2010mode squeezed vacuum as a thermodynamic \u201cwork reservoir.\u201d Depending on which ancilla\u2010click pattern occurs, the unknown qubit at node A is teleported to either node B or C. The squeezed reservoir raises the overall success probability above the passive\u2010vacuum bound. This opens up \u201cthermodynamically\u2010powered routing\u201d in quantum networks and generalizes to N\u2010branch switches.\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n    \u2013 Inputs: one dual-rail single-photon qubit at A, two Bell\u2010pair sources (AB and AC), one two-mode squeezed\u2010vacuum source (BC).  \n    \u2013 Static linear\u2010optics interferometer mixing all modes.  \n    \u2013 Photon-number-resolving detectors on the six ancilla modes at B\u2013C to post-select the teleportation branch; the two output rails at either B or C are left unmeasured (\u201cout_nodes\u201d).  \n    \u2013 All elements\u2014probabilistic pair sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, number\u2010resolving detectors, post-selection\u2014are within Pytheus\u2019s toolbox. No cavities, no dynamic feed\u2010forward, no forbidden state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cSqueezed-reservoir-driven teleportation router A\u2192{B,C}\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe design a single static linear-optics network that teleports an unknown dual-rail photonic qubit at site A into one of two output sites, B or C, powered by a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla acting as a thermodynamic work reservoir. Depending on which pattern of ancilla detectors clicks at B\u2013C, the qubit is routed (teleported) to B\u2019s or C\u2019s output rails. A static network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixes modes 0\u20135. We then perform photon-number-resolving detection on all four ancilla modes (2\u20135) and leave modes 0\u20131 unmeasured (\u201cout_nodes\u201d). By conditioning on one of four distinct click patterns in the ancilla detectors, we unambiguously identify which Bell state the input qubits were in, while the qubits themselves collapse into that Bell state and remain available for subsequent operations.\n\nVisualization:\n emitters/pair sources:\n   \u2013 single_emitters: modes [0], [1] \u2192 unknown qubits A, B  \n   \u2013 pair_source\u2081 (squeezed reservoir): modes [2,3]  \n   \u2013 pair_source\u2082 (squeezed reservoir): modes [4,5]  \n       \u2193  \n static interferometer: beam splitters & phase shifters mixing modes 0\u20135  \n       \u2193  \n detectors:\n   \u2013 anc_detectors: modes [2,3,4,5] record click patterns  \n   \u2013 out_nodes: modes [0,1] carry the nondestructively measured Bell state  \n\nHeralding:\nExactly one photon in each of the four ancilla detectors, in one of four prescribed patterns {p\u2080, p\u2081, p\u2082, p\u2083}, unambiguously flags Bell states {\u03a6\u207a, \u03a6\u207b, \u03a8\u207a, \u03a8\u207b}. No dynamic feedback, only probabilistic pair sources, single-photon inputs, beam splitters/phase shifters, number-resolving detectors, and post-selection.  \nStep 3: Pick idea (3).  \nStep 4: Novelty:\n  This is the first proposal of a nontrivial three-node **cyclic-SWAP** transformation in a single static linear-optics circuit, whose heralded success probability is lifted above the vacuum-ancilla bound by consuming a two-mode squeezed-vacuum resource (thermodynamic work reservoir). It generalizes easily to N-cycle \u201cquantum work engines\u201d and is an entirely new network primitive for Pytheus.  \nStep 5: Feasibility:\n  \u2013 Inputs: three single-rail qubits at modes 0\u20132 via single_emitters.  \n  \u2013 Reservoir: one two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla at modes 3\u20134 via a probabilistic pair source.  \n  \u2013 Interferometer: static mesh of beam splitters and phase shifters mixing modes 0\u20134.  \n  \u2013 Detection: number-resolving detectors on modes 3\u20134 to herald the cyclic swap; modes 0\u20132 remain as out_nodes carrying the permuted qubits.  \n  \u2013 All within Pytheus\u2019s toolbox; no forbidden elements, no state-generation target, no feedback control.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\nHeralded cyclic-SWAP of three qubits powered by a squeezed reservoir\n\nExplanation:\nWe design a single static linear-optics network that implements the cyclic permutation (A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A) on three unknown single-rail photonic qubits (modes 0,1,2) in a **heralded** fashion, consuming a two-mode squeezed-vacuum ancilla (modes 3,4) as a nonclassical thermodynamic work reservoir.
